PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate concerning the order of 7 December 1992 for the tabling of a note for file relating to the New Zealand experience with its goods and services tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the letter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button has tabled an arrogant, two-paragraph letter refusing to accede to the Senate's instruction to table the note for file by two Treasury officers on the New Zealand experience with a goods and services tax. In this letter, Senator Button has not even deigned to spell out in any detail his argument for not complying with the Senate's order. We have to look at Senator Button's answer to the Senate on Monday to discern the reasons. On Monday, Senator Button told the Senate that the reason the note could not be tabled was that it contained confidential discussions between Australian and New Zealand officials. He then relied on Treasury advice, apparently, that releasing any more of the report would damage Australia's continuing interest in obtaining information from foreign governments and from non-official sources. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has apparently accepted that advice.

PARA.TAB: Having told us how important this particular document was, Senator Button then went on to try to convince the Senate that it was of no particular consequence at all. Of course, we can recall the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, saying on the same day, `Who cares what the Treasury thinks?'. We could go on and say, `Who cares about the facts? Don't let the facts influence debate. Don't let anything compromise the Government's scare campaign'.

Senator Button demeaned the Treasury officers by implying they had no particular expertise in reporting on the impact of the GST and its public acceptance. In my view, the more that governments try to suppress papers, the more that governments convince the people there is something highly embarrassing to hide. What a tangled web we weave when first we set out to deceive.

What the Government wants to hide is this: I refer Senator McMullan, who is at the table, to a Sydney Morning Herald article last Saturday. To refresh Senator McMullan's mind, I invite him to look at the headline, which reads, `Kiwis love GST, says secret Treasury paper'. That is the reason, and that is the only reason, why the Government refuses to table this document.

The coalition will be seeking further advice on the options available to the Senate to secure the release of this document. We are determined that the terms of the Senate resolution requiring the tabling of the note of the Treasury officers and their assessment of the GST in New Zealand will be fulfilled.

Senator Button implies that the paper is inconsequential, yet the Government is determined that it will not be released to the public. Honourable senators will recall that a few short months ago the Senate demanded that the Marshall Islands papers be tabled. There were volumes of them. In the Kelly tape saga, the Government, after protest, produced a transcript of the relevant part of the tape, and even then the Government was censured by the Senate. Recently, the Senate forced a report on Medicare fraud to be made available. This was also produced to a Senate committee.

Mr President, you have to go back to the loans affair of 1975 to find a case where the government has flatly refused to produce a document to the Senate. Of course, we know the background to that particular scandal.

This issue now goes far beyond the particular paper prepared by the Treasury officers. The Government is attempting to establish a precedent which will restrict the powers of the Senate to demand the delivery of documents which are important and sometimes vital to ensure proper accountability of the Executive.

What is so special about these papers—this note for file—which did not apply in the Marshall Islands papers case that Senator Evans delivered to this chamber? As you can recall, Mr President, the Marshall Islands papers dealt with private correspondence, notes of conversations with government officials of a foreign country, memoranda, notes between senior officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and, of course, sensitive cables.

Yet we are told today that the Government cannot table this particular document because of the confidential nature of intergovernmental discussions. The rules which applied in respect of the Marshall Islands papers—papers which, I suggest, had serious consequences for this Government, and Senator Richardson can confirm that, and for the Government of the Marshall Islands—do not apparently apply, to use Senator Button's terms, to this inconsequential Treasury note, which he believes could damage Australia's ability to obtain information from foreign countries.

If the ceaseless public attacks by Mr Keating and the Labor Party advertisements attacking New Zealand have not damaged relations between our two countries, what a fantastic notion it is to assume that this note has the potential to damage those relations. I happen to be a Victorian. Senator McMullan will be interested to know that the Labor Party, with its TV advertisements which were so highly successful in the Victorian election, spent the first week of its campaign attempting to tell lies, do damage to and spread deceit about the situation in New Zealand.

So all this vitriol from Mr Keating and all these Labor Party TV advertisements apparently do not have the potential to damage relations between our countries. But a document which indicates the success of the GST in New Zealand will, apparently, damage relations. How contorted can the Government's logic become! What does Mr Keating have to hide?

In this chamber Senator Button said, again with some twisted logic, that he had not even read the Treasury note, which was very convenient, I must say. But, at the same time, he believed that the headline in the Sydney Morning Herald, `"Kiwis love GST", says secret Treasury paper', could not be justified. Some logic! The reason why the Government will not table this paper is that it will expose the Government's lies and deceit on the goods and services tax.

Mr President, in conclusion, I draw your attention to this morning's editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald. This is what it says on the refusal of the Government to table this paper on the effects of the GST in New Zealand:

How else to explain Mr Keating's amazing performance over the Treasury paper on the effect of the GST in New Zealand? The study was commissioned in September last year, when Mr Keating was Treasurer in the Hawke Government. Obviously it was meant to provide ammunition against the Opposition's GST proposals for Australia. (And if it had, no doubt we would never have heard the end of it.)

SPEECH.PARA: Quite so.
Unfortunately for the Government, the Treasury team came back persuaded that the GST in New Zealand was not the disaster its detractors had assumed it to be.
Then it goes on to say:

Even so, the paper represents a powerful contradiction of the line Mr Keating has been pushing on the perils of the GST. In the face of even the limited disclosure of the Treasury paper, he has reacted with uncharacteristic panic and confusion. He who has so often sought to bolster his own policies with evidence of Treasury support now says: "Who cares what Treasury thinks?" He who was presumably happy to see a Treasury team sent to gather information in New Zealand last year now says: "Frankly, as if you'd go to a Treasury team for a public view about New Zealand. I mean, the Treasury, whatever it is, it's not a public relations firm. . .
And so it goes on. The Government is condemned for refusing to table this document. Senator Button is now in the chamber; I wonder whether he has yet had time to read it. Maybe he will tell us.

PARA.TAB: This is a very serious matter. It should particularly concern the Australian Democrats in this chamber. Make no mistake—

TALK.START.PARA: —No shabby deals.

—Make no mistake, Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter: if the Government refuses to table this document—this document which we are led to believe is inconsequential—then I can assure the Democrats that the possibility of the Senate requiring governments in the future to table what they may regard as important documents is zero. It is a very big issue. Again I would ask the Australian Democrats to consider the precedent which may be set by the Government's refusal to table this document.

PARA.TAB: The Government is not afraid of damaging its relations with New Zealand; it is afraid of something Mr Keating regards as being of greater importance. Mr Keating's fear is that the Government's lies and deceit on the GST will be exposed; that is why the Government is refusing to table this document today. This is the document the Australian people had to have. This is the document which contradicts Keating's scare campaign. We will seek further ways to ensure that this document is exposed to public view. The coalition does not accept this letter. We will continue by all possible means to secure the release of this document.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you frightened of, Bob?

—We all know what those opposite are frightened of. It is very obvious; it is on the public record. It is on the page of the Sydney Morning Herald that Senator Kemp did not read. We all know what the Opposition is worried about. That is why only Senator Kemp is leading in this debate instead of anybody serious.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Where are yours?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why I am responding—because we are not taking it very seriously. Opposition senators are right. I do not disagree with that; there is no argument from me about that. Why would anybody bother to come in for all that?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I believe that that is a reflection on Senator Kemp, particularly when the Government does not even have a Minister standing in reply. We have not got a front bench, we have no Government Ministers—
—Order! It is not a point of order. It is a debating point, and you know it, Senator Walters.

—It is a bit unpalatable for those opposite, and I understand that. Mr President, you should be sympathetic towards them today—they are in pain. Maybe they should be put down and put out of their misery.

PARA.TAB: There is a capacity to distinguish between two things: the document itself is of little consequence, but that does not mean that the release of it is of little consequence. Those two things are not corollaries for the reason that Senator Button and I outlined to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read it?
—No. The fact of the matter is that there is no—
—Why don't you just sit down? You don't know what you are talking about.

—If no-one speaks who has not read the document, it will be a very short debate, and I will be delighted. The fact of the matter is that one does not have to read the document to know the consequence of its release. It is quite straightforward. The arguments as to why it should not be released, which have been put by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and me in this place, still stand. They relate to the way in which the information in the document was gained and the implications not just for our relations with New Zealand but for our relations with every country with which we have confidential discussion. Those relationships will be undermined by any indication that the Senate can, by mere resolution, require the tabling of documents that may be contrary to the public interest and that may do damage to our relationships with other countries.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely true, as this Senate has resolved, that the freedom of information rules do not explicitly constrain the material that is presented to the Parliament. The Senate has resolved that, and there is no disagreement about it. But it is also true that where the element of the FOI principle that applies relates to the national interest, it is a fact which government at least has to take into account and, I would have thought, the Senate would wish to take into account. If somebody wishes to argue that the national interest principles of FOI—to put it very broadly—have not been properly applied, then the forums to resolve that exist. If people want to examine it, they can choose to do so if they wish. That is not a matter for the Government to determine. It is a matter for the people who seek the information.

There is no sensible need to reiterate why we do not intend to release the document. The argument has been put by the Treasurer, by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and by me. It is not as if we wish to hide from a debate about the GST. Every opportunity that the Australian people can get to debate the GST, we will take—here, in the public arena, anywhere. The Australian people are working out what they think about the GST, as the people of New Zealand are. The Government in New Zealand is rating even lower than the Opposition is rating in Australia. That is very hard to do, but it is doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long has it been in in New Zealand, you galah?

—The New Zealand Government has been in office for five years and for most of those years New Zealand has been in recession. That is absolutely right. Senator Walters is quite correct. New Zealand's rate of growth is less than Australia's rate of growth. It has been in recession for four out of the five years it has had a GST. New Zealand continues to grow less quickly than Australia.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp was heard in relative silence. The same thing should apply to Senator McMullan.

—We all know that this is just a little diversion for people who are a bit worried about some other stories that are going on. Let us get on to the issues that the Australian people would like to talk about. There is some legislation on the Notice Paper. There are important issues around about Liberal governments sacking people. Let us talk about those issues, issues that people are concerned about. Or let us talk about the substance of the GST, about what impact it will have on Australians, about the concerns of the unemployed about the impact of other aspects of Fightback. Let us get on with the business. If the Opposition wants to take note of the letter, of course we do not object. We will vote for that. But we will not be tabling the document for the reasons outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Kemp to take note of the document. In doing so, I express the disgust of those in the Liberal and National parties—and I am sure I speak for the Australian Democrats and the Independents as well; in fact, for all people in Australia who treasure democracy—at the outrage this Government perpetrates in the way it treats resolutions of a duly elected chamber of this Parliament. The Parliament asks the Government to do something. The Government simply ignores it and throws in the face of the elected people, of democracy, its refusal to comply with properly worded and properly passed resolutions of the Senate.
—They did the same thing before.

—Yes. They treat this Parliament with absolute contempt, in the same way as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) treats democracy generally. He has no interest in it and he says so publicly. It is no wonder that the Government chose its most junior person to respond to this debate. It is fairly obvious why Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, came into the chamber but left straight away. He did not want to be embarrassed by this tragedy of democracy being perpetrated today. Senator Button was not prepared to stand here and face a refusal by the Government to comply with this request of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: This Government is the most incompetent, ignorant and insensitive government that this nation has ever known. I call it a government. That is almost a misnomer. The Government will only be on the treasury bench for the next one or two months until it is game to call an election. But there is that direction of the Senate which the Government has chosen to ignore.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—I know Senator McKiernan wants to say something about this. He does not often say much of particular sense, but he certainly hit the nail on the head when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are 900,000 reasons why Paul Keating should not be elected Prime Minister of Australia. The man who gave us the recession we had to have should not now be rewarded for that accomplishment.
I want Senator McKiernan to tell me why he now supports the man who brought 900,000 unemployed into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than that now.

—As Senator Chapman says, there are many more than that now. Senator McKiernan should support me in what I say about the Prime Minister. It is no wonder Senator Ray referred to the Prime Minister as a clown, although he was only half right: the Prime Minister certainly is a joke, but clowns are supposed to give some joy and happiness to people. Mr Keating has done anything but that. He has given an inordinate amount of unhappiness and unpleasantness to most Australians by putting almost two million of our fellow Australians out of work. He is a man who simply will not abide by the will of this democratically elected chamber. He does not believe in democracy and he does not understand how the institutions of Parliament work.

PARA.TAB: This Government has been incompetent in its management. After 10 years, it has no solution. It has presided over the worst recession in Australia since the 1930s. It has no policy, no vision, and no idea of what needs to be done; it has taken a bandaid approach. There are almost two million unemployed or underemployed, a $162 billion national debt and record bankruptcies. People are simply giving up hope in this period before Christmas. I paled, as no doubt did many others, when I heard Mr Keating on the weekend trying to obtain some credibility by announcing that he was giving money to the poor. He is not giving money to the poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —He created the poor.

—He has created the poor. He seems to think that the money which belongs to the taxpayers of Australia, which he is giving out to the poor—the poor that he created—is his. It disturbs me greatly that that man could be so insensitive as to try to indicate that he is giving his money to the poor.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party will not allow the Treasury paper on the GST experience in New Zealand to be published. It is simply more of the campaign of Labor lies. It is not the first time that the Labor Party has not been well served by the Treasury. The Labor Party was running around saying that the GST will cost everybody 15 per cent more to live. Treasury quickly put paid to that lie of the Labor Party by saying, `The coalition's estimate of 4.4 per cent increase in the cost of living is wrong'—but it is wrong on the high side. Treasury said that it was only 3.6 per cent. The Labor Party did not like that.
Mr Tony Cole, the Secretary to the Treasury, said that Australia needed a GST. An article in the Courier-Mail stated:
The Treasury secretary, Mr Tony Cole, shocked businessmen at a closed-door meeting with his favourable comments on the tax which is the key plank in the federal coalition's election platform.
He said it would help boost exports and was likely to increase savings . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say that it was what was needed. This is not surprising, because the Treasury understands what is needed. This analysis of the GST in New Zealand supports the Treasury and indicates how beneficial the GST has been for New Zealand. This Government is running scared and will not allow it to be published. It does not really need to be; there is a wealth of other information.

PARA.TAB: I will quote Sir Roger Douglas, someone who, I think, comes from the same Keating school of economics because he, like Mr Keating, thinks that the GST is a good proposal. You are aware, Mr President, as are all senators, that Mr Keating supported a GST because he understood that it was right for Australia. On the Pru Goward show on Monday, Sir Roger was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: For whom is the GST administratively difficult, Sir Roger?
He said:
I don't think it's particularly difficult at all. . .
He was asked:
How much time a month does it [the administration] take?
Sir Roger, again completely refuting the Labor lies, said:
So, you know, I don't think it takes very long at all.
The Labor lies are shattered by such people who understand what the GST is really about and by the Treasury document that this Government is not prepared to table. Sir Roger went on to say:

We introduced a goods and services tax which certainly put the price up of a lot of items, but some actually came down because we were removing wholesale tax. It's much the same as you'll be doing in Australia. . . But on the other hand, personal income tax came off. So, in New Zealand, it was very popular. We went from about 35 per cent support for GST prior to its introduction, to something like 65 per cent within the month of its introduction, because people felt good about it.

Sir Roger is a member of the Labour Party. The New Zealand Labour Party introduced it. He knows why it was introduced, as does Mr Keating. That is why I think they must have gone to the same economics school. He and Mr Keating understand why it is needed. He said:

They felt that they had more money in their back pocket, they had more money to spend, and what they made is a judgment that the extra cash they had in their back pocket more than offset any increase in prices. So they were very happy about it.

Senator Aulich knows that people in Australia on the average wage of about $25,000, after the implementation of the Fightback package and after they have paid any GST, will have $38 per week—every week—more in their pockets as a result of the Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: I find it abhorrent that the Labor Party, which currently occupies the treasury bench, is ignoring the will of this Parliament. It is doing so for crass political benefit, because it does not want the Australian public to understand how other countries have dealt with the GST and how beneficial it has been. It does not want more of the Labor lies exposed. It wants to try to hide this material and keep it from the Australian public.

I support Senator Kemp's remarks entirely. I know that there are a lot of my colleagues who would like to participate in this debate, but the timing and the scheduling of the Senate do not permit it. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour this day.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1. Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2. We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programs of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes that:

(i)on 9 September 1992, officers of the Department of Industrial Relations provided Senator Newman with a briefing on progress on the issue of the recognition of service with the Australian Defence Force as continuous service with the Commonwealth for the calculation of redundancy benefits,

(ii)Senator Newman was told the issue was being fast-tracked and that a report and recommendation would be with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) by no later than Christmas 1992, and that this was confirmed to Senator Newman when she sought advice on progress several weeks ago, and

(iii)this issue has been before the Department of Industrial Relations since May 1991 and that delays by the department have caused, and continue to cause, financial loss to a number of former Australian Defence Force employees of the Commonwealth; and
(b)calls on Senator Cook to confirm:
(i)that the issue will be finalised by Christmas 1992, and
(ii)that the date of effect of the revised policy will be May 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Sherry I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 30 November 1992, requiring the Select Committee on Superannuation to present its report on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992 by 10 December 1992, be modified to provide that the committee present its report on or before 14 December 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)with dismay, the continued refusal by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) to reverse his decision which prohibits Australian Research Fellowships being tenable at Commonwealth research organisations or at the Institute of Advanced Studies at the Australian National University (ANU), and

(ii)that this decision is not only completely unjustified, but is also contrary to the objectives of the fellowship scheme, which were to encourage the return of world-class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the national interest;

PARA.TAB: (b)deplores the fact that:

TAB.TAB: (i)this decision will deny researchers the opportunity to conduct their research in the most appropriate institutions, and will compromise Australia's ability to attract back high quality people who are, at present, overseas, and
(ii)Mr Baldwin's decision will particularly penalise institutions such as the ANU and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation which have high profiles internationally; and

PARA.TAB: (c)calls on Mr Baldwin to reverse his decision immediately, for the sake of the continuing success of Australia's research and his professed commitment to the development of Australia as the `clever country'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)a writ for more than $4 million was lodged in the Tasmanian Supreme Court in the week beginning 29 November 1992, claiming that Tasmanian Government officials were negligent in the establishment of the flat oyster culture program,
(ii)the program was established to develop a commercial export market for native flat oysters,
(iii)in March 1992, isolation orders were imposed on oyster farms following fears that diseased oysters from the program may have been transferred to the farms,

(iv)the isolation order was lifted 2 weeks ago and a state-wide blanket classification on bonamia was imposed, against the advice of Tasmanian oyster growers and contrary to internationally recognised methods of dealing with the disease, and
(v)these actions of the Tasmanian Government provide evidence of gross mismanagement and vindictiveness and show it to be out of touch with industry and industry practices; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to review urgently the action by the Tasmanian Government and its effect on interstate trade and Australia's international obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate invites Mr Justice Marcus Einfeld to refrain from making public statements of a political nature about matters which may fall within an area where he has jurisdiction as a judge of the Federal Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes, with alarm, that at least 44 people in New South Wales and Victoria died in 1992 while on waiting lists for coronary bypass surgery; and
(b)calls on the Government to encourage people to take out private hospital insurance in order to relieve the overcrowding of the public hospital system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the announcement on 8 December 1992 by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) that he will be amending the Coalition's Fightback! package later in December 1992,
(ii)that the Fightback! package is a manifesto of scorched earth policies, including zero or negligible tariff levels for our manufacturing industries by the year 2000, and

(iii)that car makers, textile, clothing and footwear industries, sugar growers and even some sections of the National Party have found it impossible to accept tariff and industry policies which are destroying Australian industries; and

PARA.TAB: (b)urges the Coalition, in its amendments, to modify its stance on tariffs if it is sincerely committed to fighting the social and economic costs of the current recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that—

(a)the most recent High Court unanimous decision involving Kodak and Genex v Australian Taxation Office, which held that negatives used to produce photographic prints were not subject to sales tax, is a further manifestation of the problems, complexity and uncertainty surrounding the outmoded, unsatisfactory sales tax system; and
(b)that the Government's changes to the legislation, to take effect from 1 January 1993, will prospectively nullify the High Court decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Zakharov, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the alleged misuse of Department of Social Security printing facilities, reported on pages 194 and 199 of the Estimates Committee D Hansard of 17 September 1992, be postponed till the fifth sitting day of the 1993 sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the notice I have given on behalf of Senator Zakharov.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee cannot report on 10 December as it will still be taking evidence on this inquiry next Tuesday. Thus, it will not have the time to consider a report on the matter before the end of these sittings.
—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes with concern that—
(a)on the day on which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) expressed his approval that business had achieved greater profitability, the mining industry reported a plummet in profits of 27 per cent; and

(b)recovery from the recession will not be achieved until the Prime Minister levels with the Australian people on the seriousness of the recession he said we had to have, and concedes the total lack of recovery apparent now, or in the foreseeable future, under the `more of the same' policies he currently promotes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that 10 December is International Human Rights Day;
(b)expresses concern that, despite a public commitment to international standards of human rights, far too many nations continue to violate basic human rights standards;
(c)endorses the work of human rights organisations, such as Amnesty International, which actively promote the principles enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights; and

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dealing with specific items relating to individual departments, I would like to make some comments with regard to the reallocation of funds overall because that issue covers all departments. I believe it would be appropriate to direct some comments at the overall thrust of these Bills as they have been returned from the Estimates Committee.
—This might be an appropriate time to do so.

—The Bills currently before the Committee of the Whole have been returned after consideration by Estimates Committee B. They seek to reallocate $150m in the current financial year which was previously earmarked in the One Nation statement and allocated in this year's Budget for rail projects, and also seek to reallocate $24m intended to be provided for electricity infrastructure. These funds are to be allocated to other infrastructure and short term job creation projects within the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, the Department of Transport and Communications, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

PARA.TAB: These Bills really mean that the much vaunted One Nation policy statement from February of this year, which was this Government's election manifesto, is once and for all dead and buried, that the August Budget has been blown apart before the ink has even dried on the Budget Papers, and that, as was admitted by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) in the Estimates Committee hearing, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has replaced micro-economic reform, which is urgently needed to create real long term sustainable jobs, with short term political expediency by throwing dollars around in the departments to which I referred a few moments ago to create some short term mickey mouse make-work jobs which will evaporate after the election.

While the Labor Party undoubtedly seems to understand the pressing need for decisive and critical change, election year frenzy sees it game planning so that next year we will see yet another trumped up accord with the Party's union backers with little real reform being achieved. It is fair to say that it is not only the Opposition which is critical of this failed Government's inadequate foray into reform; the report of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade entitled Australia's business challenge: South-East Asia in the 1990s, produced by the Department's East Asia analytical unit, also seriously challenges the extent of Prime Minister Keating's commitment to tangible reform. It has come hot on the heels of the Industry Commission report which similarly criticises the speed of the Government's reform agenda. That Industry Commission report asserts most strongly that further gains are still needed in transport and on the waterfront, but this Government, through this legislation, is ripping out a substantial allocation for the current financial year from the land transport sector.

The head of the Government's own micro-economic reform think tank, Industry Commission Chairman Bill Scales, actually named specific government services such as transport, power and the labour market as the top reform priorities. Yet, as we heard in that Estimates Committee hearing, the funds are being ripped from transport and power this year to be spent on other vote winning measures. In the light of the Government's claims that it is pursuing the micro-economic reform agenda, such reforms are seriously imperiled by this reallocation of funds, as are its claims that the reallocation is necessary following its review of the progress of expenditure allocated to infrastructure projects in the Budget to ensure the goals of its One Nation document are met.

The excuses that were offered in the Estimates Committee hearings for siphoning off these funds from much needed reform areas were far from convincing. What we have is $150m being extracted from important land transport programs fundamental to transport reform across the country and given to other programs, and next financial year the same amount will be returned to land transport.

The Government claims that logistical and design delays, as well as a changed demand for labour market programs, have prevented the full allocation of the $283m to the national rail system. But these lame excuses fly in the face of the Government's pace setting of micro-economic reform strategies. Recent bad balance of payments figures are quick to show that the need for pressing reforms remains crucial and nowhere more urgent than in the area of labour market reform.

We now have both of these Appropriation Bills returned to us from last Friday's hearings of Estimates Committee B, of which, along with my Liberal colleagues Senators Short and Tierney, I was a member. These Bills reflect the Government's second guessing on the urgency of micro-economic reform. The outcome of that Estimates Committee B hearing, as recorded in the report, which has been tabled as part of this Committee of the Whole debate, and also as recorded in the Hansard of that Committee hearing, confirms the justification of referring these Bills to Estimates hearings.

At the hearing last Friday, in responding to my questioning, Senator McMullan admitted that indeed these changes in funding arrangements were a setback to micro-economic reform as they would slow down the pace of reform. This admission is highlighted in clause 27 of the report of the Committee to this chamber. As the Committee Hansard records at page B756, I asked the Parliamentary Secretary, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: Has any assessment been made as to whether we can, in effect, afford to lose a year of micro-economic reform compared with our competitor nations which are simply pressing on with making their economies more competitive? As a result of losing that year, how many long term real jobs will not be created in exchange for these short term, make work jobs, that are being created because of the reallocation of funds?
Senator McMullan replied, inter alia:

. . . I accept that there is a setback to the pace at which we could prefer to be undertaking the spending . . . it will make the enhancement of the efficiency of the rail infrastructure a slower process, and that is a negative for national economic efficiency . . . there is a net loss to the rate at which economic efficiency is increased.

So there it is writ large. Micro-economic reform, which is so essential to increase our exports to reduce the massive $180 billion burden of foreign debt, to restart our economy and, above all, to create real long term jobs, is to be put on the backburner—to be sacrificed—so that the money can be used to create the short term illusion that unemployment is falling for cynical electoral purposes; the hope that it will win enough votes to return this destructive Government to another undeserved term in office.

PARA.TAB: I say to the Australian people, `Do not be fooled by this; do not be sucked in. If you give them another chance at government you will rue the day. You will suffer even more than you have suffered through this continuing recession that we had to have'. The Government's own bible for remaining in office, One Nation, offers free and open competition as being the engine which drives efficiency to be achieved through micro-economic reform.

It further refers to micro-economic reform being the basic determinant of Australia's international competitiveness, essential to minimising the impact of our geographical isolation and the location of our national resources. One Nation went to great and laborious pains to stress the importance of having a first class, nationally linked rail network, and its supposed far-sighted content has long been echoed by the Prime Minister.

Even the annual report of the Department of Transport and Communications, which was tabled only last week, highlights the $454m investment program to increase efficiency between rail and sea transport and to improve road-rail facilities. We are now told that this will be put on the backburner for 12 months. What happens to the Government's supposed grand concerns about the urgent necessities of introducing micro-economic reform? The Prime Minister's televised claims on 18 November that micro-economic reform is just about completed and that we do not have to concern ourselves about getting the Federal Budget back into structural surplus are absolute nonsense. This is demonstrated by the huge current account deficit, which has so far averaged $1.7 billion a month this financial year.

Far from slowing down the pace and tapering off, at least in this financial year, as the Prime Minister is doing by removing this specific allocation from land transport and allocating it to the other departments, we need to move more quickly on structural reform. The reason we need to do so is brought out in the Industry Commission's annual report. The Chairman, Bill Scales, has made the point well that to pause now with structural reform will undermine the process of change that is required to tackle underlying and persistent unemployment in Australia.

The Government cannot afford to dally any longer. It must urgently build on previous structural and micro-economic reforms to deliver economic growth, jobs and higher standards of living. It must concentrate on delivering long term jobs which will be here in the future—not mickey mouse choices for training programs, not options which shunt the unemployed from one dispenser of money to another and not options which hide the real unemployed or which disguise the terrible disfigurement this community suffers because the Government declines to accept the reality that it is not creating real employment.

This Government, with the launch of its One Nation plan, which it still hopes will save its bacon, is in the disguise business. It disguises unemployment figures by inventing a whole raft of courses and programs to temporarily provide respite for thousands of jobless. This is so those on training programs will not swell the true unemployment figure and the Government can say that unemployment has tapered off. Unemployment will be brought down only with appropriate policies which tackle micro-economic reform issues and assist in the restructuring of industries already overburdened with restrictive unproductive practices. The invention of temporary stopgap measures merely prolongs the agony of those waiting for the scenario to improve. This nation is in need of uncompromising hard action, and it needs that right now.

Even the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, has in recent days come out in support of Australia's need to define adequately its long term economic priorities, particularly in its pursuit of growth. These calls strengthen support for the belief that there is an urgent need for a stable and credible framework to assist longer term decision-making in Australia by a government that is not driven by crisis management.

Already this year Australia has suffered a 40 per cent deterioration in the current account deficit compared with the same period last year. The creation of long term jobs, rather than short term pro tem options, remains the central need of our recovery. Goodness knows what the visiting Japanese delegation—organised by the Keidanren, a peak business group—which met in Victoria on the day of the national dispute last week, thinks of our mishandling of reform in labour management issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would have got a pretty low opinion of Jeff Kennett.

—I think they have a pretty low opinion of this Government's failure to institute adequate industrial relations reform. Given that industrial relations reform and micro-economic reform are at the top of that delegation's agenda, future investment from Japan may now be in question not only in Victoria but also in projects right across Australia.

PARA.TAB: With unemployment remaining high and a Federal election just around the corner, the spectacle of the Government dallying with fiscal stimuli and promising much in the way of economic growth is grim indeed. Australia simply cannot afford this cynical short term posturing for perceived political gain. Australia has to become a more flexible, efficient producer and, according to the Industry Commission, we can. The economy can grind up and our industries can grab a faster share of world markets without exacerbating inflation or running into the brick wall of balance of payments constraints.

For the Prime Minister to claim that Australia is locked into the fastest growing part of the world and that our more open economic system is off and running is clearly nonsense. His further claim that all we had to do was to get the recovery phase moving and that our position in the 1990s from a low inflationary base was going to be very attractive are also quite overrated. The only inroads this Government has made in the micro-economic reform area have been essentially to place it on the public agenda and bring it to people's attention. But this is only a precursor to the reform process. Such limitations are obvious.

The centralised control of the labour market has remained virtually intact. There are some improved efficiencies from the partial reform of the waterfront, but they have not been passed on to service users. The reform of telecommunications and aviation remains unbalanced. A duopoly arrangement will remain in place until 1997 and, with respect to airline deregulation, foreign carriers are prevented from competing on domestic markets. In other spheres, such as postal services, Labor retains monopolies in areas crucial to the effective operation of business.

I return to my opening remarks that Labor has not adequately addressed road and rail inefficiencies. This ripping off of funding which was earlier allocated to rectify pressure in these two areas is nothing short of confirming that the Government is not at all serious about keeping up the pace of long overdue reform. It is deliberately slowing down the pace. The Federal election is just around the corner and, with a government which cannot demonstrate its total commitment to fast-tracking the micro-economic reform agenda to sustain the long term interests of this country, fortunately it will soon be the Federal Opposition.

PARA.TAB: A number of points are related to the fundamental question we are discussing this morning; that is, where the $150m is being spent and why it is not being spent on the projects for which it was originally set aside. Senator Chapman made great play of the Industry Commission's report, which clearly he has not read. He is simply commenting on the press reports that emanated from that report, most of which were inaccurate. If Senator Chapman had read the Industry Commission report, he would know that the Commission not only gave credit to the Government's micro-economic reform program in the transport and communications area, but also talked about the dividend that Australia has received from it—and the Commission used the word `dividend'. But one of the fundamental problems with that policy, one of the cruelest lies that Fightback tells—its fundamental fraud—is contained in its employment projections. PARA.TAB: In fact, even on the most optimistic scenario, the employment projection tables in Fightback are not two million jobs by the year 2000; they are, in fact, 1.6 million. —Mr Chairman, can I say something?
—There is nothing to be said. We have a dissent from the Chairman's ruling. It means that we have to go back into the full Senate, and I am awaiting the return of the President.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The President having resumed the chair—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in accordance with the matters for dealing with Appropriations, after hearing two 15-minute speeches, I ruled that there would be no further speeches of that nature and that, in accordance with the normal procedures, we would move to an examination of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and start with an examination of subprogram 1.11, whereupon Senator Baume disagreed with my ruling because he wished to respond to some comments made by Senator Collins.
—Unfortunately, I was not listening to the debate because I was at a Presiding Officers meeting. It might be appropriate at this stage, Senator Baume, if you give the reasons why you are dissenting.

—The reasons are simple. As the Chairman said, Senator Chapman had, in fact, cleverly made a speech canvassing matters raised in evidence before the Committee but in such a way that Senator Collins regarded it, wrongly, as somehow straying outside the requirements of the debate. The Chairman himself conceded that it was cleverly done and within Standing Orders because he allowed Senator Chapman to proceed and acknowledged the cleverness of the method used by him, which we approve of.

PARA.TAB: There was no cleverness in the blatant abuse of the Standing Orders by Senator Collins, who spent 10 minutes attacking Fightback, attacking its employment projections and attacking the GST, none of which, basically, had anything to do with the matters before the chamber. I sought from the Chairman exactly the same lenience as he had given—on reflection, totally improperly—to Senator Collins, giving him scope to spend that time attacking the Fightback package.

It is intolerable for a Minister to be given the opportunity to attack the coalition's policies without the coalition being given the opportunity to respond. It is on the basis of fairness, decency and the right of proper debate that I should be allowed to respond. I certainly do not intend to take 15 minutes; Senator Collins could be demolished in five. He failed to mention the fact that the GST exists basically to provide part of the funding for the removal of seven taxes, all of which are taxes on employment. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said that payroll tax costs 250,000 jobs. Senator Collins did not have the honesty to admit that that is one of the taxes that will be removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is a serious and totally regrettable debate on a dissent from the ruling of the Chair. It is not a debate on the virtues of the Fightback document.
—I remind Senator Baume of what he is supposed to be debating.

—I am debating the need for us to have the right to reply to the continual Labor lies about Fightback. It is a pattern of deception and deceit which has continued for 10 months. It is improper for this Minister to get up here, abuse the Standing Orders and be allowed to get away with it while any response is not permitted. Mr President, it is a disgrace, and that is why I move dissent from the Chairman's ruling.

—Mr President, regrettably, Senator Baume—and the Hansard will show it—is condemned out of his own mouth. In his contribution a few minutes ago, he not only conceded but agreed that Senator Chapman had made a second reading speech.
—I did not say that. If you are going to lie, do it effectively.
—Mr President, I ask for that remark to be withdrawn.
—I withdraw. If the Minister is going to tell untruths, he should do so honestly.

—The Hansard will show not only that Senator Baume referred to the clever second reading speech of Senator Chapman—which description I agreed with—but also that Senator Baume went on to say that he and his colleagues agreed with the Chairman in the cleverness of Senator Chapman's attempt to get around the Standing Orders. The fact is that the Chairman's ruling was impeccably correct.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman and I both delivered 15-minute speeches that were both totally out of order. As the Hansard will show, Senator Chapman spent 15 minutes attacking the policies of the Government, and I spent 15 minutes attacking the policies of the Opposition. That is not an unusual event in this chamber, but it is not appropriate to do it in the detailed committee consideration of the appropriations. The Chairman's ruling was therefore absolutely correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I want to put this matter in very simple terms. After Senator Chapman spoke, the Chairman said that there would be no more speeches of the length of a speech in a second reading debate. He said all the things that Senator Baume said. He then said, `We will now go to the appropriations'. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) then stood up and said—these words will be shown to be correct—that he wanted the right to reply. The Chairman, instead of saying `No, I am going to stick with my ruling that there will be no more long speeches', allowed the Minister to proceed. Senator Baume is now saying that if it was good enough for Senator Collins to give a speech it should be all right for him to give a speech to refute what Senator Collins said.
—Then we'll do it for the rest of the day.
—Maybe that will happen. I believe that Senator Baume is correct in saying what he did. I firmly stick by what Senator Baume said about the way that the proceedings went.

—It appears that a degree of laxity has been allowed. But it is time to get back to the rules. The Standing Orders quite clearly say that senators should relate their remarks only to matters raised in the Estimates committees. I ask senators from both sides to do that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—I have moved dissent. What happens now?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have supported the Chairman's ruling.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—I persist with my motion of dissent.
Senator Collins—You have to move dissent from the President's ruling.
Senator Michael Baume—Yes, absolutely.
Senator Collins—You have to do it in writing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you moving dissent from the ruling that I just made?

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—Yes, Mr President, on the basis of equity and fairness. Mr President, may I have your indulgence to make a brief statement?
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it has been pointed out to me that we have a very large and long list of legislation to get through and that a division on this matter will simply take up more time—time already wasted by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in his quite disgraceful and insupportable attack on Fightback. I acknowledge the fact that his view of democracy is such that I should not have the right to respond to his nonsense. I also acknowledge the fact that the Government has no interest in hearing the facts about the removal of seven taxes under Fightback, all of which are basically taxes on employment.
—Are you sure you will still be moving it?

—It is intriguing to hear such interjections from Senator Collins when this debate is about this Government changing its mind about its own Budget before the Budget was even passed. What sort of double standards do we have? But this is typical of this Government.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins admitted that he spent 15 minutes not defending the Government from the quite proper attack by Senator Chapman that was within the Standing Orders—because it is indefensible—but in attacking the coalition's Fightback package. His speech had nothing to do with the debate; the Chairman of Committees knew it and yet he allowed it to persist. That is my concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down.

—I will not be instructed by Senator Collins to sit down. He stood for a quarter of an hour and told the most incredible nonsense—I am not allowed to use the word `lies'—about Fightback, and he knew it to be nonsense. Senator Collins knows that the GST is to pay for part of the removal of seven taxes, most of which are taxes that have cost jobs. One of them is the payroll tax, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said will cost something like a quarter of a million jobs. We will get rid of those taxes.
—Get on with it.

—I will not accept Senator McMullan's instructions. He has supported a proposition which gags me from responding to Senator Collins in that debate. If we had a touch of honesty from this Government about Fightback instead of this consistent campaign of lies, it would remove the need for us to seek a fair go in this chamber and to move the sort of motion that I now intend to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins's double standards are incredible. He is so `flexible' that even before the Budget is passed, he is changing it in this way and switching money out of failed programs. Yet he attacks the Opposition as being `inflexible' and `hard' when we suggest that the economy has now deteriorated so disastrously that further measures will be needed. The Minister's double standards are a disgrace. Quite frankly, the sooner we get the opportunity to debate this matter fairly in the real chamber—that is, outside the Senate, if it is to be run like this—and the sooner we get the chance to debate it in an election, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, are you withdrawing?
—I am withdrawing.

—I thank Senator Baume. I repeat that regardless of whether laxity might or might not have been allowed, the Chair was placed in a position where it had to rule strictly in accordance with the Standing Orders and the way it has always been ruled before.
—Order! The Committee will proceed to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories program 1, subprogram 1.1.1, National Museum of Australia.

—In the Estimates Committee B hearing, as recorded on page B785 of the Hansard report of that hearing, Senator Baume asked questions in relation to the establishment of a foundation for the restoration of old Parliament House which I had in fact advocated as acting shadow Minister for Senator Baume's portfolio a couple of years ago. Senator Baume's question was, in effect, `Has anything been done about that proposal to establish a foundation with tax deductible donations to fund the major restoration?'. Mr Williams replied, `Not that I am aware of'.

PARA.TAB: I ask why nothing has been done about that proposal, given that there is obviously a shortage of funds available for the refurbishment and full restoration of old Parliament House. The establishment of a tax deductible foundation would cut by half the cost to government of achieving those goals because it would simply provide the tax deductions which would cost half of what it would if the Government had to provide all the funds rather than private people providing those funds on a tax deductible donation basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can do is confirm the advice that was given by the officers at Estimates, which is that that has not been done. I think it is a perfectly sensible idea and would assist enormously in preserving and utilising the enormous historical asset that we have in the old Parliament House. I will certainly bring Senator Chapman's concern to the attention of the Minister. I might also indicate my view to the Minister that such a proposal should be supported and expedited.
—I thank the Minister for that assurance.

—I wish to make a brief point on the matter of the old Parliament House. The level of deterioration that is occurring there is a matter about which both Senator Chapman and I have expressed concern. We note from the Estimates hearing that the revenue to be raised by admission fees to this exhibition—the fit-out for which will cost $1.25m—is simply to go towards replacing the cost of about $1m worth of maintenance that is funded entirely by the Commonwealth at the moment.

PARA.TAB: In other words, the revenue from using the old Parliament House will not go towards doing anything extra to preserve or restore it in any way. It is simply to replace some of the appropriation of about $1m being used to maintain it inadequately. That is the point I want to stress. The roughly $1m per year being spent on the old Parliament House does not maintain it adequately, according to all the available evidence. I understand that it is continuing to deteriorate and leaks are not being fixed. Senator Chapman is nodding, and that emerged from the evidence, as I understand it.

This rate of deterioration is so great that the ultimate cost of finally refurbishing the building and getting it to a proper maintenance level has increased in recent years from $48m to $60m. I admit that included in that $60m is the cost of removing some of the later additions to the building, but what concerns us on this side of the chamber is that the $1m currently allocated is not adequately meeting the needs of maintaining this historic building properly and that further deterioration is taking place. It seems unreasonable that the extra revenue to be gained from this exhibition is not to be used to increase the capacity to do something to restore what is certainly Australia's most historic political building.

There were those in this Parliament and this Government who were keen to see the building deteriorate even further to justify their ultimate decision, they hoped, to bulldoze it because the view of or from this Parliament House building was somehow rendered less attractive by the existence of this historic former Parliament House. That is not a view shared by the Opposition. We are totally opposed to any suggestion that that building be bulldozed. It is vital that it be restored, and restored properly. We regret that it has deteriorated so dramatically since the Government made its decision not adequately to fund its maintenance.

I stress that the coalition believed in 1988 that the Speaker's chair in the old House of Representatives chamber should come to the new building because it was of historic significance. That was blocked by this Government on the grounds that the old Parliament House was to be turned into a parliamentary museum and, therefore, the Speaker's chair should appropriately be there.

Four and half years later, what has happened? The building has deteriorated further. At last an exhibition is to be mounted, but if maintenance goes on at the same rate as it is now this building will continue to deteriorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing I can usefully say in response to Senator Baume's comments. I think Senator Baume would concede that what he is talking about is a separate question of major appropriations from some future Budget to a major work of restoring the building. How the coalition would do that and maintain its pledge to cut $7 billion from public spending, I do not know. But that is a separate question.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the sum of money that Senator Baume mentioned is currently keeping the building in reasonable repair. That was certainly my view the last time I visited the old Parliament House. I know this is straying from the debate and that Senator Baume will forgive me for this, but I am not going to go down to Parliament House—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume may, but I might not.

—That is true, Mr Chairman. I am not going down to the old Parliament House again until it is more fully restored as an historical site, because going there again reminded me of how much I liked the old chambers and how much I detest the new ones. They were actually debating chambers and they really are beautiful. I felt quite depressed after leaving the building and coming back to this.

PARA.TAB: I support Senator Baume, and I am sure we all do, in wanting to see those appropriations made at some future time. Senator Baume would concede that the sums of money are significant. It is once more a question of priorities in terms of determining appropriations.

I believe—and most members and senators would support me in saying this—that some priority should be given in a future Budget to conducting the major restoration of the old building to its original historical shape, in which we would all like to see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Burns, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee B.

—Briefly, on the point my colleague Senator Baume made about the old Parliament House and relative to the Appropriations, I ask the Minister whether the Government and the Labor Party have any plan, vision, policy or proposal for the old Parliament House. I know it does not have any of those things for the rest of the economy.

PARA.TAB: In the ACT it is our policy and vision that tourism will ever increase and create jobs in this region of the Commonwealth of Australia. Tourism is one of Canberra's growing assets. It is one industry that we will be fostering, and one of the things that bring people to Canberra is the old Parliament House, which is probably one of the most historic buildings in Australia. It is historic for very many reasons. One that always appeals to me is that it was the venue of those momentous times when a previous Labor Government was got rid of. It is almost a shrine that many people come to for that reason alone to pay homage and thanks that those events happened there 20 years ago.

In the context of job creation in the Canberra region and the ACT, jobs can be created from tourism, which is something we want to build up in the ACT. Does the Government have any plan, vision or policies to do something to correct the deterioration that has been going on and to enshrine that building as a true national monument?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes. As the Government published this proposal, I am surprised that the shadow Minister for the ACT was not across it. Indeed, the Government's proposal—and it has been widely debated—is to maintain and manage the building in a way that will restore the building to its original design.

PARA.TAB: It will be established as a museum of political history on the main floor and managed as an outpost of the National Museum of Australia. The lower floor planning will accommodate the Electoral Commission's education centre, a government information centre, a headquarters and education exhibition centre for the Australian Heritage Commission and an ACT Tourism Commission information booth, and privately operated franchised eating and catering facilities will also be included in these arrangements.

I fully support this proposed use of the building, and I commend the South Australian Government for doing precisely that with the old Parliament House in South Australia, which I have visited. It is a much smaller building, but nevertheless an extremely interesting historical exhibit which is well frequented by tourists and Australians who are particularly interested in the political history of this country. I have no doubt that the old national Parliament House will certainly be as successful a museum of political history as the old Parliament House in South Australia has proved to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no further matters in relation to subprogram 1.11, and none in relation to program 4, subprogram 4.2 or questions taken on notion in relation to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, the Committee will move to the Department of Transport and Communications, program 4, Land Transport, the road safety improvement package.

—Information was tabled today, I think by Senator Faulkner on behalf of Senator Burns, in relation to the road safety improvement package. It is a thick wad of documents which contains among its pages a list of projects under the black spot program. It was one of the issues I raised in the Estimates hearing. I sought a full list of the black spot projects that would be funded through the additional funds provided in Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. I ask whether the list that has been provided in these papers is a full list of projects, including those resulting from the additional funds, or whether it is the list which was approved prior to the reallocation of moneys. I notice that the press releases and so on which are attached to the list are dated in September, which would lead to the conclusion that the projects were the original projects approved, not the additional projects.

—The list does not include the new projects. The reason for that is that the detail of the actual black spots that will be assisted with the additional funding is a matter for consultation between the Federal Government and the State governments. I am advised that that information is still in the process of being put together in terms of what the State governments are assessing as their priorities for the spending of that money. Only one additional program has been received from a State. It is from Victoria which, probably not surprisingly, is the only State government that has so far completed its consideration of where those additional moneys should be expended.
—Can the Minister give any indication of when such a list will be available?

—I am advised that the Commonwealth is putting as much pressure as it possibly can on the State governments to respond in terms of setting their priorities for this additional money. I know the Northern Territory Government was commended for the efficiency with which it spent the last lot of money; we are pretty good at spending Federal Government money in the Northern Territory. All I can say in response to Senator Chapman is that the Commonwealth is placing as much pressure as it can on the State governments to respond as quickly as possible because we are anxious, not just from a public spending point of view but also from a safety point of view, for this money to be utilised as quickly as it can be.
—If there are no further questions on the road safety improvement package, we will move to subprogram 4.1, Road and rail policy development.

—Before I ask my question, I will make a brief comment on what Senator Collins had to say about why the National Rail Corporation had been held up. Senator Collins should know as well as I do that the Labor Government in Western Australia was equally concerned about the agreement that Western Australia may or may not enter into to form the National Rail Corporation. In fact, the Western Australian Minister for Transport, Pam Beggs, expressed concern many times as to what that arrangement might be. The Western Australian Government was equally to blame. I do not blame the Government or the Opposition for the stand it took. Now that they are happy with the situation—they have an escape clause if they do not see that things are going right after six months—they have signed the agreement.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that the Government had the numbers in the lower House, yet it did not attempt to ram the legislation through in a short period. It waited to see what came out of discussions and, finally, all the parties agreed—some earlier than others—on how it should go. Minister Collins was a bit unfair in attacking the Liberal Party, and the Liberal Party alone, for holding up that agreement in Western Australia.

However, in reallocating money away from rail, the main blame—and this is nothing to do with Western Australia—was placed on the lack of design or the fact that design and logistics were behind schedule. I ask the Minister how that could be, because preliminary design and logistic studies must have been carried out before anywhere near this amount of money might have been allocated. I cannot see why the Government, in moving away from the One Nation package, should blame the engineering section when it should have been on track—pardon the pun.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not respond at length to the first part of Senator Panizza's comments, for the simple reason that I do not want to get back into the same problem we were in a short time ago. I advise the Committee that I did take the trouble to read the Western Australian Parliament Hansard debates on the passage of that legislation. I certainly reconfirm the accuracy of the statements that I made. In respect to the second part of Senator Panizza's comments—
—Question.

—His question goes to the very heart of what this Government is doing with the One Nation spending, to my great delight as an Australian. Regrettably, the facts are that there has been no major capital injection into rail systems for a very long time indeed. What we stated was not a criticism of engineering departments at all; it was simply a statement of the sad fact that, until the very welcome initiatives that were taken in the One Nation statement to try to give this country, for the first time, a truly national rail freight system—after a hundred years of doing it wrongly—many of the corridor studies that are essential for the proper expenditure of the money had not been completed.

PARA.TAB: That is not, in any sense, a reflection on the ability or the diligence of the engineering departments. It is a reflection on the failure of governments generally to put any significant capital injection of this nature into a national rail system. For that reason, those studies had not been done. They are being expedited now with the changes that were being taken in this package, which have been largely overlooked, in terms of reallocating this funding and getting the corridors approved. One essential part of that process is happening in the State of Victoria. The Victorian State Government is determining the alternative routes and where the track will go, as part of that national system in Victoria.

We hope that, as a result of these changes in these appropriations, those agreements will now be quickly forthcoming and the corridor studies will be completed, then we can actually get on with the job of establishing the system. That is not just a matter, important as it is, of the employment that will be generated; it is fundamentally a matter of getting what we finally all want, that is, a standard gauge rail system that will run, in the first instance, at least, from Brisbane to Perth, connecting all our major freight corridors in Australia on a single national rail freight system. I look forward to the day when we can put the last link in between Alice Springs and Darwin.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the Minister that I will be very glad to see the last link. The Minister touched on the problem in Victoria of changing the route. Has there been a minor change of route since the new Victorian Government was elected? I presumed that had been settled while the Kirner Government was in office.

—The intense political environment that preceded the Victorian State election was an environment that precedes any election. What happened this morning is symptomatic of that. Prior to elections, tensions rise. This effectively stopped any opportunity for the proper, calm and cool decision making that is required. Senator Panizza will agree that it is very important to decide on where that rail link will go in terms of the effect it has on the communities it passes through. Once it is in place, it is not likely to be changed. That was yet another contributing factor to the delay. The election processes in Victoria simply froze any decision making.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the reallocation of money in these Appropriations, negotiations are under way as we speak with the new Victorian Government. We are hopeful of an early resolution by that Government of a decision about where the rail link should go. We certainly have a firm view about where it should go. Hopefully, that view will be shared by the new Victorian Government, and we can get on with the job of building it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the comments the Minister has just made that the delays in being able to spend the money originally allocated in One Nation for rail infrastructure were due, in a sense, to neglect by governments over an extended period. The Minister was not laying the blame at the feet of engineers in relation to the more specific design works. Given what he said, was it reasonable at the time the One Nation announcements were made for the design of the projects to be undertaken in time for the money to be spent as allocated? Were those who put One Nation together in error in assuming that the projects could be ready in time for that money to be spent?
