—It was entirely reasonable to commit that money. It was not done in ignorance of the difficulties involved. I am sure that Senator Chapman, as a South Australian, would support the initiative for the benefit it will bring to his State. South Australia will be right in the middle of the transport system. In fact, Adelaide has a real opportunity to become a major hub in this exercise.

PARA.TAB: We were aware of the difficulties involved in planning and negotiating the necessary multiple agreements with State governments. The decision in One Nation was comprehensively positive and far-sighted. An important objective was the employment opportunities that were to be created. The principal objective of the exercise was to provide us with a single gauge national rail freight system.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 4.1, we will move on to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. (Quorum formed) Are there any matters on the Department of Employment, Education and Training? Are there any matters on the Department of Administrative Services? There being no matters, I turn to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, program 6, the Office of Local Government, and, in particular, subprogram 6.3, local capital works program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During last Friday's Estimates hearings the Assistant Secretary of the Local Capital Works Branch of the Office of Local Government said of the local capital works program:

SPEECH.PARA: Because it was not an employment program we did not seek figures in relation to unemployed people . . .

That remark appears on page B727 of Hansard. However, when announcing the program—page 79 of Working for the future, a Budget related paper—the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) told us that it will focus on those regions and local government areas which have experienced higher than average levels of unemployment. If no records of unemployment creation are being kept, how will the Government determine how many jobs have been created, if reducing unemployment was what was intended?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate is on his way. As the Minister responsible, he will primarily deal with this stage of the Committee of the Whole process. It is significantly possible for something to create employment without being an employment program. It is obvious and self-evident that this program will create a lot of employment. That does not mean that its primary or sole focus is employment or particular unemployed people. It will create economic stimulus in regions, and most logically therefore in regions of highest unemployment because that is where the stimulus is most required.

PARA.TAB: In public debate there is abroad what I call the tyranny of the measurable—that is, `You cannot measure something; therefore, it does not exist'. If we cannot necessarily measure precisely how many or which jobs or for whom jobs have been created, it does not mean that there are not jobs being created.

For example, although it is not the case, let me make the extreme assumption that Senator Tierney tried to make the other day, which I think is quite wrong. I will not be quite as robust in the way I rebut it as I was when I did so the other day; I made an apology to Senator Tierney for one of those phrases. I accept that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is something, for you.
—I think Senator Tierney will acknowledge that that is the case. That is what took place.
—No, I would not agree with your logic.

—I am talking only about the apology, not about the validity of the argument. I do not apologise for the argument; simply for one of the comments. Anyway, I dealt with that at the time. I am not worried about it now.
—Tell us again.
—Does Senator Panizza want me to repeat what I said about him? No, that would not be parliamentary. It was not then and it would not be now. It was fun though.
—I would leave him to it, if I were you.
—It is quite a simple situation. It is a comment on those who do not understand it, because it is simple and straightforward.

—Senator McMullan is leaving and I have a follow-up point for him. Perhaps Senator Tate can answer it. If, as Senator McMullan just claimed, these things cannot be measured very accurately, why was it claimed in the Budget that this capital works program will generate 13,000 jobs? At the special hearing we also heard mention of another figure of 8,000 units—as they call them—over two years. That generates into—whatever the calculation may be.
—Seventeen thousand.

—I am a little curious as to how 8,000 half units ends up as 17,000 jobs but let us leave that point. My main point is that these are very specific calculations: 8,000 half units is very specific; creating 13,000 jobs out of this program is very specific; and yet we just heard Senator McMullan say that one could not measure these things. Can the Minister explain that inconsistency?

—As members of the Committee would realise, this particular program, which is designed to stimulate economic activity in various municipal areas around Australia and has been very enthusiastically welcomed by those participating municipalities and local councils, was anticipated to generate 13,000 six-monthly job units—I think that is the best way to put it—when the Budget was put together. This was done with the expectation that across the projects the average labour component would represent about 30 per cent of the expenditure on the program. In terms of the work being done at a rate of some $16,000 per year, that would represent some 13,000 six-monthly job opportunities generated by the program. That is how that figure was arrived at.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Tierney would know, the Office of Local Government has now estimated, based on the sample of 56 councils in New South Wales, that the program will generate approximately 17,000 six-monthly job units over the two financial years. Obviously, with each project the jobs that are generated or sustained by the expenditure will be of different duration. But that is how the figure was originally arrived at. It has been refined in light of the New South Wales sample.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little curious that the Minister should say that. The Budget Papers indicated that 13,000 jobs would be `generated'—that is the word that was used. Would the Minister agree that people reading that, or listening to it at the time the Budget was released, would have taken the view that they were new jobs? Yet we really have not had any information—and the Office of Local Government cannot provide us with any—on how many jobs generated by the program will be new, or on how many jobs it is just keeping on by the extra expenditure in those areas. Would the Minister agree that, because of the information which came out of the special hearing of Estimates B, what we were told in the Budget was really misleading?

—I think the term `generation' has to be seen in the context of the project. What was undertaken to be achieved—and which is being achieved to an even greater extent—was that local community infrastructure projects of enduring benefit which would otherwise not have been undertaken, because local ratepayers could not fund those particular projects, would be undertaken. Those projects are being undertaken and those infrastructure and community facilities are being constructed and, in the course of that, of course, jobs are being generated. The 13,000—or 17,000 as it is now thought to be—six-monthly job opportunities that are being funded would not have been available and would not have been undertaken apart from this expenditure. So it has generated that amount of employment activity. Whilst it is impossible to get all the figures from the councils broken down in the way that Senator Tierney would wish to see in great elaborate detail, the language used is appropriate to what has occurred.

—Would it be more accurate to say that what this program has done is not to shorten the dole queue but to stop the dole queue from getting any longer? Is that a better of description of what has happened?

—I think it would vary from municipality to municipality and from district to district. The program was not meant to be one of those schemes which cynically manipulated the CES offices by simply saying, `Roll in people off the unemployment lists'. It was not that sort of blatant exercise which could have properly attracted criticism. It was designed in a different way. There is no doubt that in some areas day labourers will be taken on into council gangs and subcontractors will take on people in order to build a community facility. There will be other situations where, as Senator Tierney quite rightly pointed out, rather than day labourers being put off or subcontractors having to get rid of a person because they have no work currently, people will be kept on. In that situation, Senator Tierney's observation is correct, although the exact balance in any one municipality will differ from the one next-door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister can understand the confusion out there in the electorate, as indicated by an article on the front page of the daily Telegraph Mirror a few weeks ago headed `Job Sham: For Ben it is a paradise lost'. When Ben found out about the Byron Bay program which employed council labourers, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I didn't realise it was money meant to create jobs for us.

Does the Minister understand that people out there are very confused by this? The Government has created a program, saying that it was job generating; it was supposed to be one of the centrepieces of its Budget. Yet the Minister has just told us, in accordance with what I have just said, that the Government is preventing the dole queue from growing rather than reducing the length of the queue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how many times we have been through this in Question Time, in Estimates and in the special hearing and now we are going around again. In relation to Byron Bay: as I indicated in Question Time, the Byron Shire Council works manager has indicated that in order to carry out various projects resulting from its $1.2m allocation, Byron Bay will employ 20 to 25 additional day labourers, mostly in the early half of next year. These projects include: sewerage works for Ocean Shores Estate, north of Byron Bay; a drainage system for Mullumbimby; restoring a historical building in Bangalow to be used as a community hall; and building some sporting facilities in two rural areas. Additional day labourers will be put on for those works.

PARA.TAB: It is not easy to stereotype this by way of a subeditor's headline as to what might sell a paper. As I say, it varies within individual municipalities over the duration of the program. What will be achieved is stimulation of local economic activity. Enduring community infrastructures will be brought on for the benefit of the community at a much earlier stage than would be the case if the councils had to rely on ratepayers and other forms of income to undertake those works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the statement that was made on Friday by the officer in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Because it was not an employment program we did not seek figures in relation to unemployed people.

Given this statement made in Estimates Committee B that the local capital works program is not an employment program and that no figures have been collected on job creation in each Government area, why was the basis of quoting the funding to local government areas on the basis of the levels of unemployment in those areas?

TALK.START.PARA: —That criterion was selected because it gives an indication of the likely level of economic activity or lack of activity in a particular area. It is a measurement which is also objective and can apply over municipalities—this anticipates some of the questions that might be raised by Senator Panizza or Senator Macdonald—which fall within a wide variety of Federal electorates where we certainly did not want to bear the accusation of any sort of political bias.

PARA.TAB: The criterion was selected in an objectively defensible way by looking at the rate of unemployment in municipalities above the average rate of unemployment. One of several measurements of the relative lack of economic activity in an area is the unemployment figures, and that is why it was chosen.

TALK.START.PARA: —We realise the Government would not allocate money in a politically biased way. We are just curious as to why the top grant went to the Prime Minister's seat and then the rest of the money seemed to go to a whole lot of marginal seats, such as Stirling. Is this just a demographic coincidence?
—Your own lips have said it.
—I think they concede the point.

—I too think it concedes the point. If the program was not directed at job creation, what does the Minister have to say to those councils which have below average unemployment but under the way this program was funded did not receive a cent? Can the Minister understand why perhaps the council at Ku-ring-gai in Sydney did not receive a cent from all these different programs? People are unemployed in Ku-ring-gai, although not as many as in Bankstown, yet there is no assistance under this program to get unemployment down or, as the Minister has indicated, to maintain the current levels of programs by providing capital works in those areas that would support employment which already exists.

—We can keep on going backwards and forwards on this. As I understand it, the municipalities that were selected have about 70 per cent of the unemployed people in Australia within their boundaries. I think that indicates that the assessment and differentiation between various municipalities has been conducted in a properly justifiable way according to that criteria.

PARA.TAB: I know, for example, that in Tasmania, where Launceston did not get the opportunity to participate in this program, the local municipal authorities have been understanding of that situation. Of course, they are benefiting from the better cities program and other programs of expenditure which will stimulate economic activity in those regions in coming years. They realise that this is just one program amongst many being pursued by the Government which can stimulate construction and other economic activity in their regions. I believe they understand the criteria used and accept the consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has just said, `It was justifiable according to the criteria'. We accept that. What we are really questioning is the criteria. Would the Minister accept that there is some lack of logic in having a program that is not supposed to be an employment generating program—that was the claim in Estimates Committee B—but having as the main criteria the level of unemployment in those council areas?

—The Government was seeking to have criteria available to it which would be a fair indication of the relative economic activity within a region. Naturally, if there is high unemployment, it is likely that spending patterns and the circulation of goods and services paid for within a municipal region will be adversely affected by relatively greater unemployment than in a neighbouring municipality which has relatively better unemployment figures. I suppose a variety of indicators or criteria could be taken. This was a reasonable one to take and, in any case, was the criterion selected and applied to this program.
—I believe there are a little more than 900 councils across Australia. Could the Minister tell us how many councils actually received funding and how many councils missed out?
—There were 410 out of 916 which received funding.
—What sorts of complaints from the other 500 who received nothing have you received?

—I will probably have to take that on notice. Apparently some 400 letters have been received. I do not know what the breakdown is—whether they are generated as a result of formal resolutions of councils or whether they are from individuals or people attaching copies of the front page of the Daily Telegraph to a scrawled note. Perhaps I can get that information for Senator Tierney if he wants to know, building on his former question, whether it is councils making formal representations.

—If information is being sought, could I ask for it to be broken down not only in the way the Minister has indicated between individuals and councils but also State by State and electorate by electorate, if that is possible. Could we also have some sort of record of the nature of the complaints. Could it be grouped by complaint type as well from these council areas.

—I will certainly undertake to ask officers to devote some resources to answering those questions. The more crude statistics should be able to be made available more readily than the qualitative accumulation or segregation of material that Senator Tierney wants. That might take some time. Depending on resources, we will make that available to Senator Tierney.

—I was just going to assist Senator Tate, who seems to be floundering with Senator Tierney's question. I was going to assist him by helping him with the answer. I can tell Senator Tate that the answer is lots—probably about 500 out of the balance. As I am the shadow Minister for local government, many of the councils and peak bodies send me copies of the submissions they make to the Government. Most of them are unhappy with the program because of its inherent unfairness.
—And playing favourites.

—Yes, and playing favourites; Senator Tambling is quite right. I think my colleagues on Friday clearly drew out of the Government the inconsistencies of its statement. In the One Nation and Budget statements the Government promised some 800,000 new jobs, I think. On Friday, my colleagues elicited that in fact no new jobs were being created and that this program was just stopping more people joining the unemployment queue. If that is the case in this part of the program, I wonder whether Senator Tate might elucidate for me what happened to the Government's claim of 800,000 new jobs out of the One Nation and the Budget programs—the programs that were going to cure unemployment.

PARA.TAB: I understand from Senator McMullan's answers to the questions in the Estimates Committee hearing that it is not working with local government. I might say as an aside that I can well understand why Senator McMullan dumped the bundle on to Senator Tate and skedaddled as quickly as he could. On Friday my colleagues completely tied up Senator McMullan. They had him admitting all sorts of things which I am sure he regrets now. I congratulate my colleagues on some fairly skilful cross-examination on Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity he didn't stay.

—Senator Tierney is quite right; it is a pity he did not stay. I do, with some humility, sympathise with Senator Tate for having this bundle dumped in his lap and being left to make something sensible of it. Senator McMullan had a fairly horrendous time simply because he could not understand or convince anyone of the contradictory statements the Government has been making about this program.

PARA.TAB: I might, as I said, assist Senator Tate in the answer to Senator Tierney's question. There have been lots of complaints because of the inherent unfairness of the program. It is unfair that a city such as Moorabbin in Melbourne which has a very high number of unemployed people in its district—almost 5,000 from memory—got absolutely nothing. Another municipality in the Victorian metropolitan area had, I think, 264 unemployed people and it got something like $300,000 or $400,000. I do not begrudge that smaller council those moneys, but it shows the inherent unfairness of the program.

It means that some councils will get infrastructure projects done—most of them worthwhile—which will benefit their ratepayers as they will not have to pay for them in the future. But councils right next door get nothing. If they want to get those same infrastructure projects done, they will have to pay for them out of their rate bill. And they will have to increase the rates in order to do that.

Unfortunately, I could not attend the Estimates Committee meeting on Friday. I was in New South Wales telling the State Executive of the New South Wales Local Government Association the tremendous benefits that it will receive from the Fightback program and how councils will be much better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait a minute. We discussed Fightback earlier. I think you had better come back to subprogram 6.3.

—I was just explaining why I was not there on Friday. I was in Sydney explaining to councils—it is relevant to this point—how well they will do out of the Fightback program. So I was not able to participate.

PARA.TAB: I hope I have assisted the Committee and the Minister by giving those answers to Senator Tierney. Not only have individual councils complained, but also, as a general rule, peak bodies have written to the Government complaining about the inherent unfairness of the scheme; complaining not about the people who have benefited as a result of the scheme, but about the fact that it was simply unfair. The scheme has not addressed the problem of unemployment—as my colleagues on Friday so clearly elicited from the Government—which shows that the whole thing is a bit of a sham. I rose at this time to assist the Committee. I want to ask some questions later, but, having assisted Senator Tate, I defer to Senator Tierney to allow him to continue with his questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Tate can explain the shift in ground. I have never seen as many shifts in ground as I have seen in this case. The Government started off by saying in One Nation that it would create 13,000 jobs. Senator Tate reaffirmed that this morning. He should check the Hansard and he will see that he said that.
—It wasn't One Nation; it was the Budget.
—All right, it was in the Budget. But the Minister reaffirmed that this morning. If he checks the Hansard he will see that he said the Government would create those jobs.
—I didn't say `create'. I agreed to the word generally.

—Senator Tate said `create' this morning. He should check the Hansard. I am not going to argue with the Minister all day, Mr Chairman, but Senator Tate said `create' this morning. I wrote it down in inverted commas as soon as he said it; he said it would create 13,000 units. In an answer to Senator Kernot two weeks ago, the Minister said that the exercise of the capital grants was in order to sustain 13,000 jobs.
—Regurgitate.
—He used the word `sustain'. He can check the Hansard again.
—He meant `regurgitate'.

—Yes, that is what he meant. In the Budget—it was in the Budget and not in One Nation, as Senator Tate has said—the Government said it would create these jobs. So we had the words `create' and `sustain'. The Minister should check the Hansard. He should not just believe me—most people do not.
—Senator Panizza, are we on subprogram 6.3, `Grants to local councils for social and economic infrastructure'?
—Yes, we are, Mr Chairman.
—Perhaps you can get on with it.

—We have had that shift in ground. Later Senator Tate might be able to explain why the ground has shifted so much. Since the beginning, I have expressed the view that although I disagree with the allocation of money to individual councils, I have no argument with the allocation itself because it creates activity. I have said all along that the money would go to people already employed via contractors or into materials. Nothing Senator Tate has said has disproved that.

PARA.TAB: After Senator Tate shifted ground further, he went on to say that the money was there to stimulate the economy. I ask Senator Tate: is there not a simpler way of stimulating the economy than by upsetting certain councils of Australia through allocating money to some and not to others? I can point to four marginal Federal seats in Western Australia where money has been allocated because this Government is trying to hold the seats, and another four seats in other States which were allocated money because the Government is trying to either hold the seats or win them back after it lost them in the last election. Would it not have been far simpler to even it out over all of the local governments in Australia, even if they are just above or below that line? Wanneroo—in the electorate of Moore which is held by Paul Filing—got zero. Alongside that, the electorate of Stirling, which is held by the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives, got $5m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor's most marginal seat in Australia.

—Yes. It got $5m. Would the end result not have been far better, with far fewer complaints, if the Government had allocated the money evenly? It would have stimulated the economy just as much as the Government hoped to by sorting out the haves and the have-nots.

—It certainly would have reduced the number of complaints; I cannot disagree with that. But I still say that the criterion that was adopted by the Government as a measure of relative economic activity within the municipalities was a fair and reasonable one to adopt. It has been applied in a way which is objectively justifiable, even though it has led to the generation of some of the complaints which we would otherwise not have been subjected to had we adopted the Opposition's scheme instead.

—I would not disagree with what the Minister has said if he were able to give us some performance indicators. There should be performance indicators for any allocation of finance in the Budget to capital programs of any sort. To date, all the Minister has told us is that 25 jobs were created somewhere in Sydney. I ask the Minister once again: when will we get some definite figures—even with regard to sustaining jobs, let alone creating them? The Minister has shifted ground from `creating' to `sustaining', so I suppose we cannot get him any other way. When will the Minister tell us how many jobs have been created and how many jobs have been sustained? Then we can judge whether this program is a success and, better still, the Australian electors can judge for themselves.

—Of course, as these projects are completed they will be monitored. Obviously an audit will be undertaken to ensure that the councils have created the infrastructure in their communities. That will also, of necessity, involve a council report on the job hours that were worked in the creation of that community facility.

—Could the Minister confirm what Senator McMullan indicated in the Senate Estimates Committee, that very few real jobs would be created—that the Government was maintaining existing people in work. I understand that was the thrust of what Senator McMullan said, and Senator Kemp agrees, so I am sure that is correct.

PARA.TAB: We have a real unemployment problem. It should be borne in mind that $345m has been allocated for this program—it was to be $245m this year and $100m next year. The Appropriations we are now talking about bring forward $55m from next year to this year. That will not create any more jobs, and Mr Calvert acknowledged that in the Estimates Committee, and that is obviously correct. That will only maintain the existing number of people in employment. So we have a real problem.

Honourable senators should bear in mind that that $345m is not paid for. It is just another bit of the $14 billion or $15 billion that the Government runs in deficit this year. The Minister will correct me if I am wrong but the Government has forecast a deficit for the next three, four or five years up to $50 billion; that is, the Government will spend $50 billion more than it will get in.

It should also be borne in mind that the Government is really spending someone else's money. It is not spending its own money. It is just borrowing it, ticking it up on the international Bankcard. The Government says, `Get us over the election. Let the kids and grandkids pay for it in the next generation'. Bearing that in mind, instead of just spending $345m, why did we not spend a couple of billion dollars? That would have not just kept the job level as it is but it might have got a few more people employed. If the scenarios I have painted are correct, why did we not do that? If they are not, could the Minister explain to me where I have gone wrong and where my interpretations of what happened on Friday are incorrect?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the premise. I have already indicated with the Byron Bay example that the only jobs that we are concerned with are those of presently employed work gang members or subcontractors' employees and so on. There will be variations between municipality and municipality and within municipalities from time to time during the duration of the program. At different times new persons will enter the work force as a result of this particular program.

PARA.TAB: So I do not accept the blanket description of the job situation that flows under this program that Senator Macdonald put forward. But that is not really his major point because we have been through that; we have rehearsed that all morning. Senator Macdonald asks why the Government did not spend another $2 billion on this particular program if we think it is so good. This is a fiscally responsible government. We have decided to give this stimulus to local areas where they need to see economic activity generated at a greater level than would otherwise be the case. It would not be responsible simply to throw another $2 billion at municipalities. Therefore, this figure was arrived at as part of an overall package in the Budget. I believe that it is justifiable. I do not believe that $2 billion would have been justifiable and, for that reason, no doubt it was never considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one thing I congratulate the Government on—that is, giving the money to local government because it can implement projects, and do it quickly and efficiently with a minimum of red tape. Local government gets the money spent. Obviously, local government will not create long term jobs because those jobs have to start by 1 December this year and finish by 30 December next year. When the money stops, of course, the jobs stop. Certainly, the Minister was correct: if the Government wants to spend money quickly before an election to give some pretence of activity before next March or April, it has certainly done so the right way, because local government is very efficient and effective at doing that.

PARA.TAB: We would not have introduced this program. Most of the projects I have seen that have been done have been good infrastructure projects. Most of them have been beneficial; most of them would have saved other people from being sacked, thus lengthening the dole queues. We would not have introduced this program because all our programs would be completely paid for. The Government's programs are not paid for.
People who understand a bit better than I tell me the deficit this year is really $20 billion. The Government has had a few asset sales, so it has been able to reduce the deficit a bit.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a $20 billion black hole.

—The deficit is a $20 billion black hole. Bearing in mind that the Government has that $13 billion, $14 billion, $15 billion or $20 billion hole, if the Government's socialist thinking is to throw a bit more money at it, why did it not give local government a lot more? Then local government could have spent that money. It can do so very efficiently. Local government could have created those additional jobs for the short term.

PARA.TAB: I am serious in asking about this because I do want to know. Many councils ask me about this. They say, `If this is the way to go; if this is the be all, the end all, the saviour, the curing of our problems in this world, why did the Government only give that money to 410 councils? Why did the Government not give it to everybody? If the Government had given more money, all of our problems would have been solved'. I ask those questions seriously because I want to know, and so do most of the councils.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will call the Minister in a moment. I would indicate that Senator Macdonald appeared to repeat his question.
—Mr Chairman, I think you are keeping a very alert eye on the clock. I guess it is the wish of the Committee that these matters be concluded by lunchtime.
—You'll get KOd!
—It will be interesting to see what happens on 18 December and how the Opposition changes Fightback. That is the clock that the Opposition should be paying attention to.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We had Fightback debated earlier this morning.
—Aren't you petrified?

—No, not at all. Mr Chairman, so far as Senator Macdonald was concerned, you made the very astute observation that his question was very much along the same lines as the question which he posed immediately before and which I answered. The moneys that we have provided within the Budget for this particular project were considered to be a responsible allocation of funds. To provide money in the dimensions that Senator Macdonald referred to in his previous version of the question would not have been responsible, and for that reason the Government did not pursue it.
—Mr Chairman, I take your hint on the time.
—I was not hinting on the time.
—I will take our Whip's hint on the time then, and I get agreement there, if not from you, Mr Chairman.
—I was not disagreeing; I was just hinting on something else.

—On Friday my colleagues established that Jobstart will commence on 1 December this year and finish on 30 December next year. So whatever starts will stop then. The full program of $345m was allocated, or Mr Calvert's advice to the Estimates Committee was that 98 per cent had been allocated. So we can say that all of it has been allocated. It has been programmed to be spent. Can the Minister inform the Committee what the purpose was of bringing forward $55m out of that $100m that we will spend next year to early 1993, like January, February or March.

PARA.TAB: When is the latest month to have an election—May? Does that have anything to do with it? It was $55m to be spent after June. I guess a greater lump of those very short term jobs will be brought forward before March, April, May—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the election.

—Before the election. I would not have been quite so base as to say that directly. Was there some other reason that this was brought forward to those particular months? This of course means that, come July, August, September, October and November of next year, the number of people going back onto the unemployment queues will be even greater because that money has been spent.
—I've got the question.

—I want to elaborate in case some of Senator Tate's colleagues in the chamber who are supporting him in this do not quite understand the question or the point. I want to make that clear. So the Government will keep them in that job a little while longer in the early part of the year, but all the money bar $45m will then be spent, so they will go back onto the unemployment queues at a much earlier time, probably just after April, May, June. Can Senator Tate explain why it was brought forward?

—As I understand it, the municipalities and councils around Australia, in these districts that were selected on the objective criteria, were so enthusiastic about the projects, and submitted projects in such numbers and with such quality, that it was obviously thought that one should take advantage of that willingness by municipalities to participate as partners in stimulating economic activity within their regions. Many good projects were able to be funded, and they have been assisted in getting off the ground by this money being brought forward.

—I have a couple of questions. I will certainly be a little kinder than my colleague Senator Macdonald. I think it is fair to say that Senator Tate is regarded as one of the more straightforward members of the frontbench of this Government. I can see the embarrassment that is caused by having to answer some of these difficult questions. There are two particular issues which I raised before Estimates B to which I still have not got a clear answer. I would like to test Senator Tate to see whether an answer has come forward. If Senator Tate has had a chance to read the transcript, he will know that there was enormous confusion in Estimates B—Mr Calvert and Senator McMullan were there—as to how many jobs were to be created.

—There was great confusion. We did not know whether they would be created over six months or over two years. Senator McMullan said that he would have to go back and check the records; Mr Calvert said he would have to go back and check. I would have thought evaluating the program was pretty fundamental. I ask, for the record, for me—and for everybody else out there—just how many jobs this program will create.

—I did read the transcript very briefly. I notice that Senator Kemp, in his usual modest and deprecating way, referred to himself in the course of the proceedings as a simple-minded senator. I do not think he should always give evidence of it by repeating endlessly the questions asked in the course of the morning on this matter.

—He said simple: simply simple. If that is a better description, I will settle for that. The fact is that we have answered this question by describing how the Budget figure was put together, based on the expectation of 30 per cent of the expenditure being spent on employment. At a rate of $16,000 per annum, that worked out at about 13,000 six-month job units. Since then a study has been undertaken by the New South Wales Municipal Association in which I think some 56 councils participated. The conclusion to be drawn from that is that some 17,000 six-month job opportunities will be generated under this program. That is what we are operating on. It has been modified upwards since the Budget on the basis of the experience in New South Wales.

—Just to speed up the journey, I will put a double-barrelled question. When Senator Tate stands up again, can he indicate whether they are new jobs or existing jobs? Another issue which has caused some embarrassment, as I can see from Senator Tate's remarks, particularly in reference to the comments of Senator Macdonald, is the fact that there is a bit of a feeling out there that certainly we should recognise that good works have been done by this; but if they are so good, why do we not do more of them? The Government seems to be able to spend hand over fist, particularly before elections. It was a useful question, and I understand why Senator Tate ducked and weaved on that, so I will not press him.

PARA.TAB: There have been press reports indicating that maybe there is a bit of political stuntsmanship occurring in the way this program is being handled, and that the intention is really to try to keep Mr Keating in his job, as distinct from the 13,000 six-monthly jobs—or the 17,000, as has been stated. One of the newspaper articles drew attention to the fact that a number of Labor members of parliament are being asked to hand out some fat cheques, get a bit of press and all that business.

So I asked a pretty straightforward question: whether the same principles are being applied in all electorates—Labor, Liberal or National Party. Is the real concern basically to get jobs for the unemployed—and we all endorse that—or is this being used as a bit of political stuntsmanship in some areas? Can Senator Tate tell us whether all members of parliament have been treated in the same way as to the way this money is being handed out publicly?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure of the thrust of Senator Kemp's observation. I believe that, where a grant is to be made to a council to help it with a particular community project, the House of Representatives member within whose electorate that municipality sits is informed. I do not think that is done on any basis other than the straightforward basis of membership of the House of Representatives. There is no differentiation on party grounds. The member is informed of that—
—Just no grants in Liberal seats.

—There are grants in Liberal seats. A primary colouring of the map of Australia is not important in this particular program. As far as the handing out of cheques is concerned, this is a Government project. I have been involved in making cheque presentations to various municipalities, and I believe it appropriate for the Government to have a person like me doing that in various municipalities, regardless of membership of the House of Representatives.

—The Minister has just confirmed that Government senators are being asked to hand out these cheques. I wonder whether Senator Tate could ask his officers whether anyone on this side of the chamber has been asked to make a presentation. I have not been. There is a concern, and some of the press have expressed it, that the Government's motives are political rather than being designed to assist the unemployed. Can Senator Tate tell us whether anyone on this side of the chamber has been asked to hand out any of this money?

—We are very conscious of the need to protect the sensibilities of Opposition senators and would not want to embarrass them by asking them to hand out cheques and to get publicity in relation to a program which they oppose. Rather than subject them to that embarrassment, I suppose the natural thing is to ask Government senators to be involved in the presentations.

—I think that basically answers the question. I thought that Senator Macdonald, our shadow Minister for local government, and an excellent shadow Minister, indicated that he felt that in a large number of areas these projects were worthwhile. So I query the comment the Minister has made. But in a roundabout way the Minister has answered the question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ascertain from the Minister what degree of study was undertaken with regard to the provision of grants under this program alongside the grants given by other departments in the social security area or in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander area. For example, I am aware that in the ATSIC area there is certainly well over $200m available through the CEDP program, which has a similar benefit in many Aboriginal communities. I am keen to ascertain to what extent the Department analysed the other government programs that impacted in the same regions or local government areas that also provided funds to those specific local government areas. Was there a degree of assessment made, or did these funds, in effect, compound the Government's largesse and implementation of funding, particularly in Labor electorates?

—As I have indicated to the Committee, I believe that the assessment and the criterion used were to do with the level of unemployment being above the national average in the municipalities concerned. I do not believe that other complementary activities, which might involve the stimulation of infrastructure or the creation of activity within the local municipality, were taken into account as a separate factor either to modify the major factor or to substitute for it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that this Government has been very rigorous in the giving of grants to local government, as I am sure Senator Macdonald would endorse. There are very rigorous formula. The various grants commissions are involved in ensuring that funds flowing to local government are equitably and fairly distributed throughout Australia. Therefore, it concerns me that the Minister is not able to indicate that any form of assessment was done that drew on a similar type of assessment, particularly where these funds are again flowing through the agency of local government. As Senator Macdonald has said, certainly the delivery of the services through local government should be complemented.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of concern that the Government has not drawn upon the normal and traditional Labor Party principles of equity and fairness in this distribution. I would be very keen to know why the Government chose to move away from its traditional areas of support in the assessment of the way grants would go. It is obvious from a number of the local government areas that were chosen that the Minister cannot sustain that the assessment criterion was purely one of employment because many of the 500 councils or municipalities that did not receive funds are also well known for their unemployment problems. Therefore, it should be recorded that it is a matter of major concern that there was not any degree of equity and fairness in these grants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course this is a policy difference between us on the construction of the program. It cannot be regurgitated in different forms endlessly, I hope. But we do believe that it is an equitable and fair program and that it will have beneficial consequences for the Australian community.

—I ask Senator Tate to take on notice to supply to the chamber a list of which members or senators from Western Australia handed out cheques in Western Australia for local government grants, including any members of the Western Australian Parliament who may have been given that task.
—All I can do, I think, is ask the Minister's office whether the Minister is able to provide such information, and I will respond.

—The guidelines for applicants for local government capital works programs state that proposals will be accepted for projects contributing to the `long term development and benefit of the local community'. What evaluation mechanisms have been established to ensure that money given to local government is spent on infrastructure which might be of most benefit to the community?

—It is a curious question. Obviously, if that is part of the criteria of the program, the advisory committees have to assess applications and rank them in accordance with those criteria. One would hope, therefore, that only those projects which fulfil the various criteria are endorsed and funded. Nevertheless, insofar as one would need to have some sort of audit, there is a program of evaluation being established, I understand, to enable the program managers to assess that what is hoped to be the fulfilment of those criteria has been achieved.

—The Minister is saying that there is a formative evaluation at the stage that the project is accepted, in that the guidelines for the acceptance of projects are that the projects must be for the long term benefit of the community. In the light of that, why has the Federal Government allowed $8m of expenditure under the program to date to be spent on 31 cycle paths throughout the country?

—I am a non-cyclist, but I believe that for those in the community who use bicycles for recreational pursuits, for going from their place of habitation to their place of employment, to engage in shopping or whatever, cycle paths provide a long term benefit to the community. Certainly I have had representations from various councils in Tasmania which see the cycle paths as a very good project, not only from a health and recreational point of view, but also from a safety point of view in allowing persons within their municipalities to move along the bicycle paths rather than being subjected to the hazards of ordinary traffic on the roads. So in many ways these cycle paths can be properly characterised as providing a facility for the local area of enduring benefit. I would be surprised if Senator Tierney were to think otherwise.

—I do not think otherwise. The Minister is missing the thrust of what I am saying. I am a user of cycle paths, as are my children. I think they are great things. But, given the chronic lack of funding in this country for worthwhile rail and road projects, which was the initial thrust of the One Nation initiative, how can the Minister justify switching money out of very much needed rail and road projects—which are aimed to get this economy moving again and to get our exports up—to cycleways?

—We are now getting into the bigger picture rather than concentrating on this program. The Government is still committed to improving the transport infrastructure of Australia in the major areas of road and rail. That does not diminish the importance to local communities of such projects as the cycle paths. I believe they are justifiable and a good part of the expenditure undertaken in this program.

—If the Minister is committed to these things, why are we not spending money on them in the depths of the greatest recession we have had in 60 years? They would seem to be employment generating; they would also add to our industrial capacity and our exporting capacity. Why are we spending money on cycleways when we could be spending it on roads and rail?
—I think that question is repeating itself.

—It is getting a bit irritating now. It is a simple repetition of the first question Senator Tierney asked me a moment ago. The fact is that we are spending money on rail and road infrastructure. Around Tasmania there has been a tremendous amount of improvement to the road system which, for example, will help get agricultural products and other produce to the ports. I believe that that expenditure is taking place in a way which will benefit Australia through improved transport infrastructure. It does not diminish the importance of these other projects. I think Senator Tierney has just about exhausted the issue; he has certainly exhausted me.

—The Minister is missing the point. We are redirecting money away from road and rail at the deepest point of a recession, when we need to be spending money and generating jobs in this much needed area. The Minister has just claimed that we are spending money on roads in Tasmania. What we are seeing in this program is a diversion of funds which are desperately needed away from road and rail, hence the point of my question, which the Minister still has not really answered. Why are we spending money on cycleways instead of the very necessary road and rail projects?

—This money was not diverted from those areas. It was brought forward from the next year's projected expenditures on this program. That was not a diversion of moneys from some rail project, for example. I think that is the better way to understand it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind him that since Mr Keating took over as Prime Minister, an extra 72,000 Australians have been out of work. That includes an extra 32,000 since the Government's last Budget. My question, therefore, is: will the Government be announcing any new policies to assist the unemployed—now nearly one million, in all, Australians out of work—or can they expect simply more of the same, and that is, more of the deplorable record of unemployment?

—One quarter we cannot expect more of the same from is the Opposition, which has been engaging in a diversionary tactic now for 12 months. Suddenly the Opposition starts to read the opinion polls—as Senator Tambling commented this morning on Northern Territory radio—and decides that it will change its policies. This is back to the Liberal Party of the 1970s—the Liberal Party which offered a fistful of dollars at election time and took them away five months later. Week after week, month after month, those opposite have been coming in here, psyching themselves up and saying, `We are different from the Liberal Party of old'.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question was very clear and very specific: `What is the Government going to do? Is it going to announce any new policies to deal with the one million unemployed?' It is a very clear question. The Minister's answer is completely irrelevant to that question, and he is seeking to debate policy. Mr President, I ask you to direct him to answer the question.
—Order! In reply to the point of order that was raised, I ask Senator Button not to debate the Opposition's policies but to answer the question.

—As I have said on numerous occasions in the Senate in the last few weeks and months, the Government announced stimulatory policies in the One Nation statement. It began to lower interest rates in this country—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Every one of those interest rate lowerings was opposed by Dr Hewson, who then said there was no need to lower interest rates because that would overstimulate the Australian economy. That is what he said quite regularly last year. Today—or was it last night?—he suddenly discovered that the recession was deeper than he thought. Or did he discover that the polls were deeper than he thought?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I thought your ruling to Senator Button was very clear. He is now defying your ruling. I ask you to instruct him to come back to the question, which was very specific: `Is the Government going to announce any new policies to deal with the one million unemployed, or does he rule those policies out?' Why does he not answer that question?
—Order! The honourable senator has made his point of order.

—As the esteemed and venerable colleague of those opposite, Mr Ian Sinclair, said, `We seem to have become the issue'. Those opposite have become the issue all right—and that is their problem. If I might continue to answer without interruption, let me say that in the course of the Budget we announced further policies which would help with employment.
—Mr President, on a point of order: are you going to enforce your ruling?
—Order! I did, and Senator Button is answering the question.

—Mr President, these interruptions, of course, are to be understood. The fact of the matter is that, in terms of the policy settings in this country, we are one of the few countries in the OECD which are showing positive growth, and positive growth will lead to an increase in employment over time. That is what we have been about. The Opposition, on the other hand, proposes nothing except taking people off the dole after nine months.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Retail Sales: Effect of a GST

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the Minister provide the Senate with detail of the latest figures on retail sales and their relevance to the Australian economy? Has the Government had examined the effects that the introduction of a goods and services tax would have on retail sales and the recovery? Further, will the Minister outline the significance of maintaining consistency in economic policy as the recovery gathers pace?

—Today, the Australian Bureau of Statistics published retail trade figures for the month of October. As I always do, I caution that monthly figures have to be treated with a little circumspection. But I have to say that this is the strongest monthly rise in retail sales since January. They are now running at 4.3 per cent above the level of October 1991. This is consistent with the Government's view that recovery is taking place in the economy, although at a slower rate than all Australians would like. The combination of lower interest rates, the One Nation statement and the employment initiatives in the Budget are helping promote growth in Australia, despite the huge difficulties in the international economy where unemployment rates, growth rates and so on are in an extraordinarily bad situation.

PARA.TAB: The Government does not believe in massive U-turns in economic policy. If one reads the serious economic commentators, one will know that that is true. There is an enormous amount of difference between flexibility in policies and U-turns. Until yesterday, Dr Hewson was at least being consistent. He consistently opposed interest rate cuts throughout last year, and he said that he would not change Fightback whatever people thought of it. Today that has all changed. He is going to learn that one cannot wrap a dead cat in silver paper and make it good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: the question was about retail sales. Senator Button should be answering that question, not one he has invented.

—Order! As I heard it, the question was about retail sales and the effect that a GST would have on retail sales, and about a consistent policy and what would happen if it changed. Therefore, I have allowed it.

—Mr President, I was moving on to the question of the effects of a GST on retail sales. Of course, we do not know what GST might be brought in in Australia. Senator Short was saying not long ago that the coalition stood full square on this issue—every dollar of it. He said that there would be no changes, that it was the best in the world. On 24 November Senator Short said that Fightback, including the spending cuts, would be implemented regardless of economic circumstances.

—Mr President, on another point of order: it is legitimate for Senator Button to talk about Mr Keating's GST—the one that he was endorsing in 1985. It is not legitimate at Question Time for him to be debating our policies. If we have to abide by the rules, the Government should abide by the rules also.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I thought the whole point was that there was some doubt about the Opposition policy on a GST—that it may not be its policy. Senator Button is quite happy to talk about it.
—Mr President—

—No, Squeak, I do not need any help from you. The ABS says that the annual trend rate of growth in retail sales is now about 4 per cent. The monthly figures are, as I said, volatile. Therefore, the trend numbers should be interpreted with care. This is particularly during periods of decline in the rates of inflation in Australia which are now taking place.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As part of its economic assessment, has the Government examined the impact of a GST upon retail sales in countries comparable to Australia?

—The Opposition wants to talk about the so-called assessment of New Zealand. Those opposite sent their dirty dozen, as they were called, to New Zealand under Mr Reith and they did not come back telling us about the great virtues in regard to retail sales.
—Ask Roger Douglas about it.

—I make this point, because Senator Macdonald has been interjecting about it. From 1985 to January 1992 there was a 9 per cent increase in retail sales in Australia. In the same period New Zealand, with its GST, had a one per cent drop in retail sales. This shows what the economic policies in New Zealand have done. That, plus a range of other policies which are included in Fightback, has had that effect on retail sales. The Opposition has to face up to the fact that this economy is growing; New Zealand's is not.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the fact that since Mr Keating took over as Prime Minister in December 1991, Australia's foreign debt has increased by $22,000m, more than $1m every hour of every day of the past year, to a gross total of more than $200,000m, representing a debt to every man, woman and child in Australia of $11,000, and to a net level of more than $162,000m. Given the fact that Australia's foreign debt has risen by $175,000m since Labor came to office in 1983, I ask: when will the Government be announcing policies to reduce that debt of $11,000 for every man, woman and child, or can Australians simply expect more of the same?

—Senator Short ought to know better than this. Of course, the Opposition tactic is so cleverly worked out. It is to divert attention from our being the main issue. That is what the Opposition tactic is about. Opposition senators are in here today like headless chooks. Senator Kemp is squeaking away over there like a chook. The fact of the matter is that those opposite present themselves as a serious alternative government in this country, but they have no policies at this stage which they can be confident about. Let me look at the Opposition. This morning Senator Boswell announced that he wants to rewrite Opposition tariff policy. Yesterday Senator Knowles announced that she wants to rewrite—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This question was whether, in the light of the $200 billion debt, a tenfold increase under this Government, the Government has any policies to do anything about it. Is it going to change policies or is it offering Australia simply more of the same? That is the question and I ask you to bring the Minister to order.
—Order!

—It is a good idea to keep Opposition senators on their toes here. I answered this question earlier in the week, but the answer went right over Senator Short's head, or through it. Senator Short is doing these silly bits of arithmetic in trying to translate the debt to every man, woman and child in Australia, which he thinks is populist, but it is economically irresponsible because it does not look at Australia's gross assets and the assets which have accumulated overseas under this Government. There were $6 billion worth of overseas assets when those opposite left government. There are now $58 billion worth of overseas assets compared with $6 billion worth when those opposite left government.

PARA.TAB: As I have said on a number of occasions, the important point about the international debt is its relevance to our international asset position and the debt servicing ratio. Of course, rather than 19 per cent of exports of goods and services being required to pay the interest on the net foreign debt, that has now dropped to 15.4 per cent. The Opposition looks at only one side of the balance sheet and ignores Australia's increase in foreign and domestic investment.

Of course, internationalisation of the Australian economy means that Australia has increased its foreign investment, and the issue of debt has to be seen in that perspective. I remind the Senate again that 61 per cent, I think, of that overseas debt is in the private sector, and that the Commonwealth Government is a net lender of some $4 1/2 billion—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is economically irrelevant.

—Senator Short says that is irrelevant. It is not irrelevant, because those opposite, in Question Time, make the comparison with Mexico, Brazil and countries such as those, which is a totally invalid comparison.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to what is happening in the chamber at present. The camera over here is focused on Senator Button. Behind Senator Button there are three or four senators, one of whom is Senator Aulich, who has a newspaper. He is holding up the Daily Telegraph showing the headline `Backflip' so that it can be seen on television. I ask you, Mr President: is that in accordance with Standing Orders or is that something that is highly improper?

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Faulkner! It is clearly out of order, and I remind all senators because last week it was being done by some members of the Opposition as well.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question—in the light of that meaningless tirade from the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He has once again refused, as he has done on every occasion in recent months, even to attempt to seriously answer a question. Does he agree that, excluding our overseas assets, a tenfold increase in Australia's net debt to the rest of the world over the past 10 years as a result of the Labor Government's policy failures represents a fundamental structural problem? I ask him again: if he does agree, what new policies will the Government adopt to reduce that debt?

—I suppose this question is designed to indicate the great flexibility of the Opposition, which, having stood—in Senator Short's words—`foursquare on every dollar in Fightback', has gone away from it.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We sat through that tirade a little while ago. I would ask you to uphold your ruling of 18 December 1990 when you said that if a Minister chooses to answer the question, the Minister should confine himself to the points contained in the question such that the explanation will be intelligible. I know the Minister has a problem with this area. The question is simple: is the international debt a problem; and does the Labor Party have a policy to solve it?
—Order! I ask the Minister to relate his answer to the question.

—Mr President, as I pointed out in my original answer and as I pointed out earlier this week in answer to almost exactly the same question—but we have to say something to those opposite 20 times in order to get it into their heads—the important point is the debt servicing ratio and the assets which Australia has accumulated overseas, and it is important to consider whether it is sovereign debt about which we are talking. If those opposite want me to say that Australia's overseas debt level is something that has to be seriously considered by all governments, the answer to that question is yes.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! All interjections are unruly. There are some people on my left who are constantly interjecting every time there is a question; I ask them to cease.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aviation Industry: Effects of a GST

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware of the increasing concerns being expressed by the general aviation industry and the regional airlines about the impact of a GST and other increases in charges as proposed by the coalition on the aviation industry? Would a GST also adversely impact on the essential domestic tourism industry, as the Tourism Industry Association has indicated? Does the Government have any plans to introduce a GST?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask: can we believe this bloke? On 20 November he said he would resign if the GST was altered.
—Order!
—Mr President, I take a point of order.
—Yes. I have asked Senator Cook not to do that.

—The GST as proposed by the Opposition includes a number of offsets to reduce its impact—offsets by the reduction of payroll tax, petrol excise and sales tax. But, even with those offsets factored in, the domestic airlines in Australia say that the impact of the consumption tax is to add $250m per annum to their operational expenses. Treasury estimated that that is an 8 per cent increase in domestic air fares. Overall, allowing for the offsets, there will be a $250m increase in operational expenses.

PARA.TAB: While the major domestic airlines will of course be hurt by that, the airlines that will be hurt most are the regional operators, the smaller airlines, that do not have the economies of scale and are not able to offset the huge impact of a consumption tax of this nature. Of course, the tourist industry has said the GST will strangle domestic tourism in Australia; and for the domestic legs of international air travel there will be a further charge as well.

We do not propose, as a government, to introduce a goods and services tax as the Opposition has proposed. But the car manufacturers have complained about the GST, the textile, clothing and footwear industry has complained about it, the building and construction industry has complained about it, the tourism industry has complained about it, the sugar industry has complained about it, the banking and finance industry has complained about it, and the aviation industry is complaining about it; not to mention St Vincent de Paul, ACOSS, the Catholic Social Justice Commission, the Uniting Church and consumer organisations—and if we believe the polls, most Australians have complained about it. It will be interesting to see whether the legitimate complaints of the domestic aviation industry will be met in any backflip the Opposition does on its tax.

We have reduced significantly the costs to the airline industry by a number of the major micro-economic reforms that we have introduced. They have made significant savings to the operations of the airline system in Australia. One of the reasons why we will not be introducing a goods and services tax is that we want Australians to have the advantage of the savings we have made and not have to pay, according to Treasury estimates, 8 per cent more on their domestic airline tickets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that answer, has the Government been able to reduce the costs of the aviation industry? If so, how?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in my answer, we have. Let me now indicate some of the areas in which price reductions to the aviation industry have occurred under our Government. The charges by the Civil Aviation Authority have been decreased in real terms every year since the CAA was established in 1988. This year alone the Civil Aviation Authority has passed on reductions in airways charges of $96m in real terms, and a reduction in the costs of safety regulation of about a further 30 per cent. This represents an effective 16 per cent reduction in overall charges in real terms.

PARA.TAB: In addition, Federal Airports Corporation charges have not increased in real terms since 1988. The Corporation is budgeting for a total capital expenditure of around $2.8 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: I need a ruling from you on this point. Frequently when people rise in the chamber to ask the Minister questions about the FAC or the CAA, the Minister claims that they are commercial operations and at arm's length and that he is unable to give any information about them. I wonder whether, if he is able to give information today, he will tell us when he will bring down the Macphee report into the CAA. If he cannot, will you rule him out of order?

—Order! As I have repeatedly pointed out in the past, it is not the responsibility of the Chair to determine whether answers by Ministers are accurate or truthful. I am not going to try to follow that request.

—What hurts the Opposition is that the answers are truthful and they do score. The FAC is investing another $2.8 billion in capital works programs around Australia, which will create a huge number of jobs for Australians.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Time expired!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am quite capable of seeing when the time expires. The Chair will give the ruling. I do not need help.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order, which I have saved until the conclusion of Senator Cook's remarks. My point of order relates to standing order 184, the standing order under which you keep control in this chamber. As I understood your remarks on an earlier point of order, you indicated that it was clearly disorderly conduct for a senator to use newspaper headlines to gain access to the television coverage of Question Time. Less than 10 minutes after that ruling, Senator Cook deliberately did just that. In other words, straight after that, he deliberately defied your ruling. Accordingly, Mr President, you have discretion under standing order 203(b) to name him for having committed an offence. I am at a loss to understand why you did not do so. I ask you to clarify in my mind and for the benefit of other senators why you did not enforce your own ruling. Or can Government senators do what they like but you will enforce it on us?

—Order! Earlier I said that it was clearly out of order for people to hold up newspaper headlines. It was done repeatedly by Opposition senators last week and they know it. I am asking all senators not to do it again.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Do we take it, from that, that we do not have to take any notice of your original discretion but wait until you repeat your ruling two or three times? Senator Evans did it while Senator Vanstone was on her feet.
—Order! Senator Walters, I am trying to get Question Time through with as few—
—Well, you're not succeeding. They're ignoring you.

—Order! It is up to the Chair at times to ignore breaches of the Standing Orders by either side. Can I just say to Senator Walters that yesterday she repeatedly broke Standing Orders when she referred to a Minister as telling lies, and I ignored it.
—Seven times.
—I did not say that.
—Resume your seat.
—Tell the truth.
—Order! I point out that yesterday you were making comments such as, `Why doesn't the Minister tell the truth'. It was clearly out of order, you did it seven times, and you were wrong.

—My question to the Minister representing the Treasurer relates to the Government's approval of the takeover of the Australian biscuit manufacturer Arnotts by the US company, Campbells. Will the Minister provide the Senate with an analysis of the net economic benefit to Australia of the takeover of this profitable and expanding Australian company? Secondly, will he provide details of when and how this analysis was done and, in particular, whether it was compared with the net benefits to Australia from Arnotts' own plans already under way, firstly to expand exports and then to directly enter Asian markets through joint ventures? Thirdly, why has the Government favoured Campbells' assurances regarding expansion into Asia and not Arnotts' assurances, particularly given Campbells' record of not complying with undertakings given to the Government and Australian shareholders in 1985 when it was first allowed a stake in Arnotts, and given the evidence that in terms of technology and distribution networks, Arnotts is already miles ahead of Campbells?

—First of all, it has been widely reported that Campbells gave undertakings at the time it took a shareholding in Arnotts some years ago. There were no undertakings given by Campbells to the Foreign Investment Review Board; rather there was a scenario as to what Campbells thought would happen as a result of its equity investment in Arnotts. That scenario, I suspect, has not been met, but it is a different matter from talking about undertakings.

PARA.TAB: The net benefits to the Australian economy are very difficult to determine at this stage, and it is the function of the Foreign Investment Review Board to determine these issues. The Treasurer has approved the proposed takeover and has imposed a series of conditions designed to ensure that Arnotts' activities remain centred in Australia. These conditions are that Arnotts will continue to be listed on the Australian Stock Exchange, that the majority of Arnotts board members will be Australian citizens, and that the headquarters and manufacturing operations will continue to be based in Australia. Under amendments made to the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act in 1989, these undertakings are now enforceable. They were not enforceable prior to that legislation being introduced.

I do not want to enter into the public debate about the structure of the Arnotts company, the position of minority shareholders and what percentage of authority they can hold in the overall deliberations and conclusions of the company. But there are legal battles, as I understand it, over these issues and they have to be resolved between Campbells and Arnotts. If the takeover does go ahead, Campbells' experience in the food industry and its financial strength could assist Arnotts in its export strategy. I think I said that in answer to a question from one of Senator Lees's colleagues a week or so ago. The Treasurer took into account a number of matters of advice from the Foreign Investment Review Board in reaching his conclusion on this matter. Conditions of the bid announced by the Treasurer were volunteered by Campbells in discussion with the FIRB and they became conditions as a result of being volunteered in the way they were.

I say to the Democrats generally that the question of foreign investment is probably something which we are quite apart on. There is insufficient capital in this country to develop the industries we would like to develop and we probably have a quite different point of view about all of that. That will be determined in the longer term.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I begin by commenting that investment up to 49 per cent is one thing, and takeover or ownership is quite another. If Campbells breaks the agreements, what do we then do? Do we then somehow get Arnotts back again? Could the Minister consider an additional undertaking: that if Arnotts is taken over, Campbells will use Australian farm products for the manufacture of biscuits both here and also in Asia if biscuits are to be made there?

—I do not know the answer to the second part of the question, but I think it would be ridiculous to try to impose that condition—requiring the use of raw materials from Australia in relation to biscuits made in Asia. That is just a ridiculous interference in the affairs of a business. A business that wants to be competitive will run itself in the way in which it is best suited by the cost of raw materials and so on. In fact, it is Arnotts which has proposed to manufacture overseas; it is not Campbells that has proposed that it do that. Its undertakings relate to manufacture in Australia. In so far as any breach of those undertakings is concerned, that would have to be dealt with under the 1989 legislation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and relates to the Job Club program, which is an initiative to assist long term unemployed people with job search techniques, to maintain their motivation and keep them from despair. Is the Minister aware that no guidelines exist to assist organisations wishing to tender for the provision of a Job Club program for 1993? Can the Minister explain why the Department of Employment, Education and Training has said it is unable to make decisions regarding tenders until the outcome of the forthcoming Federal election is known? Will the Minister make sure that the Department gets its act together as a matter of urgency to ensure, first, an effective tender process, and, secondly, that successful tenderers are notified without further delay to allow them to get their programs in place for 1993, so that the victims of the recession that we had to have are actually able to get the help that the Job Club program was set up to provide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister in this case, Mr Beazley, has provided me with the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator is referring to one of the Government's most successful labour market programs. Obviously in proceeding with any changes to Job Clubs we want to ensure that this success is preserved and built on.

PARA.TAB: The Government is firmly of the view that for many labour market programs assisting job seekers, tendering is the most effective way to ensure the best possible outcome for unemployed people with the most cost-effective use of resources.
