This is why we have decided to bring tendering into the Job Club arrangements.

The honourable senator is mistaken about the availability of guidelines. Guidelines for tendering were distributed to area offices in October 1992 and these were made available to organisations wishing to submit tenders.

Originally it had been planned that tendering would take effect from 1 January 1993. However, in view of concerns about particular issues such as equipment and reporting requirements, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services decided recently to extend the current Job Club contracts for a six month period to 30 June 1993 in order to allow these teething problems to be dealt with. This decision will bring the financial arrangements for Job Clubs providers into line with the financial year cycle in accordance with other labour market programs.

The senator is also mistaken in her reference to elections. There will be an expansion to the Job Club program and additional providers will be selected through a tendering process based on current applications. This will be conducted in January/February following consultations and guideline amendments.
I would repeat that the Government is fully committed to proceeding with tender arrangements for Job Clubs. This decision will allow us to ensure that the tendering process operates successfully.
All organisations who have submitted expressions of interest or tender applications are being advised of this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given the fact that since Mr Keating took over as Prime Minister in December 1991 the trade deficit has increased by $12 billion and last month's trade deficit was the worst figure for three years, will the Minister be announcing any new policies to turn this appalling situation around, or can Australians expect more of the same?
—Perhaps before Christmas honourable senators opposite will identify the faceless person who writes all these questions.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That might be meant as a humorous jibe, but it is a reflection on the honourable senator who asked the question. It is not the first time Senator Button has put this and I ask that he desist.
—Order! I ask Senator Button to answer the question.

—Mr President, I will not make any further comment, except to say that the vocabulary is extremely limited. This question was asked earlier in the week. I simply made the point then, and I make it again, that one month's figures are extremely volatile and all we can do in the longer term is to try, as we have been, to improve the diversity of manufacturing exports and other exports. That has happened and is continuing to happen.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am prompted and reminded by Senator Bishop's interjection, it would not happen under policies which imposed an additional inflation rate on Australia, higher interest rates and so on.
—We would give hope.

—Senator Bishop interjects that such policies would give hope. That is what everybody on the Opposition side of the chamber was saying 12 months ago. These policies will give hope and opportunity to everybody apparently, except the members of the Opposition.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I am happy to debate this matter with Senator Button any time, any place, but Question Time is not the place to do so. Mr President, I ask you to call him to order and for him to answer the question: does he have a policy to reduce our debt?
—Order! I ask Senator Button to answer the question. Again, Senator Bishop, you know that that is not a legitimate point of order.

—Mr President, the question was not about the debt. It just emphasises the point that I made earlier: one has to repeat things over and over again in this place in order for the Opposition to get any understanding of them. As I said in answer to this question earlier this week, improving the current account balance is a task which involves diversifying the export base of this country and encouraging exports. We have a number of policies in place to do that, and the results are reflected in the continuing growth and diversification of Australian exports year by year, particularly in the last two years. These figures have been commented upon by the OECD and others as being quite extraordinary in terms of the change in the pattern of Australian trade. These things will improve, but they will take a little time—
—Oh, you've had 10 years.
—The coalition has had 10 years in opposition and it does not have any policies after that period.

—I address my question to the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister examined the coalition's defence policy A Strong Australia, and will the Government adopt any of the proposals outlined in that policy as its policy?

—Having read the Opposition's policy, I would be very happy to adopt 80 per cent of it because 80 per cent of it is a regurgitation of current policy. I could give many examples here but, limited by the three minutes, I will not do so. A whole range of things in the Opposition's policy merely repeat and reiterate Government policy. It is the 20 per cent that diverts that I would not adopt as current Government policy. The reason for that is that what it really does is spend, spend and spend. It is not funded anywhere in Opposition policies. Not having the funding to do it makes it irresponsible to make those sorts of policy promises. It reminds me of a Labor Party State policy speech in Victoria in the 1960s in which all promises were made.

PARA.TAB: My Department has done a proper costing of the Opposition policy. Its analysis shows that over the period 1993-96, the shortfall in funding is between $895m and $930m. Over three years that is almost $1 billion wrong. This is also taking into account the fact that the Opposition made a mistake in counting the recurrent savings only once. We have counted them right through the program—to be very helpful towards it. That is an enormous hole in the Opposition's policy. If it ever happens to win office and starts to implement this policy in the first months of government, it would lead to absolute destruction in the defence forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were wrong on this 12 months ago and you're still wrong.
—Senator Short says that I am wrong. Senator Short says that my whole Department is wrong. The fact is that the Opposition put out in its defence policy some 229 proposals—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has obviously been reading this policy for months and we should commend him on that. But this is not the time for debating Opposition policy. I know the Government tried to dress up the question in a form that was acceptable, but the answer went beyond that into what could be interpreted as nothing other than a debate on Opposition defence policy. The time for that is after Question Time and we would be quite happy to take the Minister on then.

—On the point of order, Mr President: the question was whether the Government would adopt Opposition policy. Senator Ray said, `We will not be adopting it because it is fiscally irresponsible'. He is now pointing out why it is fiscally irresponsible, and he is quite right.
—Order! The Minister is entitled to use arguments as to whether he will implement a certain policy, but I ask him not to debate the issue.

—I will respond to Senator Hill, who says that it has taken me all this time to respond. I put out a total response to the Opposition's policy within 44 hours of its publication. That is because it had been leaked to absolutely everyone and we all knew what was to be in it.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge that Senator Hill is right; I cannot debate the policy per se, other than to say that it has now been fully and fairly costed with generous assumptions, which leads me to the view that there is no way this Government could adopt those policies without allocating an extra $300m a year over the next three financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you find the money for the F111s?
—It has nothing to do with the F111s; that is supplementary to the Defence budget and it does not have to be included in these costings. Where will Senator Hill find the $300m a year?
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister quoted from a document which he referred to as the departmental text. I ask that he table the full text of the departmental report.
—Order! It is a matter for the Minister as to whether he will table the document he was quoting from.
—It is my pleasure, Mr President. As of now, there are multiple copies in my office for anyone who wants to drop around and pick them up.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Since the Labor Government came to office nearly 10 years ago there have been 18 major economic statements, all of which Mr Keating has been responsible for. He has continually said such things as, `Australia is winning', `Government policy has been innovative', `Economic strategy is bearing fruit'—
—He's `bringing home the bacon'.

—Yes, there is the one about his bringing home the bacon. Pigs—prophetic, was it not? The Prime Minister has made comments such as, `A monument to competence' and `On the way back to prosperity'. Why should Australians ever trust the Prime Minister when we have the worst recession in 60 years and one million unemployed? Where are his policies? When will he announce them?
—This question is asked on behalf of an Opposition the Leader of which says, `If my policies have to change, I'll resign'.
—Eighteen changes.
—Senator Knowles finds it very funny. She says that there have been eighteen changes. Senator Knowles anticipated Dr Hewson. She rewrote the Fightback package on radio in Perth last week.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, I warn you against consistently interjecting.

—Mr President, I seek your guidance. I am but one person who is sick and tired of the lies that are coming from the other side. I am also sick and tired of the misrepresentation of what I have said. We are constantly asking what the policies of those opposite are and they constantly want to debate ours. At least we have a policy; those opposite do not. I ask your advice as to how we stop the diatribe of lies coming from that side.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I am asking for your guidance.

—Order! In reply to Senator Knowles, as I said earlier today—and I have pointed it out in the past—it is not the responsibility of the Chair to determine whether answers given by Ministers are accurate or truthful. Points of order cannot be taken on the basis of a Minister allegedly making inaccurate or misleading statements because that is a matter of order and not a matter for the Chair. If senators wish to refute statements made by Ministers, they should use the procedures available to them, such as motions to take note of answers and personal explanations.
—Senator Knowles attracted my attention by making persistent interjections.
—Are you going to repeat the lies you repeated yesterday?
—Order! Senator Knowles, you know that is not in order and I ask you to withdraw it.
—If Senator Knowles wants attention attracted to her, I will publish what she said, together with the Fightback policy, in Perth.
—Why don't you do the whole lot?
—The whole lot. That is what I will do.
—Order! Senator Knowles.
—Senator Knowles will get plenty of attention then, if that is what she wants.
—Order! Senator Knowles, I have asked you twice to withdraw.
—But the Minister he just continued to continue the same lie. I did not have a chance to withdraw.

—Order! I am asking you to withdraw. You asked me a question earlier about what can be done. I gave you the answer. Now I am asking you to withdraw the imputation you made that the Minister was lying. I ask you to withdraw.
—How do I defend myself against the lies that he is telling about me? I will withdraw, if that is the procedural thing to do, but he is still continuing to say things that I have not said.
—Order! Senator, you know what steps you can take to answer that later. I ask you to withdraw.
—I will withdraw.

—Mr President, perhaps I may come back to the question and answer it without interruption. It is all very well to say that the Government has had 18 economic statements in almost 10 years in office. Of course, that is true. But what we have been about as a government is implementing change and restructuring the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We inherited an economy with double digit unemployment, double digit inflation and double digit interest rates. That is the economy we inherited—an economy in which there had been no structural change during the seven years of coalition government. The fact is that through a period of nine years in government, we have had consistent structural change in this economy, which is reflected, for example, in the export performance across a range of industries.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite go on about levels of unemployment. I have just made the point that the United Kingdom, the coalition's model country, is in a far worse economic mess than this one. That is their model—that is the Thatcher model; that is the model espoused by John Hewson, their present leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it's your model.

—It is the model. Those opposite are fixed in the 1970s in terms of their economic policies—Reaganomics and Thatcherism. That is the economic model which those opposite used for Fightback. That is why they are trying to walk away from it, to get some policies relevant to the 1990s.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that the Akatsuki Maru is now certain to pass south of Australia on its way to Japan with 1.7 tonnes of plutonium, is it a fact that Fremantle and Hobart have been designated as the ports to which the vessel would go in case of emergency? If not, which ports have been so designated? During which dates will the Akatsuki Maru pass through the emergency zone for each designated port? What safety measures will be implemented at the designated ports? How will the costs of responding to any emergency be shared between the Japanese, Australian or any other governments? Why should Australians be put at risk by a totally needless plutonium shipment, which will do little more than increase Japan's future capacity to build nuclear weapons?

—No Australian port has been designated as the port to which the Akatsuki Maru would go in an emergency. As I have said in previous answers on this issue, if emergency circumstances were to arise and Japan requested Australia's assistance, the Australian Government would consider such a request in accordance with the international law applicable to ships in distress. In the case of port access, it would be within the discretion of the Australian Government to determine whether port access would be granted. Port access is normally granted to ships in distress but safety would be a paramount consideration in deciding whether to grant access to the ship and, if so, which port might be the most suitable for such access.

PARA.TAB: As to Senator Bell's second question, it is the case that the ship rounded the Cape of Good Hope earlier this month heading eastward through the Indian Ocean. The Japanese Government will not depart from its clearly stated intention, for security reasons, not to advise any other countries of the precise route. If the ship continues to sail eastward, however, then on normal sailing times it would be about mid-December before it came anywhere near Australia.

As to Senator Bell's third question, appropriate arrangements involving a number of government departments and agencies, including the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre, are in place to coordinate an Australian response to maritime emergencies, including any emergency that might involve the Akatsuki Maru. Such arrangements would be activated promptly if an emergency arose. We have a capacity to assist ships in distress, but the exact nature of the response would obviously again depend on the nature of the emergency.

In regard to the costs of responding to any emergency, the Japanese Government has said that any nuclear liability arising from the plutonium cargo is insured by the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation of Japan—PNC—which is a government owned organisation which, according to Japanese law, takes responsibility for nuclear liability. If that nuclear liability was not fully covered by PNC's insurance, the Japanese Government has made clear it would assist PNC financially, so there would be no limit to the nuclear liability. As regards non-nuclear liability, I understand the Akatsuki Maru and its escort ship are insured in accordance with usual maritime insurance provisions.

As to the final question, the Government has conducted an intensive examination of all aspects of the planned shipments to ensure that any implications for Australia could be fully considered. The Government has satisfied itself that the physical protection and safety arrangements for the shipment meet, or indeed exceed, international standards for the transport of plutonium.

As to Senator Bell's assertion about nuclear weapons, I refer Senator Bell to the answer I gave in this place on 11 November in which I stated—and I will say again—that the Government has no reason whatsoever to doubt Japan's commitment to the use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes only, in accordance with its obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. We will continue to monitor this total situation and, as I told the Senate on 25 November, I will keep honourable senators informed of any developments, especially in regard to the safety and security of the shipment which might affect our position in any way on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. The Minister, of course, detected that the purpose of the question was to determine what degree of consultation had taken place between Australia and Japan with regard to the route; and also the degree of preparedness within any of the ports which might be required to provide assistance. I do not think the Minister said what degree of consultation took place.

—I said, both in my answer today and on previous occasions, that the Japanese Government has consulted in a number of respects about safety arrangements and so on, but it has not been prepared to consult with any country, including us, on the question as to the route that the ship would follow.

—Will the Minister for Industrial Relations confirm that it is a fact that a small team of officers from the Minister's Department were sent to New Zealand to gather information about recent industrial relations reforms in that country in order to find evidence to boost the Keating Government's propaganda campaign against Fightback? Will the Minister confirm that it is a fact that when those officers returned with a detailed report attesting to the proven success of the operation of the Employment Contracts Act in New Zealand, the Minister flew into a rage in his office and instructed the officers to get out of his sight and never allow their report to see the light of day?
—Oh, come on!

—This is what I understand; it has fallen off the back of a truck. The Minister can get up and deny it if he wishes, but I hope he will take it as a very serious question. Will the Minister table this important report in the Senate this afternoon or maybe tomorrow?
—Order! The time has expired.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This question contains the fantastic proposition that I flew into some sort of rage with officers of my Department. That is totally ridiculous. That has never ever occurred in my tenure as Minister for Industrial Relations. I have answered this question in the Senate before. Senator Austin Lewis is not the first member of the Opposition to ask me a question about this. It has been fully answered before. I refer Senator Lewis to the answer which, as I recall, was that the research division of my Department is conducting research on enterprise bargaining and the effects of enterprise bargaining in various places of the world. As a part of that research task, they visited New Zealand in order to collect evidence of the circumstances in that country.

PARA.TAB: My Department is close to finishing the report. It is my intention to have the report released when it is concluded, because I think it will be an essential element in the discussion about comparative systems of workplace or enterprise bargaining. It will be a scholarly contribution to the debate in Australia because it will be done on an academic basis with due regard to disinterested analysis rather than to the politically fired rhetoric that we so often hear from the Opposition and, unfortunately, from some people in New Zealand about the alleged comparative advantages of their model.

It is fantastic to propose—as this question implies, and as Senator Austin Lewis said almost directly—that there is anything here other than contributing to the sum of knowledge and body of research available about how best a labour market might function. This is an initiative of my Department occurring without prompting from me, and I commend it for its initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I hear the Minister denying certain aspects of the question but not denying other aspects of the question. Will the Minister undertake to table in the Senate, even if it has to be in due course, an unexpurgated copy of the report of the New Zealand investigations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be published in the normal way as research monographs from my Department are published. I would not want to unnecessarily interfere in the normal course of process. I certainly will not add any weight to the unseemly and improper allegations Senator Lewis is making about this document. When it becomes available to me, I will make it available to the Senate as a matter of courtesy, now that he has asked. But I can say to Senator Lewis quite categorically that the allegations contained in his question are wrong. Asking innocent or naive questions containing serious allegations is a way of making an allegation and it is very close to being unparliamentary. I do not think that was Senator Lewis's endeavour; but if it was, it is not a very smart move by him.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Government today seemed to be trying to imply that if we looked at Australia's net debt situation, we would see that it is not as bad as the gross figures indicate and that, somehow or other, the coalition was ignoring the net situation as distinct from the gross. That, of course, is totally wrong. We have said time and again—and these figures are beyond dispute—that the net level of Australia's borrowings abroad is now $162,000m. That compares with a figure of about $25 billion at the time that this Government came into office. In other words, that is well over a sixfold increase in Australia's debt in that period.

PARA.TAB: The increase in gross debt has been even more than that; it has been closer to a tenfold increase. Indeed, if the Leader of the Government is saying that the net debt position has in any way improved, I refer him back not to the last 10 years but just five years. If he looks at his own official statistics, he will find that Australia's net liabilities to the rest of the world at the end of the September quarter this year were more than $209,000m, and that compares with a figure of only $120,000m only five years ago.

The Leader of the Government is so interested in this subject, he is so interested in a proper, rational debate in the Senate on this, that he gathers up his papers and walks out. That is typical of the performance of this Minister and this Government over recent years. He is not prepared to sit down and debate the actual figures and the real issues facing this country. He seems to regard Australia's debt to the rest of the world as a bit of a joke, as if it does not really count. He does not seem to believe that every Australian owes the rest of the world the equivalent of $11,000—$44,000 per average family in Australia—and he seeks to deny all those figures.

More importantly, or at least as significant, is the proposition that he is putting—and he has been peddling this for years now and he knows it is wrong—that there is somehow such a fundamental difference between foreign debt from private sector debt relative to public sector debt that the total level does not really matter at all. That, of course, is an absolute nonsense. It is the total level of debt that is of concern. To consider just how bad that problem is one also needs to look at the uses to which the borrowings have been put and who is doing the borrowing.

Time will not permit us to pursue the matter today because it needs a much fuller debate; but Senator Button is talking about a massive fall in public sector debt. I do not know whether Senator Button knows that, as a result of the absolute runaway situation in the Budget over the past couple of years, official public sector debt has blown out enormously. Indeed, since 1990-91, that is less than two years ago, we have had a near doubling in the public sector debt to the rest of the world to almost $30 billion. That is a matter that the Government has to address as a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in his answer Senator Button said that a Liberal-National Party coalition government would stop unemployment benefits after nine months. I am sick and tired of sitting in this chamber and listening to Senator Button and Senator Cook say that over and over again.

PARA.TAB: I was absolutely dismayed and disgusted when, during the Victorian State election, a Labor State member put out a letter to the Cambodians in the area around Springvale and Dandenong. The letter was written in Khmer, with no English translation. The third or fourth paragraph of that letter said that a coalition government would cut off all social security benefits after nine months. In the letter those people were also told that, if they could not get a job, they would be left to starve to death. That is the sort of rubbish, the sorts of lies, that those on the other side are peddling around the place, frightening people.

I do not know what legal recourse I can take but it is totally unacceptable that a Labor member can write to a group of people in their own language telling them that, under a coalition government, if they cannot find a job they will starve to death. More than half of those sitting on the Government benches are baby boomers who grew up under a coalition Liberal government and many of them are far too well fed. Some of them would do well to starve for a while. I will not sit here and listen to Senator Cook say over and over again that people—

TALK.START.PARA: —You think it is all right for people to starve?
—It is not all right for people to starve to death. Senator West should not be so stupid. I did not say that. I said it would do for them to starve for a while.
—That is different, is it?

—Some of them would do well not to stuff their faces as much as they do. As I was saying, these Cambodians were told that they would be left to starve to death. It is a lie and it is wrong to say that a coalition government would cut off unemployment benefits after nine months. Yet the Labor Party continues to say it over and over again. It is not acceptable.

PARA.TAB: What the policy says is that no-one who has participated in appropriate training programs and demonstrated a willingness to find work but who is still without a job will be denied access to assistance. That assistance, that special benefit, will be the same as the Jobsearch allowance or the Newstart allowance. So what the Government is saying is totally untrue. It is peddling untruths. It has no policies of its own; its members do not have a policy in their brains. They have sent this country down the tube.

We now have over one million people unemployed and many more underemployed. We have a foreign debt which is insurmountable and which our children and our children's children will be paying back. They will be working their insides out to pay back the debt that this Government has left this country with. That is the legacy it has left us with. Government members peddle lies. They have no policies. All they can do is tell untruths about our policies. I find it unacceptable, and I do not know what we are going to do, but somehow the public will realise at some point that the lies that they are peddling are what they are—lies—and that they are telling newcomers to this country in their own language that we will leave them to starve to death. That is the level that they play at.

TALK.START.PARA: —It stinks.
—Yes, it does stink. That is the way they play. We do not play that way. We have a policy up front and we are telling people how it is, not lying about their policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments of Senator Short in taking note of the most unsatisfactory answer of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. The very simple, straightforward question was this: we have an international debt of $162 billion net, and I want to know, and Australia wants to know, what the Government's policy is to reduce that debt. Clearly, there is no policy. Again and again the Minister abuses individuals because they have the audacity to ask him for the Government's policy. Senator Tate was honest the other day. He said that the Government did not have a policy. It is important that we put on the record some of the more, shall we say, profound statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) over the years as that debt has grown. Perhaps we can start with this one. In the Budget Speech 1985 the then Treasurer, the now Prime Minister, said:

PARA.TAB: . . . I have outlined the Government's strategy for the new financial year. It is a strategy that builds upon our very significant successes . . . and puts behind us the despair and economic failure of the former Government.

SPEECH.PARA: By this stage the foreign debt had risen from $23 billion to $51.2 billion. Each year it went up—to $75 billion and then to $82 billion. In 1988, he said:

PARA.TAB: . . . the nation is successfully emerging from its most severe economic crisis in a generation.

SPEECH.PARA: He said, `This is the one that brings home the bacon'. So he bought a pig farm. He went on:
Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.
By then the debt was up to $92.8 billion. In the Budget Speech of 1989 he said:

PARA.TAB: . . . as a result of the Government's economic policies Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving.

SPEECH.PARA: By this stage unemployment was up and debt was $100 billion. In the Budget Speech of 1990 he said:

PARA.TAB: This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up.
. . . delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

SPEECH.PARA: Well, we got both, did we not? By this stage the debt was $124 billion. In 1992 he said:

PARA.TAB: The Keating Government's economic strategy is to accelerate recovery from recession and at the same time build a stronger Australia. It is a four year plan. It begins now, with an immediate boost to spending and employment. It ends in 1995-96 with a Budget back in surplus and dramatically reduced marginal income tax rates for most Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: By this time foreign debt was $145 billion and there was a big hole in the Budget and a subsequent statement, saying:
Since when has surplus become holy writ? We won't have a surplus.

In other words, every year the statement that the Prime Minister has made both in his capacity of Treasurer and then as Prime Minister simply is untrue. He reverses his position. Look at the myriad of so-called policies we have had on the run in the communications area and the pay television area—back-flips, reversals, changes of mind, roll-overs in the party room. You name it; it has happened.

PARA.TAB: Finally, here we are trying to find out what policy the Government has to reduce the now $162 billion debt. What answer does it have? Nothing, except to criticise a fine policy, the Fightback policy, which has long had a heritage and a tradition of being subject to monitoring by the Cole Committee, with various announcements being made from time to time. We are moving in a most deliberate, systematic and logical progression, taking account of a million unemployed and an international debt of $162 billion—and a Prime Minister who tells fibs.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is delightful for Senator Bishop to talk about Fightback as a fine policy and about backflips. In the last 24 hours we have seen the best backflip in all political history. Opposition senators were going mad about our comments on the impact on the community of certain of their policies, but they did not know that policy was being made on the run. There was a minor variation in the morning, and by the evening there was a huge variation.

—If I could take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: it is the Government that has caused us to have limited debate when taking note of answers given in Question Time. Therefore, I think it important that the little time we do have relates in fact to the question and answer given. In other words, the question was: what is your policy, Government, to reduce our debt? The answer was that there was not one. We are not discussing our policy.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President, I point out that the point of order that was raised when Senator Patterson spoke to this motion had nothing to do with the debt level. She talked about letters to Cambodian voters in the Victorian State election, which had nothing in any way to do with Senator Short's motion, and she was allowed to use a full four minutes.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, if I could take a point of order: Senator Button in his answer to the question told a monstrous untruth about our policy on unemployment benefits, so Senator Patterson, who was taking note of Senator Button's answer, was quite entitled to raise that issue. Senator Schacht, as usual, has got it wrong.
—All these points of order are debating points of order. I think Senator West should have the chance to speak.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Kemp referred to something Senator Button said as a `monstrous untruth'. That is obviously unparliamentary, and I ask you to request him to withdraw it.
—He just called it an untruth, as far as I—
—A `monstrous untruth'. That is unparliamentary, in my submission.
—I did not think it was. I thought that to be unparliamentary it had to be termed a `lie'.
—Might I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to refer that matter to the President for determination?
—Yes, you may. I will do that.

—There are obviously some very sensitive souls opposite who do not want us to examine too closely some of the reasons behind the flip-flops that have taken place in the last 24 hours. It is interesting that they talk about foreign debt. They conveniently forget that we have greater net assets overseas in money—
—I said `net debt'.
—Most of the debt in this country is in fact owed by private people. Maybe they should be asking their previous President, John Elliott, just how high his foreign debt is.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Could I please have silence on my left.

—These are issues that those opposite might like to canvass with some more thought. We have seen in previous weeks severe castigation of members of the Opposition, who have had the temerity to suggest that there might be changes to their policy. I am particularly reminded of the criticism that was heaped on the right honourable member for New England, Mr Sinclair, by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) when he dared to suggest on 19 or 20 November this year that Fightback would be doctored, that there would be changes, and that certain things would happen if the coalition won power and was not doing terribly well in presenting its policies. The right honourable member for New England was roundly criticised by his Leader, but it now appears that Mr Sinclair was correct.

PARA.TAB: Mr Sinclair, being the wily old politician—and I say that with the utmost respect; he is someone who is venerated and respected—obviously had grave reservations about the GST. In Bathurst on 19 November he said that some changes to Fightback and the GST would be necessary. He went on to say that the coalition plan to remove many existing taxes and replace them with a flat rate system must be subject to finetuning to meet the needs of the time. That, of course, is the key thing that those opposite will say—that they are meeting the needs of the time and are finetuning.

We must never forget that the GST will be introduced and, when the Opposition deems the time is right, further finetuned back to what it originally wanted us to be subjected to. Mr Sinclair went on to say, `Of course they will be doctored'. I suggest that this is what will happen within the next 10 days; we will see the Opposition doctoring its policies.

The other matter is that those opposite will wait until 18 December to announce the changes. They are not able to come into this place or go to the people of this country and tell us what their policies are because they do not have the intestinal fortitude to take them into the lower House so that they can be debated there and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) can, in his usual form, do over, very slowly and very well, the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

PARA.TAB: The other argument we heard from the other side was, `We have these other assets overseas'. Let us talk about some of those other assets that we are supposed to have overseas. The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! Senator Schacht, you can make your contribution later.

—He is well known to be a balanced man: he has a chip on both shoulders. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Short. Senator Short has basically said to every interest group in the Australian community, `Come and see us in the next 10 days and we will amend Fightback to take account of your needs and your interests. We know we are doomed to lose the next election because all the polls in the last four weeks have turned round and we can't win'. For the last 13 1/2 months Dr Hewson has said that there would not be the slightest change in Fightback, and that it would stand. He said, `I will resign rather than change'. Yesterday, he calmly announced—but there was a note of panic—after some pressure from the jellybacks in the Liberal and National parties, `We are going to review the policies. We are going to make changes to make Fightback more acceptable'.

PARA.TAB: After 13 or 14 months, four different opinion polls came out in 3 1/2 weeks which showed that those opposite were going to lose. Madam ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Schacht, you will use the correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee gets up in this place and tells us that this is a terrible Labor policy. He is a member of a coalition that has no policy at all on foreign investment. Fightback has now become `Turnback' and, ultimately, the new policies ought to be called `Clawback', as those opposite try to claw their way back in the opinion polls to get over the panic that has set in. —I suppose the best thing we can say about Senator Schacht's speech is that it was marginally better than Senator West's speech, and that is not saying much. PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—
