TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the minute or so of time remaining to me in this debate, let me puncture some of this pompous rhetoric that is coming from the other side by making two swift points about our debt. The first point is that the significance of any country's national debt depends, first of all, on its composition. The composition of Australia's overseas debt, whether we are talking about gross or net, is overwhelmingly private rather than public. The overwhelming proportion of it is debt that has been chalked up by the private sector in order to improve our domestic productive capacity. Only a small proportion of it is public and, of that, only a very small proportion is in the Commonwealth sector from either the Commonwealth Government or the Reserve Bank.

PARA.TAB: The second point I would make is that the significance of any country's debt depends, if one is trying to attribute economic significance to it, on whether or not one can service it out of the flow of returns that come from the export of goods and services. In that respect, the story is a very simple one. The debt servicing ratio—our capacity to service this debt—has been dramatically declining. It is down to 15.4 per cent from 19.1 per cent last year. That is an improvement to the lowest rate since 1988. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the circumstances surrounding the positive drug test on Mr Alex Watson. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: RECOMMENDATIONS—COMMITTEE'S REPORT
Recommendation l.A

That until the performance enhancing effects and the likelihood of athletes exceeding the International Olympic Committee (IOC) Caffeine limit are clarified, the Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) recommends to the IOC the removal of Caffeine from the list of proscribed drugs.
Government Position: Not Supported
The Government considers that the removal of caffeine from the International Olympic Committee (IOC) list of proscribed drugs would result in a significant and unacceptable amount of caffeine doping.

Until further research is completed, as per the Committee's Recommendation l.B., any change to the IOC Caffeine limit would be premature. While there is uncertainty about what should be the IOC's Caffeine limit, this does not justify the complete removal of any control on Caffeine as a performance enhancing substance.

The Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) is currently undertaking research into the likelihood of athletes exceeding the IOC Caffeine limit and reliable measurements for Caffeine levels. Depending on the results of this research, ASDA will consider a review of the status of the IOC Caffeine limit, within the next twelve to eighteen months. Where this research indicates that the Caffeine limit imposed by the IOC is inappropriate, that information will be made available to the IOC Medical Commission.
Recommendation l.B.
That the Australian Sports Drug Agency commission research into:
(i)the ingestion of Caffeine comparing alternative routes; for example: by drinking, by suppository, by injection;
(ii)the likelihood of athletes exceeding the IOC Caffeine limit;
(iii)reliable measurements of Caffeine levels;
(iv)the effects on performance;
and that it report its findings to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.
Government Position: Supported in Principle

The Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) has commissioned a research project, jointly funded by the Australian Sports Commission's (ASC) Applied Sports Research Program entitled "An Investigation of the Pharmaco-Kinetics of Caffeine Ingestion and Elimination in Athletes". The research will provide information relevant to questions on the likelihood of athletes exceeding the International Olympic Committee's Caffeine limit and reliable measures for Caffeine levels.
ASDA will ensure the findings of the research are made available to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and presented in relevant scientific journals.

Research projects on alternative routes of Caffeine ingestion and the effects of Caffeine on physical performance have been identified as priorities in ASDA's 1992-93 Research Program and will be undertaken if funding becomes available from interested agencies.
Recommendation 2

That the AOC recommend to the IOC that while Caffeine remains on the IOC list of proscribed drugs., Caffeine beverages not be available at Olympic Games competition venues and athletes be advised of the possibility of exceeding the proscribed limit by simply drinking coffee.
Government Position: Noted
This recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.
Recommendation 3
That the AOC provide comprehensive drug briefings for Australian Olympic athletes both at the time of selection and immediately prior to departure for future Olympic Games.
Government Position: Supported

This recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's (AOC) attention. In addition, the Australian Sports Drug Agency developed an internationally acclaimed drugs in sport education program. In 1992-93 the Agency received an additional $300,000 to enhance this program. The Agency will offer to assist the AOC to provide comprehensive drug briefings for Australian Olympic athletes competing in future Olympic Games.
Recommendation 4
That the AOC:
(i)formulate comprehensive procedures for when Australian athletes are found to have positive drug tests or infringe IOC drug rules at Olympic Games;
(ii)provide all Australian Olympic athletes with a copy of the procedures; and
(iii)ensure the availability of an appropriately qualified advocate for any Australian athlete infringing IOC drug rules.
Government Position: Noted
This recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.

That Australian athletes found to have breached drug guidelines be penalised in accordance with internationally accepted standards: up to three months ban for inadvertent use, two years for a first offence, and a life ban for any subsequent offence.
Government Position: Supported

The Australian Sports Commission's Doping Policy provides for sanctions in line with international standards recognising that there is variability among international sporting federations, particularly between Olympic and non-Olympic sports. As a condition of funding under the Sports Development Program, Australian sporting organisations are required to apply and enforce effective sanctions on persons who are found to have engaged in a doping practice.
Also, this recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.
Recommendation 5
That the Australian Sports Commission comment in its annual reports on positive drug tests by prominent Australian athletes and the procedures established to deal with them.
Government Position: Supported in Principle
The Australian Sports Commission (ASC) accepts its responsibility to report on its area of responsibility in drugs in sport issues in its Annual Report.

In August 1990, compliance with the ASC Doping Policy was made a condition of funding under the Sports Development Program. From the time Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) was established as an independent authority and commenced regular reports to the ASC on positive drug test results and refusals, the ASC has monitored actions taken by sporting organisations. Relevant reports will be included in the ASC's Annual Report.
In giving effect to this recommendation the ASC will have regard to and comply with the provisions of the Privacy Act.

In addition, ASDA provides a list of all positive drug tests recorded by the Agency in its Annual Report. The list does not identify individual athletes but rather records the sport, date of collection, default, substances, class of drug and the sanction imposed.
RECOMMENDATIONS—MINORITY REPORT
Recommendation 1

That the details of this research [. . . on Caffeine related matters currently being undertaken by the Australian Sports Drug Agency . . . ] and the subsequent findings be made available to the Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) and the International Olympic Committee (IOC) Medical Commission.
Government Position: Supported

Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) has commissioned a research project, jointly funded by the Australian Sports Commission's (ASC) Applied Sports Research Program, entitled "An Investigation of the Pharmaco-Kinetics of Caffeine Ingestion and Elimination in Athletes". The research will provide information relevant to questions on the likelihood of athletes exceeding the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) Caffeine limit and reliable measures for Caffeine levels. ASDA will ensure the findings of the research are made available to the Australian Olympic Committee and the IOC Medical Commission.
Recommendation 2
That the AOC provide a thoroughly detailed and comprehensive drug briefing for Australian Olympic athletes both at times of selection and immediately prior to departure for future Olympic Games.
Government Position: Supported

This recommendation has been brought to the attention of the Australian Olympic Committee (AOC). In addition, the Australian Sports Drug Agency developed an internationally acclaimed drugs in sport education program. In 1992-93 the Agency received an additional $300,000 to enhance this program. The Agency will offer to assist the AOC to provide comprehensive drug briefings for Australian Olympic athletes competing in future Olympic Games.
Recommendation 3
That the Australian Olympic Committee appoint an independent Sports Drug Tribunal to hear disputed cases of positive drug tests and to facilitate any appeals to international authorities.
Government Position: Noted
This recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.
Recommendation 4
That the AIS rule prohibiting access by (drug) banned athletes be amended to permit assistance to such athletes who may require AIS facilities in order to appeal against positive drug tests.
Government Position: Supported

The Australian Sports Commission (ASC) is aware that the interpretation of some positive tests may require an evaluation by medical or scientific experts. Banned athletes will not be refused access to ASC facilities where this access is directly relevant to an appeal against a positive drug test.
Recommendation 5
That the AOC:
(i)provide a legal adviser who can assist;
(ii)provide a technical expert;
(iii)formulate comprehensive procedures for Australian athletes found to have positive drug tests or alleged to have infringed IOC drug rules at Olympic Games;
(iv)provide all Australian Olympic athletes with a copy of the procedures; and
(v)ensure the availability of an appropriately qualified independent advocate for any Australian athlete infringing IOC drug rules.
Government Position: Noted
This recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.

That Australian athletes found to have breached drug guidelines be penalised in accordance with internationally accepted standards: up to three months ban for inadvertent use, two years for a first offence, and a life ban for any subsequent offence.
Government Position: Supported

The Australian Sports Commission's (ASC) Doping Policy provides for sanctions in line with international standards recognising that there is variability among international sporting federations, particularly between Olympic and non-Olympic sports. As a condition of funding under the Sports Development Program, Australian sporting organisations are required to apply and enforce effective sanctions on persons who are found to have engaged in a doping practice.
Also, this recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.
Recommendation 6

That the AOC devise and publish a protocol to be signed by Australian Olympic athletes covering the manner in which any athlete would return to Australia if disqualified from a Games. Such a protocol would determine aspects of travel, escort arrangements, communications with family, protection from media attention and the particular requirements of adolescent athletes.
Government Position: Noted
This recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.
Recommendation 7
That Caffeine in any concentration in the urine be proscribed.
That an appeal against the findings of Caffeine in a sample could be based on inadvertent use and that a level for inadvertency be set.
Government Position: Not supported

Proscribing any level of Caffeine in the urine would create many difficulties for testing agencies. If this were to be enforced, it would inevitably lead to a vast increase in the number of athletes testing positive through inadvertent use of Caffeine, and therefore create an unnecessary drain on the limited resources of testing agencies.
Recommendation 8

That the Australian Sports Commission comment in its annual reports on positive drug tests by prominent Australian athletes and the procedures established to deal with them and other investigations conducted by the ASC into alleged doping practices including self admission of the use of banned drugs and possession of banned drugs.
Government Position: Supported in Principle
The Australian Sports Commission (ASC) accepts its responsibility to report on its area of responsibility in drugs in sport issues in its Annual Report.

In August 1990, compliance with the ASC Doping Policy was made a condition of funding under the Sports Development Program. From the time Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) was established as an independent authority and commenced regular reports to the ASC on positive drug test results and refusals, the ASC has monitored actions taken by sporting organisations. Relevant reports will be included in the ASC's Annual Report.
In giving effect to this recommendation the ASC will have regard to and comply with the provisions of the Privacy Act.

In addition, ASDA provides a list of all positive drug tests recorded by the Agency in its Annual Report. The list does not identify individual athletes but rather records the sport, date of collection, default, substances, class of drug and the sanction imposed.
Recommendation 9

That the IOC adopt the hearing and appeal provisions as set out in their brochure Annex 6 headed "Rights and Responsibilities of Sports Organisations, Athletes and their Entourage", together with Annex 7 "Guidelines for Sanctions and Penalties".
Government Position: Noted
This recommendation has been brought to the Australian Olympic Committee's attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This response from the Government to the report by the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts is welcome, except for one aspect from my point of view. I will come to that in a moment. The inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the positive drug test on Mr Alex Watson grew out of the drugs in sport inquiry—that is a fair enough way to say how this inquiry arose. I note on the record—as I think we have done before—that, in large part, we need to acknowledge the input of Senator Crichton-Browne in bringing this initiative to attention.

PARA.TAB: The concerns were two-fold as far as the Committee was concerned. Firstly, what exactly constituted caffeine drugging for the purposes of performance enhancement? It is certainly of concern to the Committee—and of concern to me—that the Government has not supported the Committee's first recommendation which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That until the performance enhancing effects and the likelihood of athletes exceeding the International Olympic Committee (IOC) Caffeine limit are clarified, the Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) recommends to the IOC the removal of Caffeine from the list of proscribed drugs.

I think that leaves the difficulties that confronted the Committee when it first examined this whole question of caffeine drug assistance in sport exactly where they were before. The second recommendation—which the Government supports in principle—states:
That the Australian Sports Drug Agency commission research into:
(i)the ingestion of Caffeine comparing alternative routes; for example: by drinking, by suppository, by injection;
(ii)the likelihood of athletes exceeding the IOC Caffeine limit;
(iii)reliable measurements of Caffeine levels;
(iv)the effects on performance;
and that it report its findings to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

I think it is not unreasonable to say that until we get back the detailed research we should withhold recommendations about whether caffeine should be a proscribed drug. It certainly seemed to the Committee that, as in the case of Alex Watson, considerable injustice was possible if the caffeine limits were left as they were.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, there is much confusion about what is a proscribed drug. The definition includes that it be performance enhancing, but caffeine as a drug sometimes has exactly the opposite effect: it makes performance less good. I do not see the International Olympic Committee or those official organisations which are testing against the use of caffeine making the distinction. If caffeine is actually a disadvantage we would not bother measuring it; as opposed to when caffeine can be said to be an advantage and it should be measured.

There is a lot of room for very much tightened definitions in this area of sport and drugs. In the meantime, I am very pleased that we have this report as a test case and a warning, if you like, to those organisations which have the responsibility of dealing with drugs in sport. They need to make sure that they practise natural justice. If there is doubt about a definition I believe the definition should be tightened before any more challenges or charges are brought against people for using particular drugs.

One of the matters I have raised in this place which is of enormous concern to me is that if we are looking at the definition of a proscribed drug to mean that it is performance enhancing, what business do people have testing for drugs which are not performance enhancing? The example I have cited before in this place is the testing of football teams for marijuana which, by any definition, is not performance enhancing—quite the contrary. A lot of organisations and drug testers seem to have their morals confused with performance enhancing drugs. As a matter of natural justice, we should be looking very much to clear up the definition of proscribed drugs and what we mean by `performance enhancing'. In particular, in the context of this report it is important to determine what those two criteria mean when it comes to the use of caffeine.

The report also pointed out that it was very odd indeed for caffeine to be listed as a proscribed drug and, at the same time, be freely available for athletes during their performance. So we recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . caffeine beverages not be available at Olympic Games competition venues and athletes be advised of the possibility of exceeding the proscribed limit by simply drinking coffee.

The Government's response is that this recommendation has been noted and brought to the attention of the Australian Olympic Committee. Bringing it to people's attention is one thing, but if we are very concerned—as we were in the Committee—that caffeine is a proscribed drug, that athletes could be found guilty of exceeding the limits for that drug and that very significant consequences could flow for their future in sport and their life generally, it seems very odd indeed, in fact positively contradictory, to have caffeine beverages freely available. Subsequent testing has shown that it is possible to exceed the proscribed levels of caffeine merely by drinking coffee.

PARA.TAB: The Committee discovered that there are very significant differences from one person to another in the body's capacity to absorb and break down caffeine. A dose that would take one athlete above the proscribed levels might not necessarily cause another to reach those levels. So, again, the difference between individuals needs to be taken account of. Levels need to be set so that some people are not inadvertently caught. At the same time we think it is very important that athletes be provided with full information about the effects and impact of caffeine, particularly—as we saw in the case of Alex Watson—when the consequences for an athlete found to have breached those limits are very significant.

The Government supports recommendation No. 3 recommending comprehensive drug briefings for Australian Olympic athletes both at the time of selection and again immediately prior to departure for future Olympic Games. There may be a very significant time lapse between the time of selection and the time of departure and, with so many things on athletes' minds, the fact that drinking coffee could take them over a proscribed level may slip from the front of their brains. So we recommended that the athletes be reminded of this fact prior to departing for the Olympic Games, wherever they may be. Indeed, they will not have to depart for them, if they are held in Sydney. We are pleased that the Government supports that recommendation because of a concern by the Committee that natural justice be done in providing for our athletes.

The Government has noted recommendation No. 4 and tells us that it has also brought it to the AOC's attention. The Committee recommended that comprehensive procedures should be formulated to deal with the case when an Australian athlete is found on testing to have breached the drug levels or the IOC drug rules at the Olympic Games; that all Australian athletes should be provided with a copy of those procedures; and that there should be an appropriately qualified advocate for any Australian athlete infringing the IOC drug rules.

Much was learnt by the Committee in examining what happened to Alex Watson, who was the first Australian athlete to breach those rules. It was quite clear that the AOC did not have comprehensive procedures in place at the time. We appreciate that the situation has changed since, but we also think it is important to have recommended—and we are pleased that the Government notes this—that that kind of procedure be in place for athletes, again as a matter of natural justice.

The recommendation that Australian athletes found to have breached drug guidelines be penalised in accordance with internationally accepted standards—that is, up to three months ban for inadvertent use, two years for a first offence, and a life ban for any subsequent offence—has been supported by the Government. Again, our Committee made this recommendation because it was very clear that to give a first offender, as Alex Watson was, a life ban was extraordinarily severe, particularly given the internationally accepted stepped levels of penalty.

We recommend that that stepped series of penalties be introduced and applied to any future Australian athletes found to have breached drug guidelines. The Government supports that position. This is something that the AOC and Australia have learnt as a consequence of what happened to Alex Watson. Recommendation 5 states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian Sports Commission comment in its annual reports on positive drug tests by prominent Australian athletes and the procedures established to deal with them.

The Government's response is to support this recommendation in principle. Sports drug definitions and procedures are still in their infancy. Therefore it is very important that the organisations or institutions with a responsibility in this area provide as much information as possible. Firstly, there is a need to assist the community to recognise whether there is a problem and, if so, make recommendations to deal with it. Secondly, we need to know whether the process established in Australia—which is one of the leading processes in the world—is dealing with the difficulties in a very fair and satisfactory manner. So it is interesting to note that the Government supports this recommendation in principle.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether we give too many directions to organisations or departments about what should be in the substantive parts of their annual reports. I would have thought that it is not unreasonable, given the early days of the drug and sport establishments in Australia, that we should expect a report about that from the Australian Sports Commission. The Australian Sports Commission can also report on any other matters related to drugs in sport in Australia.

The Government also responded to the recommendations in the minority report. The recommendation for detailed research, which is not too different from the recommendation in the Committee's report, is supported by the Government. Recommendation 2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the AOC provide a thoroughly detailed and comprehensive drug briefing for Australian olympic athletes—
This recommendation is also supported. Recommendation 3 states:
That the Australian Olympic Committee appoint an independent Sports Drug Tribunal to hear disputed cases of positive drug tests and to facilitate any appeals to international authorities.
That recommendation is noted and it has been brought to the attention of the Australian Olympic Committee. Recommendation 4 states:
That the AIS rule prohibiting access by (drug) banned athletes be amended to permit assistance to such athletes who may require AIS facilities in order to appeal against positive drug tests.
The Government supports this recommendation. This is, if you like, another piece in the natural justice plank. Recommendation 5 states:
That the AOC:
(i) provide a legal adviser who can assist;
(ii) provide a technical expert;
(iii) formulate comprehensive procedures . . .

This actually itemises and spells out in a little more detail a similar recommendation in the Committee report. The Government notes this recommendation. Again, the Government supports the recommendation that there be a staged level of penalty for drug offenders in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I will not go through all of the recommendations. I am quite sure that Senator Crichton-Browne will pick up on them. Recommendation 7 states:

SPEECH.PARA: That Caffeine in any concentration in the urine be proscribed.
That an appeal against the findings of Caffeine in a sample could be based on inadvertent use and that a level for inadvertency be set.

This recommendation is not supported. So the Government, I suppose, is in some ways consistent. It does not support proscribing caffeine and it does not support setting levels. Again, the Government argues that it will not support those recommendations while research to establish more accurately the facts about caffeine and its influence on athletes is being carried out.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that the Government has found this a useful report. It has assisted to finetune some of the procedures, particularly for our athletes at Olympic Games. Even as a matter of natural justice, those things are properly and well advised to be done. One very great concern of the Committee is our difficulty in this place, for example, in making recommendations which ask the AOC to require the IOC to do things. We know from the IOC's response to our Committee that we have very little expectation of anything changing at the IOC level.

In one way, there is almost an arrogance to disregard the matters of concern that have been raised by this Committee, particularly the Committee's concern about justice being done to athletes in the testing process, in terms of the possibility of an appeal against the results and in dealing with the athletes by providing sufficient information both beforehand and afterwards. These are matters of very grave concern which go, as I said earlier, to the livelihood of and lifelong consequences for the athletes. They should be very seriously taken up by the IOC. So far, it seems that that is not the case.

Australia is in a difficult situation. We are at the forefront, if not the leader, in the area of testing for drugs in sport. We are certainly at the forefront in terms of random testing between games, world performances, athletic meets, carnivals and so on, and we are certainly at the forefront in terms of procedures and processes to assist both the athletes and the testing. If the rest of the world does not keep up with Australia or if Australia gets too far in front, we will put all our athletes and competitors at a very distinct disadvantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I note Senator Crichton-Browne's support. I am quite sure that he will spell out the issue even more. We cannot really ask Australian athletes to train to peak condition and to give their all in any kind of performance when they know that they are competing against people who are cheating by taking drugs in order to assist in that process.

PARA.TAB: It is untenable to say to any performer, `Do your best, knowing that it won't be good enough', particularly when we live in a world that places very great store on gold medals and any medal ahead of even attempting to participate. One has only to look at the consequences for the athletes who return from major sporting events, such as the Olympics. Those who get gold medals are very differently recognised, acknowledged and supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —They all got a gold car.

—Exactly. Benefits flow to them. If a number of Australians were asked to remember the names of the gold medallists, they would have a go at answering—some gold medallists are reasonably well known; some have become national heroines and heroes—but it would be extraordinarily difficult for them to recite the litany of silver medallists, while bronze medallists are very often forgotten.

PARA.TAB: While on the one hand we say that it is wonderful to have even been chosen to represent the country—a view I might say that I hold—on the other hand it is very hard to convince athletes that we really mean that when, if they do not get anywhere, we have headlines such as, `Australia fails: no gold today'. We do not celebrate much for athletes if they only achieve a bronze medal. To those who win silver medals, we say, `What a pity you didn't try harder'.

We say to people who want to get the gold medal—that is, to be the peak acknowledged performer—`Well, you can go out and bust your gut for Australia, but you don't stand a chance because many of the other competitors are on drugs. We know that the testing procedures are so insufficient that they can do this and get away with it'. It is not fair to say that to Australian athletes or to any athlete. I sincerely hope that the AOC takes the recommendations of this report and very strongly argues for, and hopefully can negotiate, changes with the IOC so that the fairness that we are trying to apply in Australia is applied across the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, Senator Crowley, in speaking to the Government's response to the report by the Committee on the circumstances surrounding the positive drug test of Mr Alex Watson. I start by observing that this response is to the final report of that Committee euphemistically known as the `Committee into Drugs in Sport'. It was an inquiry that began some years ago and, as a consequence of these reports, particularly the first two, there has been a profound effect upon athletes and sports officials within Australia.

PARA.TAB: The main manifest consequence of the findings of those reports has been the passing by this Parliament of legislation setting up the Australian Sports Drug Agency. The purpose of that legislation in setting up that agency was to provide and put in place a statutory body whose functions and responsibilities were to establish and implement a drug testing regime in Australia. The effect of that legislation and of ASDA has been to ensure, as far as possible, that all elite athletes are, by and large, drug free and compete on their merits.

A further and perhaps more important long term effect has been to change the ethos and culture in Australia towards drug taking in sport. Until some years ago, there has been the view that taking performance enhancing drugs was legally wrong, but morally right; that, because the overwhelming majority of athletes at elite level took performance enhancing drugs in one form or another, it was appropriate for everybody else to take them—and that in itself was to create the even playing field. I think it is now clearly understood and accepted by Australian athletes that to take performance enhancing drugs is to cheat upon their fellow athletes and to seek to take an unfair and distinct advantage.

I have been in the Parliament for some 12 years now and I have served on a number of committees in that time. This particular reference, given to the Committee, of course, by the Senate, is perhaps the most difficult reference I have ever had to deal with. Seeking the truth, honesty and the facts from vested and entrenched interests was extraordinarily difficult. There was no greater objection and difficulty created by anybody than by sports officials. I thought I knew something about the politics of political parties but, having now had some insight into the politics of sport in Australia, I am sure that the latter is played with much more vigour and dedication—and to the death!

From memory, there was not one sport whose officials were prepared to concede or accept that drugs were a problem for that particular sport. Having said that, let me say that it was the professional sports which were the first to acknowledge the prospects of inherent and intrinsic risks and promptly, expeditiously and very effectively set up arrangements to ensure that their athletes were competing cleanly and honestly. Those athletes—both retired and contemporary—who gave honest and frank evidence of their own drug use and drug use by other competitors were vilified, first of all by sports officials and then, to a lesser extent, by other athletes.

I can give honourable senators one or two examples. When the Committee identified the personal cheating of one favoured Australian Institute of Sport athlete, who had been living on taxpayers' funds by way of scholarships for nine years at the AIS, a campaign of cover-up and vilification was waged against the Committee. A senior sporting official directly involved in that conspiracy to cheat was described by his contemporary senior officials as committing a potential error of judgment.

Several senior sporting officials lied in writing to the Committee. One senior sports official in particular in Australia was so outraged by the exposure of the truth by the Committee that in his rather stupid and naive way he publicly announced through the media that he would have the Prime Minister close down the Committee. That shows his understanding of the political system in Australia and how vastly different it clearly is from that of sports politics in Australia.

One senior sporting official, who also happens to be a lawyer, made a contribution in the form of a comment about the urine substitution incident relating to Jane Flemming. He told the world through the media that technically no offence had been committed. Of course, no offence had been committed because at that point nobody had imagined that people would take somebody else's urine and proffer it as their own for tests to demonstrate that they were honest when, of course, they were cheating the whole time.

Nobody at that time had imagined that women were using condoms filled with urine and placed in their vaginas so that when they were tested after competing they were found to have clean urine. Nobody had imaged at that point that athletes were prepared to empty their own bladders before competing and have their bladders filled with somebody else's urine by using catheters.

Those are the sorts of things that had not been imagined when officials were writing the rules. This pompous lawyer-official was boasting to the world that Jane Flemming had not committed any technical offence. One wonders what chance there was of having athletes conduct themselves honestly on the basis that they were unlikely at that stage to be detected for cheating. Their honesty very much depended upon their own integrity.

There was no observation of immorality on the part of the official, only to say that technically no offence had been committed. The incident was covered up and it still would be were it not for the fact that it was exposed to the Committee, much to the chagrin of the vast majority of those officials who knew about it or were directly involved.

The Committee very quickly learnt that the challenge was not to educate the athletes of Australia that cheating was wrong, but to educate the coaches and officials that cheating was wrong. The ethos amongst officials seemed to be that cheating was not wrong; the sin was to get caught cheating. That is still the ethos and mentality that prevails at Olympic level. When people talk about a drug-free Olympic Games, they are talking about an Olympic Games where nobody tests positive; not that they are clean, but they have not been proved to be dirty.

The responsibility of coaches and officials needs to be understood. Many of the young people who are now becoming elite athletes are aged 12 years and upwards. These coaches and officials have their health, welfare and, in some cases, their lives in their hands and they have an onerous and heavy responsibility.

By and large, the effect of ASDA flowing from the Committee has been to ensure that the overwhelming majority of Australian athletes compete honesty and fairly. The other side effect has been to ensure that they are grossly disadvantaged to the extent that they are clean when they compete internationally with dirty overseas athletes.

For instance, Darren Clark ran fourth at the Seoul Olympics. Who would remember that? If my memory serves me correctly, the three athletes who ran ahead of him have all since been detected for drug abuse. We have a heavy and onerous responsibility to ensure that we do not condone this cruel inequality.

I make it clear, particularly to one or two officials, that I propose to continue to campaign to have the IOC accept responsibility for out-of-competition testing. Until the IOC accepts this responsibility, drug abuse will continue to flourish. The IOC is the only international body with the status, the standing and the funding to enable it to set standards and enforce them and to ensure that athletes play by the rules. If the IOC were to ban cheats from competing at future Olympics, it would be a very sobering sanction on those athletes.

I have no intention at all of standing by and watching our athletes compete with little or no prospect of winning, knowing that they are clean and the rest of the world is dirty and saying, `That is not our responsibility; that is not our problem. Our responsibility ended when we cleaned up our own act in our own country'. In this day and age we have athletes who give the better part of their lives to that gut wrenching, cruel agony of hours and hours of daily training. We have an obligation to ensure that they compete fairly and equally with the rest of the world.

Who amongst us did not turn on our television sets to watch the swimming at the last Olympics? We saw our girls and some of our men fall well behind the field. On one occasion a Chinese girl appeared on the scene who had all the obvious symptoms of human growth hormones. She won the gold medal. The official supervising the pool was a Chinese official and his athlete was not tested. The gold medal winner was not tested. But the Australians were tested. There is a very good reason for testing Australians: one knows they are clean; it makes the statistics look good. But when someone is patently, obviously at risk, they are not tested. It was only after much agitation and public comment by Australian officials that all the athletes started to be tested and were put on an even playing field.

I turn for a moment to the Watson report. It has been a very difficult period for Mr Watson. He was quite improperly found to have cheated by ingesting 14.25 micrograms per millilitre of caffeine. He was humiliated, driven out of the Olympics Village and sent home to Australia. Notwithstanding attempts, for a very long time, to have that ban overturned and to have the axiomatic ban placed by the AOC overturned, he was unsuccessful in his endeavours until public disquiet caused circumstances to change.

I acknowledge the contribution of Mr Coates, the President of the Australian Olympic Committee, in putting into place a proper appeals mechanism, a proper tribunal and proper arrangements to see that athletes in Australia are provided with every opportunity to demonstrate their innocence. It is a pity that there are certain officials in Australia who continue to sink with the Titanic in defending their own previous failings.

The IOC has not learnt. It still has absolutely no appeals mechanism. If an athlete's samples A and B test positive, he is provided with no written notice of his offence. He is given no formal notice of a period in which to allow him to prepare a defence. The matters are usually dealt with within a matter of hours. There is no automatic legal representation; there is no separation of responsibilities between those who make a finding and those who impose the penalty; and there is no separate appeals mechanism. In Mr Watson's case, some of his golden years were destroyed because of this situation.

I wish to talk about the role of government in sport. To the extent that we give about $70m or $80m a year—in many respects we have socialised sport in Australia—we all have a responsibility to ensure that taxpayers' funds are acquitted properly and responsibly. This inquiry has, by and large, been conducted by this Committee in a non-partisan way. In my view, sport ought to be apolitical and ought not be used by parliamentarians to the advantage of one political party and the disadvantage of the other or for the crude object of obtaining votes to the disadvantage of athletes.

Athletes want an assurance from government and the sports Minister that when they go onto the track to compete, every opportunity is given to them to compete on an even playing field. They do not want twitty, dilly speeches, obsequiously ingratiating and designed for political purposes, invariably not having been written, never mind having previously been read, by the Minister in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I like the word `obsequiously'.

—It is very interesting to watch Prime Ministers and Ministers when they are with sportsmen and women. They seem to develop an ingratiating and obsequious style and manner. I do not want to be political about this, but I often think about Bob Hawke when he is around Greg Norman. He seems to get even shorter, but in his own way he is all the more puffed up like a little blowfish. Or if Ministers are at the tennis and rubbing shoulders with Pat Cash or whoever the contemporary of the day is, it seems to give them a permeating glow, as if the adulation awarded the athlete is in some way radiating onto the member of parliament and advantaging him politically. As I said, sport should not be political.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I propose to continue to campaign in the face of some sort of undercurrent by certain officials determined to ensure that their conduct is justified and what they wish will be. If I had a choice of being able to influence whether Australian athletes went to the next Olympic Games competing on an even playing field or competing in Sydney on an uneven playing field, I would vote the former every time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't recommend China, would you?

—China's reputation for drug use is not particularly attractive at the moment. There are a lot of complications in respect of China but they are matters that can be addressed properly by the IOC. One of the difficulties with having impartial second country teams testing some of these athletes is in being able to identify them. With 1.25 billion people, it has been put that they could serve up Mr X and say he was Mr Y and he could continue to test clean every single time, but we would have the wrong athlete. Identification is a very real problem in some of these countries.

PARA.TAB: I am not suggesting that the Olympics should be held in Beijing; I argue they should be held in Sydney. But I am saying that if it got down to a choice of ensuring—because of the conduct of Australian officials—that all athletes, like Australian athletes, were clean and that meant we lost the bid, I would put my hand up for that any time rather than gagging and ensuring, for short term political expediency, that the games are held here but they are dirty games like all the rest have been thus far. I hope that will not be a choice.

I hope that I do not find myself, over the next months, when IOC officials will be coming out to Australia to be wined, dined and looked after, and persuaded that we are the place, lobbying them to give Australian athletes a fair go. I hope that when our officials are talking to them, and telling them what a wonderful country we have and why ours is the bid, they also say that the IOC executive is the only body in the world that can guarantee our athletes a fair go. I hope our officials are lobbying those IOC officials. I hope that I do not have to do it, but I will if I have to.

I hope that our sports officials take their responsibilities seriously. I hope that Australia does not continue to be the only country in the world—save in some respects for New Zealand and Canada—which has a legitimate drug testing agency and regime. Otherwise we will find ourselves continually competing internationally against American track and field athletes who are dirty. Everybody knows they are dirty but, because we are playing the game, we shut up about it.

I hope that this Government and the senior sports officials of Australia have got the guts, the commitment and the courage to go overseas and wage a campaign to clean up drugs in sport, as they have done in Australia. If they do not, they have done a grave disservice to our athletes—save for the health of the athletes—by cleaning up drugs in sport in Australia. It would be grossly unfair, having forced Australian athletes and officials to clean up their act, for us to do nothing, for political reasons, about drugs in sport past the borders of Australia.

I conclude by observing that most of the recommendations of the minority report, of which I was a signatory, have been accepted by the Government. Those that have not been accepted have been referred to the AOC, which is the proper body to deal with them, save for one which, in some respects, goes to the heart of the problem. The proposal of the minority report was that caffeine be a proscribed substance. The reason I argued that was because scientific evidence has now been provided that one can breach the proscribed level of 12 micrograms per millilitre by consuming two or three cups of coffee over 24 hours.
Senator Knowles interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If one drinks enough coke. One can inadvertently breach the limit with two or three cups of coffee. Caffeine is not like drugs of another nature which have a more precise effect, it varies according to people's metabolisms. There is a whole range of factors that influence levels in relation to consumption of caffeine. It is particularly dangerous and unfair to have a proscribed level of 12 micrograms per millilitre, because some people can reach that level with two cups of coffee whereas others can take 10 cups.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the sensible thing to do is to proscribe it completely. Then, as occurs with the ratio between testosterone and epi-testosterone and with some drugs in the category of cold tablets, such as ephedrine, there is a limit which is considered to be inadvertent. If caffeine is proscribed completely and an athlete tests positive, he can appeal on the grounds of it being inadvertent. If his range is so low that it is clearly inadvertent—and so low that, of course, it would have no performance enhancing effect—then there would be no penalty. That recommendation was rejected by the Government—for reasons which are not clear to me; although I take it, it would have taken advice from somewhere else—because it is all too hard. The response to this recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: Proscribing any level of Caffeine in the urine would create many difficulties for testing agencies. If this were to be enforced, it would inevitably lead to a vast increase in the number of athletes testing positive through inadvertent use of Caffeine, and therefore create an unnecessary drain on the limited resources of testing agencies.

That is the whole point. We get to the point where we say that a little cheating is all right because to impose the proper discipline would unnecessarily drain the limited resources. It seems a poor old excuse for not doing it properly. If, as with ephedrine and other drugs, we are able to have mechanisms to cope with inadvertency, there is no reason why we cannot have them for caffeine.

PARA.TAB: If it is argued that caffeine is a normal social drink and, therefore, is not normally illegal, and one would expect athletes to take it, athletes will have to do what they do with other substances which are bad for them when they are training or exercising or when they are competing: they will just have to stop taking it. If athletes stop having a normal intake of caffeine through the normal processes, there will not be any problems. Athletes who inadvertently pick it up by eating chocolate or drinking Coca-Cola—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or tea.

—Yes, tea—to a lesser extent than coffee, but certainly in tea: if a level is detected, it would be ignored. If it comes within that category where it is obvious the athlete has had a very small intake, the testing officials would say, and put it down immediately to the fact, `It is clear that he has had a cup of coffee or has eaten a bar of chocolate'. They would ignore it. That does not seem to be a problem. It is only when one gets past that level that the testing official would then deem the athlete to have tested positive.

PARA.TAB: Athletes are not positive automatically because they have breached the proscribed level. They have to be deemed to be positive. It is a deliberate, affirmative action. I see no reason for doing that. At this very moment Alex Watson, who did nothing more than socially drink coffee but who was banned from the Olympic Games, in the eyes and according to the level of law of the International Olympic Committee is still guilty because it does not happen to have an appeals mechanism. All he did was have a few cups of coffee on the day of the competition. If it wants to ensure fairness and ensure that athletes do not cheat, it will put mechanisms such as this in place.

But to get the IOC to do these things is not easy. It can spend $50m on a museum in Lucerne; it does not give one single dollar for out-of-competition testing. There are nations in the world that cannot afford it, to start with, but the reason I am arguing that the IOC ought to fund it is that it makes hundreds of millions of dollars out of the Olympic Games these days. It should set up these testing regimes around the world and say, `If any athlete tests positive, he or she is banned from the next Olympic Games'. That would soon put a stop to it, but for reasons best known to the Olympic movement it refuses to do so. As long as it is left to international sporting bodies, there will not be the will, the commitment and, in many cases, the resources. I support the government response, save for the Government's failure to support the recommendation that really mattered—that caffeine be proscribed completely.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to Special Report No. 1 of the Joint Committee on Migration Regulations, and I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: MINISTER FOR IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

SPEECH.PARA: PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Dr Andrew Theophanous MP
Chairman
Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Dr Theophanous
I refer to Special Report No. 1 of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations which was tabled in both Houses of the Parliament on 5 September 1991.

As you are aware, the Report comprises two letters to me in which the Committee raises matters arising from its inquiries about the migration regime. The attachment to this letter apprises the Committee of recent developments in relation to the Government's processing of refugee claimants.

The Committee's letter of 15 August 1991, which comprises Part B of the Report, raises several issues where the Committee has identified what, in its view, are unintended injustices under the Migration Regulations. The attachment to this letter sets out the Government's response to each issue raised by the Committee in the Report.
I should be grateful if you would thank the Committee for bringing these matters to my attention.
Yours sincerely
Gerry Hand
JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS
SPECIAL REPORT No. 1
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE

The Committee expressed concern that undocumented arrivals may be held in detention for lengthy periods before their applications are submitted. The Committee made several recommendations in relation to the implementation of strict time limits in which applications should be made, including:
(a)that undocumented arrivals at the border be required to submit a written notice of intention to apply for refugee status within 48 hours;
(b)claimants be required to submit full applications within 28 days of date of arrival, with a possible extension of 28 days in appropriate circumstances;
(c)the Government provide increased assistance to organisations such as Legal Aid Commissions and Refugee Advice and Casework Services in order for applicants to meet the proposed deadlines;
(d)border claimants be given priority in the assessment of applications;
(e)that the initial determination of a border claimant's application be made within three months and priority be given to the determination of any appeals from border claimants.

On 12 February 1992 the Government announced new measures to improve processing of refugee claimants and, in particular, expedite the process of applications made by those claimants who are in custody.

These measures include the introduction of time limits within which a person may apply for recognition of refugee status. The onus will be placed on a claimant to make an application and respond to requests for further information within a set time-frame.
Border claimants and others who are arrested and detained as illegal entrants will be given priority and processed within approximately two months.

Amendments were recently made to the Migration Act to require undocumented asylum seekers who arrived by boat, or arrive by boat up to 30 November 1992, to be detained in custody until their claims are resolved. These Amendments also encourage claimants to cooperate in the processing of their applications as the length of custody will be affected by delays in presentation of information.

The Amendments are an interim measure to ensure integrity of Australia's border while the Government explores further legislative possibilities for strengthening the Government's ability to respond to legal challenges to the refugee determination process, whilst maintaining current standards of fairness and equity. Further amendments of a long term nature are expected in the 1992 Budget Session.
The issue of Government assistance to organisations such as Legal Aid Commissions and Refugee Advice and Casework Services is currently being considered.
The following matters were raised by the Committee in relation to the operation of the Migration Regulations:

The Committee expressed concern that in many cases where a person has become an illegal entrant following lodgement of an application for review but before the time of the review hearing, that person's chances of meeting the criteria for grant of an entry permit are extremely limited due to their illegal status. The Committee believes that this has resulted in section 121 of the Migration Act 1958, which allows the Immigration Review Tribunal to adjourn the review hearing to permit the person to apply for other entry permits, not operating as it was intended.

The Committee has recommended that the regulations be amended so that a person applying for a further temporary entry permit is also taken to apply for a processing entry permit. The processing entry permit should cover the time up to the final determination of the review or, where no review has been sought, the expiry of the time in which to seek review.

The Government's policy, as implemented by the Migration Regulations, is that persons who become illegal entrants should have limited access to regularising their status. This is regardless of whether or not review has been sought.

Review rights are provided to ensure that the correct and preferable decision is made on the application under review. These review rights are not intended to bestow any benefit on an applicant that is not directly related to the review process.

The aggregation power is intended to exhaust an applicant's potential claims by an aggregation or accumulation of such claims, to prevent an applicant extending his or her stay in Australia by making a series of further applications.

Section 121 permits the review authority to identify for the applicant real possibilities for obtaining another entry permit of which the applicant may have been unaware, whilst ensuring that further applications may not be made at will. The section operates within the framework of the Government's policy.
The Government notes the Committee's concerns, which are being examined in the context of the review of the merit review system.

The Committee, while endorsing the policy behind the balance of family test, has expressed concern that it appears to create an injustice in certain cases, such as where the step-children of sole parents or the estranged children of a partner are counted against the parent applicant.
The Committee has recommended that regulation 38 of the Migration Regulations be amended so that:

PARA.TAB: (i)the step-children of a widowed, separated or divorced parent, or
(ii)the estranged children of the spouse of a principal applicant,
are not counted against the parent applicant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the Committee's endorsement of the policy which has given rise to the Balance of Family (BOF) Test and the Committee's wish not to undermine the controls in this class. However, the Committee has also expressed the view that the test results in an injustice and operates harshly in circumstances which are set out in the report.

It is necessary to consider the Committee's comments in the context of the objectives of the policy. The BOF Test was introduced to tighten the former generous entry concessions for parents which had resulted in growing numbers being approved for entry, evidenced by a 43% increase in the three years from 1983/84 to 1987/88. The decision to introduce the test was also made in recognition that parents make a heavy demand on public health and welfare services. This cost is harder to justify when there are stronger family links overseas than in Australia. Further, settlement experience indicates that there is less likelihood of family breakdown and reliance on the social welfare system where parents are located with the balance of their children.

The BOF Test has been constructed to operate as impartially as possible across a wide variety of cultural backgrounds. For this reason the test is concerned only with the numeric and geographical disposition of the children of the applicant, the applicant's spouse and former partners of either. It is independent of the social values of the applicant, the relative economic position of the children and the quality of the relationship between parents and their children.
Scope for variation of the test is limited if the intention of curtailing numbers and consequent costs is to be preserved.
The Committee has recommended that the Minister amend the Balance of Family Regulation to provide that the following children are not counted against the applicant for the purpose of the BOF Test:

PARA.TAB: (i)the step-children of a widowed, separated or divorced parent; and,
(ii)the estranged children of the spouse of a principal applicant.

SPEECH.PARA: In the cases described in the Attachment to the Special Report No. 1, the recommendations would have a beneficial effect, that is, they would assist the applicant in meeting the BOF Test. However, such recommendations would work against parents who have step-children or temporarily estranged children in Australia who may benefit from the Regulation remaining as it is.

An issue raised by recommendation (ii) is that the quality of relationships is not easy to assess, particularly within a family unit. A relationship that is estranged may previously have been, or become, under changed conditions, close and nurturing, and may at times be again estranged. It cannot be assumed that a step-parent child relationship discontinues or weakens after death, divorce or other separations as the Committee's recommendations would imply.
The Government does not accept that in all circumstances described by the Committee applicants who have failed the BOF Test have been treated harshly or suffered an injustice.

The case studies which have been summarised in the Discussion Paper accompanying the Report in support of the Committee's proposals feature a combination of family circumstances unique to those cases. The three parent cases which have been approved through the exercise of Ministerial power of intervention under Section 115 and Section 137 to set aside the BOF Test also presented exceptional claims which contributed to the final positive outcomes.

The Migration Act provisions for Ministerial intervention in cases which present unusual, unforseen or other features that are deserving of a favourable response would seem to encompass the particularly compelling circumstances envisaged by the Committee in making these recommendations in relation to the BOF provisions.

The Committee has highlighted what it believes are injustices stemming from cases in the extended eligibility (family) category. The Committee believes that it is inappropriate to require aged-dependent, remaining, special need or orphan relatives to apply overseas. It has recommended that the requirement in regulation 127(a)(iii) of the Migration Regulations that such relatives qualify `as the result of a death or permanent incapacitation' be deleted.

Consistent with the Committee's recommendation, the Migration Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1991 No. 418, deleted the requirement in regulation 127(a)(iii) that aged-dependent, remaining, special need or orphan relatives qualify `as a result of a death or permanent incapacitation'. This amendment came into effect on 26 December 1991.

The Committee has sought advice in relation to how Departmental procedures address situations where minor children who are either Australian citizens or permanent residents arguably have some need for continuing contact with a parent, but that need does not bring that parent within the `special need relative' definition in the Migration Regulations.

The Government notes the Committee's concern with the position of minor children, resident in Australia, who have a need for continuing contact with a divorced parent, but whose need for assistance does not meet the criteria under the Migration Regulations for a "special need" affecting the child.

The Special Need Relative category was introduced as a concessionary category to enable an Australian citizen or permanent resident to sponsor a relative for migration where that relative is willing and able to give substantial, continuing assistance to the citizen or permanent resident in circumstances of special need. These circumstances are defined as a permanent or long-term need for assistance because of death, disability, prolonged illness or other serious circumstances affecting the citizen or permanent resident personally, or a member of his or her family unit. The definition also requires that the assistance cannot reasonably be obtained from any other Australian relative or welfare, hospital, nursing or community services in Australia.

The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is not able to provide figures on the number and incidence of cases with the Campbell case profile. As the Committee has identified, in these circumstances, the child's need for contact with, and support from, the divorced parent falls outside the interpretation of the meaning of "special need" contemplated by subparagraph 2(1) of the Regulations. The Government considers that in these circumstances a child's needs for parenting are not well covered by the term "assistance". The period of a child's greatest needs for access to both parents is also, of course, not permanent, nor in many cases long-term. Policy guidelines specifically exclude from approval within this category applications based primarily on love and affection and the wish to be reunited with relatives in Australia. Also excluded are applicants who seek solely to provide assistance with child care, financial, emotional or moral support and companionship.

The Committee was undecided whether such cases can be appropriately dealt with under the Minister's residual discretion or whether fine tuning of the Special Need Relative Regulation is required. The Government considers that no fine tuning of this Regulation is warranted based on the issues raised for the Committee by the Campbell case and similar cases which have been brought to the Committee's attention. Such circumstances would be more appropriately handled via the Parent migration visa class which provides for the sponsorship of a parent/s by a minor, or where appropriate, by the exercise of Section 115 and Section 137 Ministerial discretion.
The Committee has expressed concern about the complexity of the scheme and that many changes to the Migration Regulations have created new problems or compounded existing ones.
The Committee has recommended all future changes be implemented with proper care, attention to the wider context of the changes and with timely deliberation.

The Government notes the Committee's concerns and agrees that the structure of the Migration Regulations is unduly complex. To address this problem, the Regulations are currently being restructured into a "recipe-card" format so that all the criteria, conditions and fees applying to each class of entry permit and visa are easily accessible.
The Government notes the Committee's recommendation and endorses the continuing need for changes to the Regulations to be implemented with care and attention to the wider context.

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTER FOR IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Senator Brian Harradine
Senator for Tasmania
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator

I refer to the issue you raised in the course of debate on the Migration Reform Bill 1992 on 10 December 1992 on the subject of access of the Cambodian boat people to humanitarian consideration. I am writing to confirm the position outlined by Senator Tate in response to your questions on the issue, namely that under the present Act and Regulations persons who make unauthorised entry to Australia do not have such access.

The procedures currently in place for allowing refugee applicants access to humanitarian consideration are complex. They rely on a power of the Minister to grant individuals an entry permit, in this case a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit, in spite of the fact that criteria for that permit may not have been met, in certain exceptional circumstances.

The Migration Act provides that applicants are entitled to be granted an entry permit if they meet the criteria set out in regulations. Conversely, the Minister is specifically enjoined from granting an entry permit where the criteria are not met. There are only two circumstances where the Minister may grant an entry permit to an applicant who does not meet the regulatory criteria. This is when an application for a permit has been rejected either at internal review under section 115 of the Act or by the Immigration Review Tribunal under section 137 of the Act. In that case, the Minister may grant the permit if he or she considers it would be in the public interest to do so.

The current mechanism for allowing some persons rejected for refugee status to stay in Australia on humanitarian grounds makes use of the Minister's powers under section 115. In essence, the Minister grants applicants a domestic protection (temporary) entry permit in spite of the fact that they have been found not to meet an essential criterion for the permit, namely that they have been determined to be a refugee. The key point is that to access the Minister's powers, an entry permit review application must have been rejected. A refugee status review rejection does not trigger the Minister's section 115 powers. This reflects the fact that at the time section 115 was drafted, refugee status decisions were not formally incorporated in the Act.

The Cambodian boat people are designated persons held in custody under Division 4B of the Migration Act. Previously their status was that of prohibited entrants held under section 88 of the Act. No review rights attach to any entry permit or visa application made by a prohibited entrant or a designated person. As a result, the Minister's powers under section 115 or section 137 cannot be engaged in respect of any such application.

As applicants who have not entered Australia, in the strict legal sense in which the term entry is used in the Act, there are a limited number of visas and entry permits for which the Cambodians can be considered. It would seem that the only permit for which they might qualify is the domestic protection (temporary) entry permit. If the Cambodians are not found to be refugees it is likely that they will not meet the regulatory criteria for any entry permit or visa. If this proves to be the case, neither the Minister nor any officer of the Department will have the power to grant them an entry permit or visa under the law as it presently stands.

In your remarks to the Senate on this issue, you drew attention to the Report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations on Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian System, particularly paragraphs 5.4 and following. In those paragraphs, the Committee outlines its understanding of the operation of the present mechanism for granting humanitarian consideration. Although I cannot, of course, speak for the Committee, I think it would be fair to assume that the paragraphs in question were not intended to be a full and complete description of that mechanism. As it happens, the Committee has quite correctly set out the procedures which apply for the normal case. The Committee apparently did not feel it necessary for the purposes of its report to note that these procedures do not apply in all cases. As noted above, in the case of a designated person or a prohibited entrant, the Minister has no power to accede to a recommendation to grant an entry permit on humanitarian grounds.
I hope that this letter helps to clarify the issues you have raised in relation to this complex and important issue.
Yours sincerely
Gerry Hand

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is clear from that letter that the Minister considers that under the present Act and regulations persons who make unauthorised entry into Australia do not have such access. The first paragraph of the letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the issue you raised in the course of debate on the Migration Reform Bill 1992 on 10 December 1992—
it must have been 8 December—

on the subject of access of the Cambodian boat people to humanitarian consideration. I am writing to confirm the position outlined by Senator Tate in response to your questions on the issue, namely that under the present Act and Regulations persons who make unauthorised entry to Australia do not have such access.

My question was about whether the provisions of the new legislation, taking effect from 1 July 1993, will enable the Minister to exercise the discretion to enable a person to have the benefit of lawful presence in Australia in accordance with humanitarian principles; that is, persons who entered Australia—I use that term not in a legal sense—in the same way as the Cambodian boat people did. I want to make this final point: these individuals entered Australia after coming from a war-torn country. They entered Australia in a traumatised condition. They came from a country not then recognised by Australia. Many of them have been in detention ever since. Some have been in detention for over three years, suffering further trauma and hardship. They are fearful of what might occur to them on their return.

PARA.TAB: I believe that humanitarian considerations should now come into play. The 36 or 37 refugee status applications have finally been refused, notwithstanding that those refugees have been in detention for more than three years. The High Court decision yesterday made it clear that, had these people been properly afforded their rights of appeal to the Federal Court, they would have had the right to have their case heard by the Federal Court as to whether they were unjustly and unfairly detained.

That right was refused by legislation which was pushed through this Parliament two days before the case was to come to court in May. The day before the High Court decision they received their notices from the Minister's delegate that their refugee application had been refused. So the only thing left is for humanitarian considerations to come into play. In this letter the Minister is saying that, under the present Act and regulations, those humanitarian considerations cannot come into play. The Minister does not have a discretion in this matter.

However, I point out to the chamber that the reason why the Minister has no discretion is that this was not included in the May legislation. The people are designated persons and, therefore, once those processes have been finalised, as they have been, the Government has tied the Minister's hands—put him in a straitjacket where he cannot move.

It seems odd that the Minister can now say that he can do nothing about it when it was the Government itself, on the Minister's recommendation, which adopted procedures which ensured that he could do nothing. That was the purpose of my raising the matter yesterday in the hope that these people, like those who will come after them, could at least have the humanitarian considerations applied to them in the event of their failing a refugee status application.

I do not know—and perhaps the Minister might take this on board—whether there is some other way, some other avenue, whereby these humanitarian considerations could come into play. I do not know whether there is some other avenue outside the legislation and the regulations that have been referred to in the Minister's letter. I hope that this is the case. I wish at a later stage to refer to a number of other matters that were contained in the Government's response to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations but, in view of the time, I will not do so now. I thank the Senate for listening to me on this particular occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, will be brief in my comments on the government response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I make a comment in passing on a matter that Senator Harradine has just addressed. PARA.TAB: As a member of the Committee, I welcome the response of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) to the Committee's report.
