SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Industry Commission for 1991-92 is from one of the Government's key economic advisory bodies. It could not be a report more damning of this weary and policy paralysed Government's pathetic performance on micro-economic reform. The stark facts are laid bare by the Commission, which has rightly taken the Government to task over its record on micro-economic reform. The report states on page 11:

The imperative is to act quickly and to tackle reform on a broad front. . . However, in light of what governments must do to lift Australia's economic performance, reform initiatives have been lacking in number and scope.

Yet only last month the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that the `great micro-economic reform agenda' had been almost completed—just one more lie from a man who has turned public misinformation and colourful but empty rhetoric into an art form. The Industry Commission report exposes those vacuous claims by setting down the directly contradictory facts.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senator Short, could you repeat to me what you just mentioned—`misinformation and lies'?

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. I am afraid that I was caught up in another part of the chamber but I think the honourable senator did refer to a member of parliament as being well versed in the art of the lie and misinformation. I do not believe that is parliamentary.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—There has been a fairly free flow of rhetoric. I did not exactly hear all the words, but I understand it did include the words `lie' and `misinformation'. I think you ought to withdraw that, Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did use the word `lie' in relation to the Prime Minister's statement, and accordingly I withdraw. The Industry Commission report exposes those vacuous claims by setting down directly the contradictory facts. I must say that the Government, and in particular the Prime Minister, rarely seem interested in facts nowadays. The report stated the reverse of the Prime Minister's statement. Page 15 states, `Clearly, much more remains to be done'. So much for the Prime Minister's statement that the great micro reform agenda is mostly completed. Quite obviously and quite patently it is not. The report makes it clear that not only is the Government's agenda not broad enough, but also it has let many promised reforms slip, including backtracking by the National Road Transport Commission, increasing assistance for footwear, delayed reforms in the sugar and dairy industries, and many more. The report makes a strong case that, without accelerating the pace of micro-economic reform on a broad front, unemployment will remain at high levels for the rest of the decade, even if growth strengthens, which seems most unlikely given the policy paralysis evident from all in this worn-out Government.

PARA.TAB: There are many other direct criticisms of Government policy in the report. For example, in what can only be seen as a not-so-veiled criticism of the ridiculous training levy to which Labor is committed, but which we will abolish when in government, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The task of upgrading skills and increasing flexibility through training requires broad, comprehensive and far reaching reform . . . Reforms need to lead to an education, training and retraining system sensitive to emerging opportunities for skilled employment.

In other words, one blanket rule for everyone will not suffice. A flexible and sensitive training regime is needed to get people into jobs that will last. The report places labour market reform, the policy which is the biggest `no go' area for this Government, right at the top of its priority list for needed change. On page 11 it is stated:
Much more is to be gained from extending reform . . . particularly removing impediments to the efficient operation of labour markets.
In what could only be interpreted as a direct endorsement of the coalition's industrial relations policy, the report states:
Increased flexibility in wages and conditions would allow current and prospective employees to judge where skill shortages are greatest and where there would be pay-offs to additional training.

The report goes on in like frame. They are the recommendations of the IC. They are also, of course, the Fightback policies which will get Australians back into jobs and back into work. Faced with these facts, the Prime Minister and the Government have decided that they will turn their backs on the only road to real solutions. That is obvious from looking at the last 10 years of hard Labor.

PARA.TAB: If the Government had not wasted years sitting on its hands, if it had been prepared to act on the structural problems which the coalition has spoken of and addressed in its policy reform package, we would not be in this current malaise. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on this Industry Commission report and draw attention to the fact that, if nothing else, it indicates that the Industry Commission, which replaced the Industries Assistance Commission, is still going down the discredited road of economic rationalism. It was rather interesting to read in today's Canberra Times a report of a statement made by Nugget Coombs who has advised successive governments in the economic area in this country for a long time. Among other things, the article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian society's intellectual and moral basis was being corrupted by economic demands, veteran policymaker and academic H.C. "Nugget" Coombs said . . .
The intellectual and moral basis of Australian society is being corrupted by the subordination of its institutions to the demands of the owners and entrepreneurs of `the economy'.

It seems to me that one of the institutions which have been corrupted by this is no less than the Industry Commission itself. When the Industry Commission was set up, it replaced the Industries Assistance Commission. The Australian Democrats sought by amendment to ensure that this would not happen, by insisting that one of the commissioners be a person with experience in and knowledge of the environment and that environment be a constant reference for the Industry Commission.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, we have to recognise that, with the very rare exception of matters like the report on the fishing industry and the fisheries Bills which we dealt with last year, most of the Industry Commission's reports have very little to do with the matters that are of clear concern to Nugget Coombs. He said that the real job of the economy was to provide for the livelihood of people. One can only say, `Hear, hear!' to Nugget Coombs. It is a great pity that the economists of later generations, as Michael Pusey pointed out, do not have that broad education which Nugget Coombs brought to his job as an adviser to successive governments and as the head of the Reserve Bank for quite a long time.

In this report repeated attention is drawn to the standard of living without qualification, as if the material consumption of individuals equates with standard of living. That runs right through the document. It fails to recognise that material consumption does not equate with standard of living. As per capita GDP in Japan is considerably higher than it is in Australia, one should pose the question: who in Australia would change places with those who are living in Tokyo? Many things need to be taken into account, quite apart from the material standard of living.

Another matter that the Industry Commission totally fails to recognise in its report, despite the fact that it is comprised of these economic rationalists, is that the first step which needs to be taken into account in properly representing prices in the market system is to internalise the externalities; in other words, to put into the cost of production the cost of pollution, the cost of industrial accidents, the cost of occupational health and so on and so forth. Throughout this report there is an overemphasis on the stripping away of all regulations and all taxes. This is precisely the way in which, in a properly run market economy, one would represent those prices so that those people who consume the goods and services which come out at the other end of the productive process get the right price signals.

I am afraid that this report simply confirms again that the Industry Commission is on the wrong track and that it has not learnt anything in the couple of years that it has been in existence. Economic rationalism is discredited. It is about time that the Commission recognised that, as many other countries have already recognised it. For a long time they have pursued interventionist policies. That is now the name of the game. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever anyone gave reasons why the Australian Democrats are out of touch, it was Senator Coulter today. He came in here and criticised the Industry Commission. At no stage in his address did he mention any concern for the unemployed in Australia. The Industry Commission's report is both a sobering and timely report. Let me quote some of the remarks made by the Commission:

SPEECH.PARA: The most pressing economic and social problem in Australia today is unemployment. Over a million Australians are unemployed or too discouraged to look for work. The economic and social cost is enormous.
I am quoting from the Industry Commission report that Senator Coulter came in here and said was discredited. I continue:

High rates of unemployment have persisted for more than a decade, pointing to an underlying structural problem that recovery alone will not solve . . . The bulk of the recent increase in unemployment was caused by the recession, with structural reform playing a relatively minor role.
The report then goes on to say:

Just putting the economy back on its long-term growth path will not be sufficient. Even stronger growth would be needed to ensure that the employment opportunities expanded at a rate sufficient to absorb those currently unemployed, as well as new entrants to the workforce.
The report further states:

PARA.TAB: Without major changes in the way the economy operates, the economic and social waste of unemployment will persist.
Underlying persistent high unemployment is evidence of structural problems.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be remembered that Australia has structural problems. The report says:

Labour markets are not functioning as well as they could . . . Reform of labour markets can raise productivity to support high and rising standards of living and create employment directly. Reform directed to improving the flexibility of wages between industries and occupations, and of work practices, will create jobs in the medium term.

Surely this is the major issue that everyone in this chamber should be addressing. Yet Senator Coulter comes into the Senate and says that what was said by the Industry Commission was discredited. How remote can anyone be?

PARA.TAB: Time and time again in this chamber we have tried to get some idea from the Government as to its policies to correct the misery it induced for Australia. We heard Senator Button say in Question Time today that the Government has consistent policies. We know what that means—more and more of the same. This country cannot afford those sorts of consistent policies. I received a letter from a constituent recently who was very concerned that her son, who has two degrees, was unable to get a job. She said that it was impossible to believe that a land which offered so much for its sons and daughters had sunk into the socialist bog where mediocrity is the norm. That says it all.
Senator Spindler interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop bleating about it. The Democrats have no policies and they want to lead us down the track to more unemployment. Dr Hewson and the coalition have offered a plan to restore the economy—an economy which has collapsed from the policies of this Government. The Government cannot avoid that fact. The Labor Party has been in government for nearly 10 years and its policies have failed. We have something like a million people out of work. The Labor Party has condemned the country to a repetitious cycle of recession, growth and recession again and there is no incentive whatsoever for growth in business. The Labor Party's industrial relations system, as pointed out by the Industry Commission, fails to maximise productivity.

PARA.TAB: The Fightback package offers real incentives to the private sector, the only part of the economy which can create real jobs. Without a growing and viable private sector there is no revenue for schools, roads, education, health and so on. The Fightback package offers a plan. It is the only plan going around at the moment which can restore this economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the second one.
—Don't tell me the Democrats have got a plan! That would have to be the joke of the century. (Time expired)

—I agree with many of the comments that Senator Parer has made. This nation's economy is in desperate need of reform, and it is in desperate need of reform that is going to create jobs for people. It is all about creating jobs for people. There are some people who would argue that we need an interventionist approach to create those jobs, and they are perfectly entitled to have that view. But the danger with that view is that, basically, it is a case of picking winners. Those people are saying, `We will go to the races with your money, we are going to put your money on some of the nags out there and we are hoping that we can pick the winners'. Of course picking winners never works.

PARA.TAB: I think this is a very dangerous path to take because, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President—although I understand you are not a gambling man yourself—there are many who are gambling people and rarely do they end up more profitable at the end of the day than they were at the beginning, because picking winners is a very difficult task. What we are saying in the coalition is very simple: the best way to create jobs is to create jobs in the private sector by policies that improve profitability.

My quibble with the Industry Commission is very simple. Sometimes I think the Industry Commission is too willing to reallocate the profits of some of our struggling primary industries. For example, when they take money off the sugar industry and recommend the abolition of price pooling in the sugar industry, or an end to assignments, there is a very real financial cost to the people who have to bear it. What we believe in the National Party, quite simply, is this: this country does need reform, but it needs reform in an intelligent way which is going to take into consideration the fact that there are certain industries where all the benefits of the so-called reforms that are advocated by the Industry Commission will not flow to this country but will flow to consumers overseas.

For example, if one were to accept the recommendations of the Industry Commission—the National Party does not, in so far as sugar is concerned, and the coalition has given a commitment not to implement the Industry Commission report regarding sugar, because it is flawed—about abolishing the export powers of the Queensland Sugar Corporation, we would throw away the advantage to Australian producers of having one export seller for sugar. Instead, we would pit something like 1,600 sugar farms up and down the east coast of Australia against each other, selling to three multinational buyers. At the same time, we need to recognise the fact that those international buyers—such as Tate and Lyle, for example—have become quite fat on the subsidies that they have received from EC sugar production, so they are definitely in a position to exert enormous power over Australian producers.

As far as the Industry Commission report is concerned, we are saying: yes, we do need those reforms, and we need them urgently. But we need to ask ourselves: who is going to get the benefit of the reforms? If those reforms are going to lead to lower prices for Australian producers, to benefit being passed overseas and not retained in Australia, when this country is struggling in the grip of a recession into which this Government has thrown this nation, obviously we have to seriously question whether those ideas are correct.

I suppose the real acid test as far as the Industry Commission is concerned is this: if the Industry Commission has its way, who on the Commission is willing to tie their income to the income of cane growers over the next 10 years? It is very easy, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you well know, to sit in Canberra and make recommendations, but it is the people who have to live with the consequences of those recommendations and who know the real price—just as the people who have lived with the consequences of this Labor Government's failed economic policies know the real price. The people who are unemployed know the real price, and the people who have been bankrupted by high interest rates which this Government subjected us to know the real price. It is only those opposite who make the recommendations, who do not have to live with the consequences, and who never see the human face of recession in Australia, who are oblivious to the pain that is being caused in this country now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address briefly the 1991-92 annual report of the Industry Commission. Let me comment equally briefly on the case put forward by Senator Parer who was waxing lyrical about the work of the Industry Commission. What he left out of sight is that the current Government's policies, which have resulted in a million unemployed, have actually been based on the advice of the Industry Commission. I wonder whether Senator Parer has realised that the advice coming out of the Industry Commission was based purely and solely on financial considerations. It did not take into account social consequences, it did not take into account cultural consequences and it did not take into account environmental consequences.

PARA.TAB: I wish to address a particular aspect of this report, but before I do let me just agree with what Senator O'Chee said. If the report by the Industry Commission on the sugar industry were implemented in total the effects would be calamitous. Another report, the dairy industry report, suggested that the whole 13 per cent in support given to the dairy industry should be removed totally. If that happened, thousands of dairy farmers in western Victoria and East Gippsland—Victoria has 90 per cent of Australia's dairy industry—would have had to walk off the farms. Fortunately—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not walk off.

—Or they would have been pushed off. Fortunately, that report of the Industry Commission was not accepted in its totality. Rather, a much more scaled down version of industry assistance was negotiated with dairy farmers. We still have, as a result of that, a dairy industry in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is a proposal that the Industry Commission actually have an inquiry into public housing. That suggestion fills me with trepidation, because if the Industry Commission follows its usual method of operation—of looking at efficiency only, of looking at financial factors only and not taking account of the social consequences—we will finish up with a report that is a total waste of money on the one hand and which would be quite destructive were it ever to be implemented on the other. This statement says that the Industry Commission is to look at the management, allocation and rental of publicly provided housing. It is going to look at public rental housing, community housing, crisis accommodation, emergency relief and, last but not least, housing for Aboriginal people. If the Industry Commission applies nothing but its normal standards of financial efficiency, I fear for the social priorities. I fear for the client groups which need to be looked at in terms of their priorities. How will the Industry Commission take account of priorities in terms of the money that is to be spent on public housing? I believe that it is the last body that should be looking at the provision of public housing in Australia.

If the Industry Commission is to be asked to look at the financial aspect, then we need a parallel inquiry that looks at the priorities of the groups that are in need of public housing. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a couple of comments on the Industry Commission report because it seems to me that the Industry Commission, in the way it has operated and in the framework of thinking within which it is operated, is very much representative of some of the mistakes we made in the 1980s and which I believe the Liberals, with their Fightback proposals, are about to make in the 1990s if they ever get the opportunity to pursue their policy.

PARA.TAB: I have looked at the report and I cannot see any mention of the words `value added' in relation to our current industries. I cannot see any mention of the word `downstreaming' and I cannot see much of a mention of environmental or social considerations, but I do see a lot in this report, and in many of the reports from the Industry Commission, about the so-called efficiency principles. All of these other considerations—the social and environmental costs of unemployment, bad housing and so on and the question of value adding to our industries based here—are not mentioned.

It seems to me that the Industry Commission report is plus cum ultra—the best example—of the approach that has taken us down the wrong path in the 1980s. For example, if we were to look at the Australian economy and ask what went wrong in the 1980s, apart from banking deregulation which was done too prematurely and without proper arrangements set in place to modify excesses, we would say that the second and more important factor is the absolute lack of capacity that this country has had—and, I might say, the willingness as well—to value add to our primary industry base.

We still export our wool uncleaned. We still export too many raw materials from the mining industry unprocessed. We still, on many occasions, ignore the fact that Australia makes a large proportion of its income from primary industries. Yet the very companies that have made billions of dollars out of the primary industry area—from the sweated backs of the farmers; those poor people out there who are living on negative incomes, and have been doing so for years—have put nothing back into value adding to those primary industries. Those companies took the raw materials overseas and got what they could for them. They then took their profits and put them into television networks, beer companies, and everything but the very area where they made their money.

We can come into this place and we can argue about what propositions ought to be put one way or the other in terms of our policies going into this election. But, until every party in this chamber gets down to that simple issue of how we value add to our primary industries, we will all be behind the eight-ball. We can fiddle around with farm subsidies and so on but, essentially, if we do not return the wealth that is created in the primary industries area to that area by value adding, we are throwing away what is, basically, Australia's birthright.
Look around us. Australia pioneered agricultural improvements, and it is terribly efficient in terms of what it gets from each person per acre and so on, whichever way we look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hectares these days.
—Yes, hectares. Australia does not make its own tractors. We do not make our own combine harvesters, despite the fact that we invented them.
—But we used to.
—We used to.
—What happened?

—Basically, what happened was that money did not circulate back into the area where it was originally produced. I look at Fightback and, I might say, I look at some of our programs—I certainly look at the Industry Commission reports—and I say, `There are no answers in those. They fiddle around at the edges. They play around with the taxation system—basically, aiming to make the consumers happy'. There is nothing there to encourage or force people to invest back in this country in the area where they originally made the wealth.

PARA.TAB: I come from Tasmania. For example, in the Derwent Valley, we used to have a thriving fruit industry. We had IXL jams, which was a value adding process that picked up the wealth that was created in that area; similarly with hops. What happened? They were bought out, sold up, capitalised, and the money was used to buy other things elsewhere on the mainland. This report does nothing to solve any of those problems.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. This report will be listed for further consideration tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the nineteenth report of 1992 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on aspects of heavy road vehicle charges, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure commenced its program of public hearings in June of this year and concluded it in October. Hearings were held in Adelaide, Mount Gambier, Melbourne, Perth, Darwin, Canberra and Sydney. During the program the Committee also made field inspections near Mount Gambier, around Yalgoo, Meekatharra, Bunbury and in Darwin.

PARA.TAB: The evidence the Committee received showed that there is widespread concern that uniform registration charges will lead to increases in costs for operators of heavy road transport vehicles and threaten their viability. There is also concern that additional costs will be passed on to users of these services and will lead to higher prices in communities, particularly in rural and remote areas. It is generally acknowledged that the proposed charges will in some locations lead to increases in costs of road freighted goods and in others to a reduction in costs.

In this regard it is important to bear in mind certain qualifications, namely: will operators of road freight services pass on increases or decreases in costs to their clients or will these be absorbed by them; how will States and Territories treat and apply other charges applicable in each jurisdiction to heavy road vehicles apart from the registration fee; and the recognition by the National Road Transport Commission that the level of charges `are not set in concrete' and there are issues applicable to the charges which are still being discussed, analysed and negotiated.

Overall in the evidence the Committee received there is acceptance of the principle of uniform registration charges for the road transport industry. It is hoped that all authorities involved in determining the level of registration charges and other charges will develop a charging regime that is fair and equitable for the industry. If some individual jurisdictions impose additional charges to compensate for lost revenues, the spirit of the principle for reform and uniformity in the industry will be jeopardised.

On the question of total input taxes and charges and whether adjustments to the general level of taxation applying to the industry are warranted, the Committee received diverse comments. Although various studies and comments differed in their findings and the basis of analysis varied, there is a general acceptance that the road industry is taxed at higher levels than most other industries.

The Committee found varying methods of calculation for the levels of taxes and charges applicable to the road transport industry. The conclusions drawn indicate a glaring lack of comprehensive data specific to the industry. This inadequacy needs to be corrected. That is why the Committee recommends that a high priority be given to developing a comprehensive and industry-specific database from which an accurate assessment of the industry's cost imposts can be conducted.

To conduct an immediate inquiry into cost imposts from the existing generalised database would not achieve an accurate result. Until an accurate database exists, any inquiry would only repeat past findings which contain too many assumptions, estimates and qualified conclusions. The Committee supports remedial action on the level of taxes and charges applying to the road transport industry once it can be accurately determined whether the industry is inequitably treated and to what extent, and the Committee has recommended accordingly.

In conclusion, I thank all the contributors to the inquiry—the witnesses who gave oral evidence, the people who made possible the field inspections we conducted and the staff of the Committee's secretariat.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure had referred to it about 12 months ago for inquiry a matter relating to aspects of heavy road vehicle charges. The issue particularly related to the impact of heavy vehicle charges on isolated and regional communities, and of the full recovery of road costs incurred by heavy vehicles. It further related to the level of taxes and charges paid by the members of the road transport industry and whether adjustments in these charges would be warranted with the implementation of full cost recovery measures. The Committee received 117 submissions and heard evidence from 87 witnesses in many locations around Australia. During those hearings, members of the Committee had the opportunity to see heavy vehicles in use and to hold frank discussions with many involved at the coalface of the industry.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties have long been concerned at the very high level of taxes on the road transport industry, particularly the level of taxes that it has had to endure under this Labor Government. It has been acknowledged that those taxes amount to some 3 1/2 times the taxes paid by other industries. Many of the witnesses appearing before the Committee were extremely concerned that many road transport operators would be forced out of operation, particularly having to meet that excessive level of taxation during a period of deep recession.

Recommendation 5.2 of the Committee's report recommends that the National Road Transport Commission extensively publicise that it is continuing to seek input on the charging schedule. I believe that this is an extremely feeble and inadequate position for the Committee to have taken on this particular issue. It merely seeks to appease people living in isolated and rural areas. This recommendation fails to address the real issue that the industry already pays more than its fair and equitable share of the tax burden. In the three years leading up to July 1995, when the new charging system will apply, many operators may already have been forced to leave the industry as a result of the excessive burden of taxation that they are already bearing.

Recommendation 5.4 relates to the establishment of a database of information on the industry, and particularly with regard to taxation of the industry. But that recommendation fails to acknowledge that a timeframe for the establishment of the database is a fundamental requirement of the utility of such a database. There should have been a recommendation from the Committee with regard to the establishment of a specific deadline for the setting up of that database.

Every single one of the 117 submissions to the Committee expressed concern with the levels of taxation levied on the industry, yet the conclusions and recommendations of the Committee report which has been tabled today do not reflect any attempt to redress those inequities. Overall, the report is impotent and, in effect, a whitewash of the Government's overtaxing of the road transport industry. The report fails to address, in the strongest terms, a call for an immediate, extensive and full inquiry into all taxes levied on road transport operators.

When we return to government, the Liberal and National parties will remove many thousands of dollars of the tax burden inflicted by this Labor Government on operators and, as a consequence, reduce the cost of road transport for all Australians. This report does not fully and adequately address the inquiry's original reference points. Firstly, the likely economic and social impact on isolated communities was passed over; secondly, no assessment of the total input taxes and charges paid by industry members appears in the report; and, thirdly, whether adjustment to the general level of taxation applying to the road transport industry would be warranted with the full implementation of full cost recovery has been totally ignored. These issues are addressed in the dissenting minority report lodged by Senators Panizza and Macdonald and me.

We make two particular recommendations: first, that taxes be removed from the transport industry by the abolition of sales tax from trucks, tyres, parts and other transport equipment; and, secondly, that the Government urgently address the inherent unfairness of the 26c per litre fuel excise from fuel sales when it spends only 7c per litre on road maintenance and construction. We believe those recommendations ought to have been part of the major report. We are very pleased to have put them in our minority dissenting report.

The Australian Democrats warrant a mention with regard to this inquiry. The Democrats originally refused to support the coalition's move to lay this legislation aside so that a full inquiry into taxes and charges could be held. But the Australian Democrats, although they did attend some—I would say only a few—of the hearings of this Committee during the inquiry, did not bother to attend the meeting at which the final draft of this report was nutted out by the Committee. For a party whose forebears and founders claim that their role was to keep the bastards honest, they appear to have strayed a long way from the beaten path.

I commend the overall detail of the report, and particularly the information and findings that are contained in that report, to the Senate. As I said, there are severe shortcomings in the recommendations of the majority report, but those shortcomings are addressed by the dissenting minority report of Senators Panizza, Macdonald and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original inquiry was set up mainly to look at the effect of the National Road Transport Commission's uniform charges into rural and remote areas. Those of us from the Opposition who were on the Committee had a different sort of reference in mind. But the Government decided on the reference that the Australian Democrats wanted. It was a simple whitewash. These references were accepted by the Government to avoid the fact that the NRTC was set up without inquiring into what the road industry was doing or expecting and, most importantly, without inquiring into how it would affect people in remote areas.

PARA.TAB: Having claimed the moral high ground for setting up this inquiry, the Democrats took very little or no interest even on the night we had the meeting to accept or reject the report. As I wrote in the minority report, they were not present at that meeting whatsoever. At that meeting, the Government rushed through the recommendations that it put forward, and the Opposition was completely ignored.

Everywhere we went in Australia we received evidence of the effect full cost recovery would have in all areas, whether city, regional or remote. Of course, the remote areas felt the biggest effects of the lot. Evidence confirmed statements made by the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, when he said that the road industry was taxed three and a half times any other industry. Yet, no recommendation was made whatsoever to recognise the fact that the industry is already overtaxed and should not be taxed any further.

The only recommendation that the Committee, as a whole, unaided by the Democrats—they were not there, and I suppose they would have gone along with the Government if they had been there—could make was to set up this database. There is no deadline for the database either.

There is no real need to set up any database. We need to collate data that is already there. Data is not necessarily found in one place. The Committee has recommended the setting up of this database, but all that will do is collate the information into one place. With all the information that the NRTC could have had available, neither it nor this Committee did anything towards collating it. So much for the tax side of the industry.

I will now turn to the impact of full cost recovery on rural and remote areas. I have already said that evidence has indicated that those areas will be affected the most. All the Committee as a whole could say was that in some cases freight rates would go down. They would come down in New South Wales because registration charges in that State are already high. So freight rates may drop and the benefits of that may be passed on. But if freight rates in New South Wales drop and even if the benefits of that are passed on, that does nought for remote areas in Western Australia. The Committee ignored that point altogether.

Because of the higher registration charges in New South Wales, trucks are being licensed in other States. New South Wales is used as a corridor; when travelling from Queensland to Victoria and from Queensland to Western Australia, trucks cross New South Wales. New South Wales is not getting revenue from the registration of those trucks but it has the cost of repairing its roads. If New South Wales agreed to uniform registration charges, the trucks that should be registered in New South Wales would be. Evidence to the Committee suggested that this would happen.

The main part of the inquiry concerned the effect of such charges, but the Committee totally ignored that issue. We have had evidence on top of evidence that higher registration charges would increase freight costs by 3 per cent, 5 per cent, 7 per cent or 8 per cent, depending on the State. Those increases do not seem very much, but when it comes to the effect on net profit they have a vast effect. For example, an increase of 6 per cent or 7 per cent in oncosts could wipe out a farm that is running at a 2 per cent profit.

We made certain recommendations in the minority report. One recommendation is that there should have been a time limit to set up the database. If there is no time limit, the database will never be set up and that will become an excuse for doing nothing.

We also stated that the NRTC should look at the full effect of total taxation on the road transport industry and reflect that in its registration charges. The only recommendation in the main report was that the NRTC could publicise widely that it is looking for more evidence of the effect of such charges on the transport industry. I believe that is a very weak suggestion. The Committee should have recommended to this Parliament that total taxation be taken into account. I believe that the Committee should have recommended that the Government remove some of the unfairness in the road industry where, for instance, only 7c of the 26c a litre fuel excise from fuel sales goes towards improving roads.

All in all, I certainly enjoyed the inquiry. It confirmed many things that I already knew. I enjoyed seeing some of the city based senators and the city based secretariat getting out into some of the remote areas such as Meekatharra, Cue and Bunbury—although Bunbury is not quite so remote—to see what those areas do for Australia and Australian exports. Hopefully they learnt something about what those people and those industries do. Once again, I condemn the Democrats for their non-action. They took the moral high ground in this case and did nothing whatsoever. They are not even here to listen today.

TALK.START.PARA: —They wouldn't want to be. They want to add 16 1/2c a litre to the price of fuel.

—I will take up that interjection. The Democrats suggested the other day that, if they were in government or were supporting a government, they would add 16.9c per litre to the price of fuel. What would that do to the remote areas of Australia where there are important industries?

PARA.TAB: I wish to thank the Chairman for his cooperation during the whole inquiry. As one can see, there is not much that I agree with in the report, but I thank him for his cooperation; it was a pleasure to work with him. I hope that this report does not gather dust because there is a lot of good information in it about the problems of the road industry and the problems of the people and the industries that use those road industries. Unfortunately, that was not borne out in the Committee's recommendations, but it is taken off the shelf by the Hewson Government, we will be looking into it more deeply in order to carry out much needed reform in the road industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in making a few very brief remarks about the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I start where Senator Panizza left off by expressing how pleased I was to be part of this investigation into road transport and heavy vehicle charging throughout Australia. It certainly provided me with a great deal of information about the road transport industry and reinforced my views on the enormous importance of road transport to Australia—particularly its importance to those of us like you, Madam Acting Deputy President, who live in those more remote parts of Australia and who understand the importance of road transport in getting Australia's wealth from where it is produced to the ports and overseas to the export markets. Road transport is also enormously important in getting goods to communities like yours, Madam Acting Deputy President, and any other rural and remote communities right throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: I want to make particular reference to my colleagues who served on the Committee. It was a pleasure to work with the Chairman, Senator Foreman, and to be a member of a committee where the Chairman has a real interest in what is happening and understands what is happening. He is, of course, constrained somewhat by his political allegiances in the sorts of things he might be able to say or do. But I was quite confident that Senator Foreman was well across the issue and it was a pleasure serving on a committee under his chairmanship.

Similarly, the Deputy Chairman, Senator Chapman, was obviously someone well experienced in this area. Of course, when dealing with these sorts of issues, it is also a pleasure to be on a committee with Senator Panizza who has the real hands-on experience in this industry as in so many others. There is really very little that can escape a committee on which Senator Panizza serves because he has a way of making sure that the right information is extracted and put before a committee.

I also pay tribute to the people who gave evidence at the Committee hearings. As with all of these types of committees, people around Australia put an enormous amount of work into their submissions and into the points they wanted to get across to the parliamentary Committee. It gives a very good example of how parliament works and how people can feel they are having a say in the things that happen in the Federal Parliament. The number of people who do respond—and respond so willingly and enthusiastically—is, I think, another step forward in our democratic process.

All of the many people who prepared submissions put a lot of work into them. Those people who were called to give evidence gave their evidence very well and at times, I am sure, at great personal cost to them. They made some very good points that will be of benefit to all members of the Committee who heard them. I hope the Government will take up some of the issues that were raised and the recommendations that have been made.

Briefly, the recommendations of the majority of the Committee led the Government in the right direction. We in the minority did not think they went quite far enough. As my colleagues have said, one of the real problems with infrastructure in Australia, and one which impacts upon so much of Australia's being, is that the transport industry, which is so important in distributing Australia's wealth to those of us who live in the more removed areas, has enormous taxes place upon it. In fact, that brings me to one of the complaints we had with the NRTC—although it got around it a bit by going outside its charter, one might almost say, to do what the Opposition wanted it to do, even though when the Bill was going through the Parliament the Government would not accept our amendment on the point. The Government did not want the NRTC to fully look into all of the taxes on the transport industry that currently exist. In fact, the NRTC did some of that of its own accord.

Our Committee was made very well aware of the enormous taxes imposed in so many different ways upon the transport industry. It was suggested to us that that industry pays more tax than any other comparable type of major industry within Australia at the present time. This Government has ignored the question. It has not been game or prepared to address it. I am pleased to say that our coalition leader, John Hewson, and the Liberal and National parties were—

TALK.START.PARA: —You almost said `Howard' for a moment!
—Senator Bolkus should not be so stupid. We know that Government members are continually in that frame of mind. That is just what the Labor Party is about.
—Do you mean John Howard?

—Our leader, John Hewson, and the Liberal and National parties have been prepared to address the real issues, rather than babbling like Senator West who really does not understand. We have been prepared to address these issues. Senator West claims to represent some rural area. If she does and has any interest in the people she claims to represent, then she will be an enthusiastic supporter of John Hewson's policy to completely abolish the tax on fuel.
—How are you going to fund the roads?

—I thought Senator West was telling us before that she had read the Fightback package. We did not believe her then and she has just proved that she cannot be believed in that regard. It is all there and it is all costed. If she has a look at Fightback she will understand that we have guaranteed—and we have shown where it can be funded—that, out of general revenue, at least as much money as is currently being spent by the Commonwealth on road construction and maintenance will be spent under Fightback, and we will do it at 26c a litre cheaper than the present cost.

PARA.TAB: If Senator West has any interest in the people she claims to serve, she will support that sort of proposal; to get rid of all the costs of getting goods out to—where do you live? It is Orange or somewhere out in the central west of New South Wales, I understand.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Macdonald, would you please address your remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes; thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. My colleague Senator West claims to represent an area in the central west of New South Wales. If she really represents the people there, she will understand the enormous addition to their cost of living as a result of the cost of transport out to those areas.

PARA.TAB: I am not quite sure where Senator West is from. Obviously she is not from an industry which produces the wealth of this country. I do not know what she does or where she comes from, but obviously she is not involved in the wealth producing areas of our nation. If she were, she would understand the cost of getting goods from those areas through to the ports and what transport and additional freight costs are involved.

I am very pleased to say that John Hewson and the Liberal and National parties have adopted this proposal to get rid of the 26c a litre fuel tax. As well, we are removing the sales tax on those trucks. If Senator West had any idea about the people she is supposed to represent, she would join with us in getting rid of that 20 per cent impost, which is sales tax, on the purchase of those trucks.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! Senator West, you may make a contribution later if you wish to. I would like to hear what Senator Macdonald has to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West would be interested to know that a 500-horsepower rig—and I suppose there are a few of them out her way—costs about $250,000. Sales tax constitutes $38,000 of that $250,000.
—How much?

—It is $38,000. Under the coalition, that goes. It has this effect: the leasing costs on that $250,000 truck are, from memory, about $6,000 a year. If one takes off the $38,000, that brings the cost of the truck down. The leasing payments decrease to about $5,000. I am sure of this figure: leasing costs are $1,000 a month less when the sales tax is removed. In the case example that was done, the fuel tax saving amounts to some $26,000; the sales tax saving on tyres and repairs amounts to another $4,000. That truck operator can save some $44,000 every year if sales tax and fuel tax are removed. That is what we think should be done. We think the transport industry is overtaxed. That is why we were required to put in this minority report.

PARA.TAB: Whilst not disagreeing with a lot of what the majority report said, we did go on to recommend that the Government should, as a matter of urgency, address the inherent unfairness of a fuel tax that collects 26c a litre from fuel sales but spends only 7c a litre on road construction. We further recommend that, in relation to the overtaxing of the transport industry, as part of overall tax reform, taxes should be removed from the transport industry by the abolition of sales tax from trucks, tyres, parts and other transport equipment. The minority members of the Committee certainly recommend that Government look at those things, that it adopt those sorts of policies, because that would result in a much fairer distribution of the tax burden and it would be a real boost to the transport industry and all of those people who rely on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on the record a question to Senator Macdonald or the Opposition. Can they say whether all these wonderful things they predict will still be here next Friday?
—Do you expect an answer to that question, Senator West?
—No.
—Can I seek leave—
—You have already spoken.
—I know that, but I seek leave to respond to the question directly asked of me by Senator West.
—Is leave granted?
—On a point of order: I contend that Senator West was cheekily out of order when she asked the question. Two wrongs do not make a right in this case, so I do not think we should prolong the debate.
—Senator Macdonald has sought leave to answer Senator West's question. Senator West should not have put the question if she did not want it answered. Senator Bolkus, has leave been granted?
—Leave is not granted.

—I have not spoken on this matter, and therefore I rise to answer Senator West. I can assure Senator West, in answer to the stupid question she asked, that all those goodies will certainly be in place. She speaks absolute rubbish. I am surprised that Senator West, who represents a country area, is so opposed to truckies getting petrol 26c a litre cheaper.

PARA.TAB: I am absolutely appalled that the people you represent are obviously becoming more and more aware that you would deny them that particular aspect of our Fightback package. Transport is terribly important in a country as big as Australia. You tell us that you support and represent the country people of New South Wales. You speak on every primary industry issue; you are the only one from your side who does. You are hiding your head now. I do not blame you; I would be too, if I were you.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Walters, I would like you to address your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President; I certainly will. Senator West has asked us the question. She has just denied her truckies 26c a litre cheaper petrol—

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. We do have an item before us. Senator West asked a question, which I referred to earlier as maybe not being in order. Any further debate on that, I would contend, is also out of order. Senator Walters can obviously talk to the report.
—I believe that Senator Walters is quite relevant to the matter.
—Of course, I was talking to the report. As I said, Senator West is denying the people in her area the tremendous advantage of $1,000—
—It's $1,000 a month—when they make their lease payments.

—They will pay $1,000 a month less, just on the abolition of the wholesale tax, ignoring all the other petrol cost advantages and all the other advantages of the abolition of the payroll tax in the manufacture of parts, trucks and tyres in Australia. Ignoring all that, Senator West is prepared to deny the people in her area cheaper transport of all the goods that they require. Madam Acting Deputy President, as you can see, she is hiding her head in shame. I do not blame her; I would be, too, if I were her. It is too ridiculous for her to ask a smart alec question and then not expect one of us to respond to it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Imported Food Control Bill 1992 introduces point of entry inspection procedures for imported foods to ensure that they meet Australian food standards. Under Australian law, all Australian primary producers and food processors are required to meet very high food standards. This carries a considerable cost. Australian companies have been complaining that imported foods are cheaper because they are not a source of animal or plant disease and the States were responsible for inspecting food on supermarket shelves under their health authorities.

PARA.TAB: In July 1990 the current system of food inspection, which covers only about 10 per cent of imports, was introduced under the health provisions of the Quarantine Act. It focuses on a small group of products assessed as high or medium risk to human health. Most imported food is not subjected to any inspection. Little is known about how it is grown or under what conditions it is processed. While some countries maintain an effective control over food production, others, which represent a significant proportion of our imports, do not. Allowing this sort of product onto our shelves before checking is a risk that should not be taken. It also gives imported products an economic advantage over product that must meet certain standards.

Even the existing imported foods inspection program with only seven inspectors has found a significant incidence of non-compliance with food safety requirements in the limited amount of food it covers. In the first year, the program found that 8.4 per cent of risk categorised food failed for microbiological contamination, the presence of microtoxins and excessive levels of chemical residues. In the year just ended it was 6.8 per cent.

Products found unacceptable overseas have been redirected to Australia because of our lack of point of entry monitoring, and products rejected in one State have been sent to another State. The National Food Authority, a joint Federal-State body which the coalition supports, has concluded that this is sufficient concern to warrant extending point of entry monitoring to all imported foods to ensure the same safeguards as local produce is subjected to. The States have also agreed. Australian exporters are also subject to very strict food standards imposed by the United States of America, Canada, the European Community, Japan and other countries—often at considerable cost.

This legislation does three things. Firstly, it extends inspection coverage to all imported foods. The focus will remain on public health, but enforcement of other food standards requirements will be included. Secondly, there is provision for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to negotiate certificate arrangements with overseas authorities where AQIS is satisfied that they operate equivalent production control arrangements to those required of Australia. This would largely remove the need for inspection on arrival, although some inspection for auditing purposes would remain. Thirdly, the legislation provides for AQIS to negotiate quality assurance arrangements directly with overseas suppliers aimed at meeting Australian food law requirements.

Monitoring intensity will reflect a food's compliance performance. Current arrangements where high risk classified foods are withheld from release until results of analysis are obtained, and medium risk foods allowed release, subject to possible recall, will continue. About 35 inspectors will be employed and they will come from existing AQIS staff. The inspection will be user pays; money being collected from the importer. The current cost of inspecting imported food is about $2m. It is expected that this Bill will add a further $4.5m to the cost. The total cost is only estimated to add about one-third of a cent to every dollar's worth of imported food.

Importers will pay 100 per cent of all costs, which is identical to the charging of export inspection. The new import inspection system will overcome the problems in a point of sale monitoring approach by the States and local government bodies. It will also improve the present unsatisfactory labelling situation for imported food. However, the States and/or local authorities will be responsible for both food standards and labelling of domestic product. I know that this issue is very close to a number of important policy considerations that have been pursued in this Senate for some time by my colleague Senator Boswell, and I am sure that he will comment on it in the debate today. The new system will bring Australia into line with other Western nations.

Last financial year, that is, 1991-92, Australia imported foodstuffs and skins worth $2.366 billion. This is up $42m from the 1990-91 figure. Of this $2.366 billion, $1.2 billion was for fish, live animals, tea, coffee, spices, beverages, hides and skins, while the remaining $1.1 billion was for food.

I will just go through several of these imported food lines that have come onto the market. Imported vegetables and fruit in 1990-91 amounted to $382.6m; in 1991-92, $469.1m. For live animals, the comparative figures are $73m in 1990-91 and $59.6m in the last financial year. Tea, coffee, cocoa and spices: $308.7m in 1990-91; in 1991-92, $309.2m. Feeding stuff for animals, in 1990-91 the figure was $65.2m; it is now up to $90m. Meat and meat preparations rose by nearly $6m in 1990-91; in 1991-92, the recorded figure was $42.5m. Dairy products, birds and eggs rose by $9m in 1990-91; for the financial year 1991-92, the total figure was $135m. Fish imports in 1990-91 were up by $30m; for 1991-92, a total of $474.5m—a very interesting figure. Cereal and cereal preparations in the last financial year reached $112m. For sugar, sugar preparation and honey—I am sure Senator Boswell would be well aware of this—in 1991-92, $59m worth was imported into Australia. Miscellaneous edible products and preparations for 1991-92 were $306m; and oilseed, which was recorded at $58m in 1990-91, reached $60m in 1991-92.

Under fruit and vegetables, the largest item was orange juice: $23m—up from $9m. Apple juice accounted for $13m—up from $5m. Prepared or preserved vegetable: $39m—up almost $1m on the last year. These vegetables came from 45 countries. It is interesting to consider some of the import figures and from where they are derived: $12.3m from New Zealand; $7.8m from Spain; $4.7m from Canada; $3.4m from Thailand; $2.3m from Greece; $1.9m from Italy; $1.6m from China; and $1m from the USA.

This is an important piece of legislation. Obviously it will have to be under constant review and will need very careful monitoring. However, I am pleased to indicate that the coalition will be supporting the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Imported Food Control Bill 1992 provides for the inspection of foods at their point of entry into Australia to ensure that they comply with Australia's very high food standards. As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) pointed out in his second reading speech, under the current system only around 10 per cent of food imported into this country is actually inspected. The overall failure rate of food last year because of the presence of excessive chemicals or toxins was 6.8 per cent. So we agree that there is a need for a more stringent inspection system. This Bill is largely welcomed by the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Australian food producers work hard to ensure their products maintain consistently high standards. We encourage them in this. It is only fair to them, if they are to compete with overseas products, that those imports meet our high standards and that we have an effective way of policing this requirement.

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service will have the responsibility of overseeing the inspection process. It concerns me a little that the Minister says that these new arrangements will be handled by existing AQIS staff. I seek an assurance from the Minister that AQIS really does have the appropriate number of staff and facilities to adequately carry out an obviously increased workload. What is being proposed is an extremely important task for an integration of both trade and consumer affairs policies.

The Bill provides for imported food to be rejected on a number of grounds, ranging from failing to meet labelling requirements to failing to meet public health standards. Under the Bill, there are three choices available to importers whose food is rejected: they can rework the food by reprocessing or relabelling it and then represent it for inspection. Alternatively, the food can be destroyed, or it can be re-exported to another country which may not have such stringent standards or inspection procedures.

The reworking of food is a viable option when food fails on the grounds of such things as country of origin labelling. It is vital that both the nutritional and country of origin labelling on foods is accurate in order to give consumers as much information about the product as possible. Indeed, along with Senator Boswell, the Australian Democrats have long argued for tougher country of origin labelling so that consumers who choose to buy Australian-made products can do so with confidence.

The Democrats recently proposed a new system of labelling which would leave consumers in no doubt as to how much of the product was actually made in Australia. We have recently begun a trial of this system at supermarkets in Adelaide, and it appears to be working well. So although proper labelling is important for consumers, it is a relatively simple matter for importers to correctly relabel products that have failed on those grounds and then to apply to reimport them.

Food that fails on the grounds of not meeting our public health and safety standards is another matter. As the Minister points out, there have been disturbing reports of food that is contaminated by bacteria and micro-organisms, food with high levels of pesticides and toxic metals and food containing illegal additives and preservatives entering the country and going onto our supermarket shelves. Food that fails public health and safety standards cannot be reworked as easily as changing a label. Some of it can be made into food products for animal consumption and some of it will have to be destroyed, and the Bill provides for this.

It is the third option the Democrats are most concerned about—the re-exportation of food that fails our public health and safety test. The food that has failed our tests can then go to a country which may not have such a high standard or such tough port of entry inspections. In a manner similar to toxic waste, some foods travel the world looking for a home or looking for entry at the weakest ports of inspection. Food actually goes port-hopping until someone takes it or until it can be reworked. It is not unusual for failed food to be reworked in Europe, normally by the process of irradiation, and then shipped off to another port.

The irradiation process is a bonanza to port-hoppers, as the process destroys the micro-organisms that spoil food so that it then lasts long enough to be shipped elsewhere. This is an appalling scenario. The fact that this can happen and we are a part of it I think begs some action on our part.

While Australia does not currently accept irradiated food—and we all know this could change in the future—there is no known method of detecting the process I am talking about. Imported food could be rejected in Australia on public health and safety grounds and then be re-exported, possibly irradiated, and dumped somewhere else. If Australia decides to lift its moratorium on irradiated food, it will be feasible for Australia to become part of the process whereby food is rejected here, irradiated here and either accepted here or shipped elsewhere.

If the food is not fit for us to eat, should Australia then be a party to shipping it off to another country? Why should we give dubious importers the soft option of shipping substandard food elsewhere? It is not fashionable to talk about moral obligations in response to legislation, but surely we have a moral obligation to try to discourage the practice of port-hopping for substandard food. The way to do this would be to amend the Bill to ensure that food that failed public health and safety tests could not be re-exported as it is.

The importer would have the choice of re-working the food into something such as animal feed or fertiliser, or destroying it. This would send a strong message to importers of dubious food that such food will not be tolerated in Australia. It would encourage them, I suggest, to lift their standards. Importers who do not want to risk having their food destroyed will soon learn to comply with our standards. I believe that the responsibility should rest with the importers to ensure that their food meets our standards and to carry insurance in case it does not and has to be destroyed.

In closing, I would point out that food exported from Australia currently enjoys a good reputation as being clean on the world market. Australia may jeopardise this reputation by re-exporting substandard food. While it is true that this food may not be a product of Australia to start with, if it is inferior and it is re-worked here, it would be seen by the rest of the world as coming from this country. I feel strongly that our reputation could quite easily be sullied by this process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Imported Food Control Bill 1992 is important legislation. I concur with what has been said by Senator Kernot and Senator Tambling. I support this Bill, which addresses an area that has concerned me for a long time. I am pleased that the Government has introduced this Bill. I am also pleased with the direction the Bill takes to deal with the issue of imported food. This Bill changes our current food inspection scheme so that all imported food can be inspected at the point of entry into Australia.

PARA.TAB: Australian primary and manufacturing industries have taken a battering in recent years from imported food products. Imported food last year amounted to $2.366 billion, and that was up $42m on the previous year. To give some examples, vegetables and fruit imports increased last year by $86m to $469.1m; meat was up by $6m to $42.5m; dairy products were up $9m to $135m; fish was up $30m to $475m; and oil seeds increased to $60m. With orange juice alone, last year imports were up to $23m from $9m the previous year, and apple juice jumped from $5m to $13m. I think Senator Tambling mentioned some of those figures. Frozen vegetables increased in one year by $7m to $24m, and pineapples went up to $16.2m. That does concern me very much as a Queensland senator. With Golden Circle, we have a very fine pineapple industry in Queensland. Peanuts stood at $13.8m, and dried grapes increased from $8m to $13.8m.

Australia is a major exporter of raw and processed food products. It is in Australia's best interests that international trade goes on. But in recent times an unequal position as to the laws and regulations required to be followed with flow-on effects to trade has existed for Australian producers as compared with their overseas competitors. Australian producers were entitled to believe that there was one law for them and an easier one for importers.

Differences have existed in relation to the health and quality standards between local and imported foods—for example, labelling and packaging requirements, and strict environmental, residue and chemical level requirements. Also, local producers have had to compete against a high incidence of dumped and subsidised food products being sold on the Australian market.

Under the present system, allowing this sort of product onto our shelves without checking introduces a risk for the consumer that should not be taken, and the Australian farmer and processor are forced to compete on an unequal playing field. Australian food products meet a very high health and quality standard. They also meet strict labelling, packaging and environmental standards for products sold on both the domestic and export markets.

By contrast, as the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) said in his second reading speech, a significant proportion of our import trade has not been subjected to an equal level of food product control as our local product. Food inspection in the past has been directed at preventing health threats entering Australia and at remedies after those threats have occurred.

The scheme is now changed by this Bill requiring that the imported food comply with all Australian food standards at the point of entry. Since 1990 about 5 per cent of food imports have been inspected. They have fallen into the high and medium risk categories, including foods such as nuts, cheese and shellfish. In the first year, 8.4 per cent of food inspected failed because of microbiological contamination, and last year the figure was 6.8 per cent.

In recent times there have been many reports of unacceptable standards in foreign food. The actual cans the food was imported in have been found to contain lead solder and dirt. Foreign objects have been discovered in imported food, as well as high levels of insecticide, banned additives and chemicals. Also, products have not complied with our country of origin labelling. The ridiculous situation exists presently whereby many products imported and sold in Australia would not meet the health requirements to be re-exported out of Australia.

Australians do not want their country to become the dumping ground for other countries' surpluses and low quality and unhealthy products. Consumers have stated this, as has the Government's watchdog, the National Food Authority. The National Food Authority concluded that there is sufficient concern to warrant extending point of entry monitoring to all imported foods to ensure the same safeguards as for local produce. The States have also agreed to this approach.

A survey last year by the Victorian Government found that 59 per cent of imported food did not reach the Australian standards for content or labelling. Other countries have had much more stringent imported food laws than Australia. Just this week the US announced sweeping changes to its labelling laws. In the US all food will need to display the amounts of nutrients contained in the context of a daily intake requirement of 2,000 calories and details of weight reducing qualities.

I welcome this Bill, which introduces the possibility to inspect all imported food. However, this Bill will work only if these new requirements are policed effectively. It is most important that this Bill is administered effectively as its consequences are extremely wide ranging.

Before the Christmas break the Senate will deal with other legislation which will be influenced by this Bill. Several Customs Bills will deal with anti-dumping measures and the Mutual Recognition Bill will create uniform standards for goods and occupations across all States and Territories.

My initial concern with our anti-dumping and countervailing laws was prompted by the huge increase in dumped and subsidised goods flooding into Australia and the damage it was doing to our rural primary and processing industries. As a consequence, the Senate inquiry which I initiated to investigate the effectiveness of our laws made recommendations to tighten our anti-dumping and countervailing laws, the majority of which have been introduced.

Still enormous damage has continued to be inflicted on our industries from dumped and subsidised imports. Despite winning its case—which is threatened again by an appeal from the importers—the tomato industry has had to suffer a market share loss of 40 per cent to dumped and subsidised imports. The peaches and pears industry lost 25 per cent of the domestic market to imports. The pork industry has just lost a Customs hearing on dumped and subsidised Canadian pork, and is on its knees as a consequence of competition from subsidised imports.

The presence of even threatened imports lowers domestic returns to producers, but does not necessarily result in lower consumer prices. It is hoped that a more thorough inspection process will pick up the imports which do not meet Australian standards and are competing unfairly with Australian products. Similarly with mutual recognition: if a product meets the requirement of one State it is admissible to all States and Territories, even though the first State may have a lower standard. Under these conditions, it is vital that all imported food be inspected at the point of entry into Australia. At the moment, imports go port-hopping. If they are refused entry to one port, they keep going until they find a port where they skip through the inspection process. It is hoped that this Bill will stop this practice.

Because Australia does not have a system of inspecting imported foods in a comprehensive way, not only has Australian industry lost sales in an unfair way to imports; its development has been stunted. The Australian food processing industry has great potential. At the moment, it is a $30 billion industry. It employs 20 per cent of the manufacturing work force in Australia, some 170,000 people. Australia exports only 3 per cent of processed product. Our raw food exports amount to $17 billion, while our processed food exports amount to $210 billion.

This industry has grown by 17 per cent since 1989. However, $80 billion of value is added to our raw food exports offshore. On our doorstep, Japanese processed food exports have more than doubled between 1984 and 1988. The import market is growing at 30 per cent a year, but Australia supplies only 6 per cent of this market. Thirty-two per cent of Japan's imported processed food comes from the USA. So there is a large market there for Australia and great potential. The potential in Japan and in other Asian countries such as Taiwan is reported to be huge. We have the unique qualities of clean, safe, high quality produce, low pollution levels, an efficient agricultural sector and close proximity. So it was a sorry state for our future to see Australian food producing industries declining under the burden of unfair competition from imports.

I have also been concerned about the issue of country of origin labelling. Numerous surveys have shown that Australian consumers want to buy Australian, but our labelling laws only require the country of origin to be printed at the pinhead size of 1.5 millimetres and do not require the source to appear on the front of the label. Following questions in the Senate by myself and other senators, unpackaged fruit, nuts, fish and vegetables now must be labelled at the size of 4.5 millimetres.

The situation of orange concentrate imported into Australia—at great loss to our citrus industry—has been corrected. Once mixed with Australian water, it was allowed to be labelled `Product of Australia'. Labelling standards are now the responsibility of the National Food Authority. The authority is looking into the labelling of unpackaged meat products. This needs to be done urgently, certainly as it relates to Canadian pork—which Senator O'Chee and Senator Bjelke-Petersen are very concerned about—so that all imported unpackaged raw products are consistently required to display a country of origin label.

I encourage the National Food Authority to correct this oversight with regard to meat and also to reconsider its recent decision not to increase the country of original label size from the inadequate 1.5 millimetres. However, once the labelling issues are determined by the NFA, under this Bill labelling standards will be one of the many Australian food standards on which imported foods will have to toe the line.

I support the Bill. It is long overdue. I hope that it is policed adequately. I am pleased that Australian food producers and processors will at last be given a fairer deal in their competitive trade with imported foods because of the reform inspection process introduced by this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Imported Food Control Bill 1992. The purpose of the Bill is to introduce point of entry inspection procedures for imported foods aimed at ensuring that they meet Australian food standards. I certainly agree that that is very necessary and important and I support the Bill.

PARA.TAB: Australia imports some $2 billion worth of food each year. The current system of imported food inspection, introduced from July 1990 under health provisions in the Quarantine Act, covers only around 10 per cent of this trade. It focuses on a small group of products assessed as high or medium risk in human health terms. I regret that it does not address the broader requirements of Australian food law. The Bill has been introduced to try to remedy that defect. At present it does not cover the importation of Canadian pigmeat. Australian pork producers are vitally concerned that the importation of subsidised Canadian pigmeat is undercutting prices and introducing disease into our market. It is producing a situation which gravely threatens to undermine the financial viability of the pork industry in Australia. Currently, the quality of Australian pork is now the highest in the world. We have no disease in it and we want to keep it that way. I believe that this Bill should take action to make sure that this happens.
