If we continue to import Canadian pigmeat, it will be open slather on the Australian market. As far as this Government is concerned, there will be no health inspection except for document checks.

When the Government had these concerns raised by pork producers right across the country, all it said was that a limitation of 17,000 tonnes would be put on imports. Australia has a healthy and viable pig industry which should not be jeopardised with this sort of threat. It is bad enough just trying to make ends meet working on the land in the current economic climate. Producers do not need to have their livelihoods threatened with the possibility of increased demand from inferior quality and disease-ridden products from overseas. However, the major problem the industry faces is that most other overseas pig producing industries receive the benefit of government subsidies.
The annual report of the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council will come before the Senate in the presentation of reports tomorrow. The report says:

In view of subsequent concerns of industry about a noticeable trend downwards in returns to producers apparently brought about by lower prices of imported subsidised product from Canada setting a floor price . . . Council decided to convene a conference of interested parties during the first week in December, 1991. . .

SPEECH.PARA: The concerns expressed by industry at the December meeting regarding the downward trend of prices were confirmed by the substantial decline in returns to the producers during the May-June, 1992 period.

Consequently, the Pork Council of Australia put its case to the Australian Customs Service. That case was rejected earlier this month. The decision by Customs has made a mockery of the Government's claim of having the fastest and the best unfair trade protection mechanisms in the world. This decision absolutely refutes that claim and must act as a warning to all primary producers that the system does not work and will not protect Australian producers from subsidised imports. Customs said that it was satisfied that subsidies were paid or granted to Canadian producers which had a bearing on the prices paid by processors. However, it reasons that only a small proportion of that subsidy is added on in lower prices.

PARA.TAB: Australian pig producers have every right to feel offended by the decision, which favours Canadian producers in preference to Australian pig farmers. There is also the problem of pork coming in from overseas which we are not sure is disease free. That is what concerns us with regard to this Bill. I quote from an editorial in the South Burnett Times, a local paper in Kingaroy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good paper, too.
—It certainly is; if you read it regularly, you will learn a lot. It says:

PARA.TAB: Rejection of the pig producer case against subsidised Canadian pork being dumped in Australia is yet another tragic example of the failure of Australian laws to protect domestic industries against unfair competition. . .
The Australian Customs Service appears to have developed a policy of proving the producer case then awarding costs against them.
The ACS decisions are rightly described as a miscarriage of justice.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to all the evidence about subsidised imports, the Government was given scientific data on the threat of transmissible gastroenteritis. That is where this matter applies to the Bill. This threat alone should prevent the importation of pig meat. Page 11 of the report says:

Although the Federal Government announced on 30 July, 1990 that it had decided to allow imports of uncooked frozen Canadian pigmeat on the grounds that the ban could no longer be justified on either scientific or economic grounds, Council—
that is, the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council—
continued to be unconvinced that uncooked pigmeat could be imported from Canada without risking the introduction of TGE.
That is why I wanted to speak on this important Bill. The Australian Pork Federation, as well as the Pork Council, is convinced. A newspaper article quoting the Federation said:
I've listened to all the technical arguments and our vets say the Government is looking at the situation from an unrealistic point of view.
In fact they completed a trial, at our insistence, a few years ago.
Results suggested a one in three and a half million chance of disease spread. Yet trials we have done suggest a risk as high as one in 250.
The article went on to say:

It has been reported by an Australian Pork Producer's Federation solicitor, that international and internal government pressures were placed on the Minister to make the decision, and I think the Government's real intent is to facilitate the export of other Australian commodities.

The frustrating thing for people in this industry is that the Government will not reveal its real agenda. Two or three years ago, Canada could not have exported to Australia because of our stringent quality control. I believe it is time that the Government acted to save yet another industry that is being threatened by the unfair trading practices of other nations.

PARA.TAB: I wanted to speak strongly about this issue because I have read many articles about it recently in the South Burnett Times, the very good paper that I mentioned earlier, and I know about the upset and the worry that the import of this Canadian pigmeat is causing the large number of pig producers in our South Burnett area because of the threat of TGE. That is why I believed the Imported Food Control Bill was a good opportunity to speak about this matter. I hope the Government will stop sacrificing all Australia's rural industries on the altar of free trade and look after jobs for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of points which go to specific areas of the Imported Food Control Bill have been made in this debate. I could respond at this stage, but I think it would be more appropriate to do so at the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 1 December 1992, the Imported Food Control Bill 1992 stands referred to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for consideration and report by 14 December 1992.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following Government Business orders of the day be taken together for their remaining stages:
No. 3Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992 and Medicare Agreements Bill 1992
No. 4National Health Amendment Bill 1992

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE (QUALITY ASSURANCE CONFIDENTIALITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1992MEDICARE AGREEMENTS BILL 1992NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate on Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992 and Medicare Agreements Bill 1992 resumed from 11 November, and debate on National Health Amendment Bill 1992 resumed from 12 November, on motions by Senator McMullan and Senator Tate:
That these Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is absolutely bizarre that we are debating three health Bills of this magnitude cognately—the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill, the Medicare Agreements Bill and the National Health Amendment Bill. In fact, we were asked earlier today whether we would debate two other Bills with these, which would have been absolutely ridiculous. I know that Senator Newman, who was to speak first in this debate, is going to deal with the aged care aspects of this legislation so I will not concentrate on that in any detail.

PARA.TAB: The National Health Amendment Bill 1992 seeks to redress a current anomaly in the nursing home benefit payments scheme by enabling the recovery of overadvanced benefits. In addition, it introduces a legislative mechanism to protect the rights of the Commonwealth and prospective purchasers of nursing homes in relation to money owed in the form of overadvanced fees. The coalition supports both of these initiatives. Given the time constraints placed upon me by the Government's inability to manage its business, I am unable to add any more than that. I will leave the details to be dealt with by my colleague the shadow Minister for aged care, Senator Newman.

I think it is important to reiterate the coalition's concern about nursing homes which are in financial difficulty because the Commonwealth can pursue them for overadvanced funding allocated prior to 1 July 1993. This is really a direct result of the Government's failure adequately to monitor the situation on an ongoing basis and to carry out regular reviews. By clawing back funds advanced as far back as 1987, the Government is jeopardising the quality of care provided by some homes and putting their existence into doubt.

The coalition also supports the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill provides statutory confidentiality to information obtained from quality assurance activities and immunity from prosecution for those engaged in conducting these activities. My colleague Senator Herron will speak in depth on this Bill and outline the coalition's concerns about proposed clause 106N, which empowers the Minister to authorise disclosure of information about conduct that may constitute an indictable offence. It is widely believed that this discretion will substantially reduce the effectiveness of quality assurance and quality assurance activities and may undermine the primary purpose of this Bill. I have in fact referred one aspect of this particular clause to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills; I hope that it had time to look at that this morning. I will not speak further on the Quality Assurance Bill except to foreshadow that the Opposition will move an amendment in the committee stage to eliminate this ministerial discretion.

Of the three Bills before the Senate, the Medicare Agreements Bill is, I believe, certainly the most important. It sets up the framework for public health care in Australia for the next five years. It outlines the principles and commitments that the States and Territories must adhere to from July 1993 if they are to receive the $21 billion of funding outlined in the 1992 Budget.

The Government does not have a mandate to force a new Medicare agreement onto the States and Territories from July 1993 to June 1998. We are talking about a period after the next election. A Federal election must be called by May 1993 and this Bill is nothing, I believe, but a last gasp attempt by the dying Labor Government to force its own failed health policies onto the States for yet another five years. One must ask why the Government is so desperate to have this legislation enacted and the agreement signed. There is one reason, and one reason alone, why the Government wants to lock the States into its own failed brand of health care, regardless of whether it maintains power in Canberra.

We ought not make any mistake that this Bill is the Government's health policy for the next election. It is a health policy which has been rejected by over half of the State and Territory governments, which have refused to sign the new Medicare agreements. It is a health policy which has forced one Labor State Minister to resign—Mr Wilson. He has resigned because of Labor's refusal to reform the health care system. He described Medicare as `the most inefficient and ramshackle hospital funding system one could imagine'. It is a very serious thing when a Minister resigns. A Labor Minister resigning at State level when there is a Labor government in power at the Federal level is absolutely amazing, but that is what happened. That is how bad he thought it was. He thought much of the rest of the health policy was bad, too. He raised a number of issues and concerns about the ramshackle system he was dealing with.

The Government's attempt to force this legislation through the Parliament while holding a loaded gun at the heads of the States and Territories is really, I believe, a despicable abuse of our democratic system. We have an election coming up and we are now going to have put in place Labor Party health policies for the next five years. The Government is saying, `We don't care who wins the next election; we don't care about what the people say. We are going to force on the Australian people a health policy for five years'. Regardless of whether it retains power or control of the Treasury, it will decide how the $21 billion will be spent.

There is no urgent need to pass this legislation. Negotiations with the States and Territories could go on; they could go on regardless of whether legislation is passed. In fact, I believe it is more likely that negotiations would be more open and fruitful if the threat of this legislation were not hanging over their combined heads.

The people of Australia must have the opportunity to decide the type of health care system they want. If we pass this legislation, we face the very real prospect of locking the States and Territories into a Medicare system they do not want and which will have been rejected by the majority of Australians at the next election.

One does not have to be Einstein to pre-empt the Government's tactics in relation to health during the coming election campaign. It hopes to get this legislation passed and get as many States and Territories as possible to sign the new agreements, then tell the electorate that the coalition's health policy is unworkable and will undermine the stability of a health care system which has been predetermined by Labor.

I believe that this is a disgraceful attitude. Australians are vitally interested in health care. Health care rates as one of the three most important issues as far as Australians are concerned. A number of votes will be cast by people in terms of how they see the various health policies. It is thoroughly dishonourable and, I think, utterly spineless for this Government to seek to impose its health policy on Australians for another five years regardless of the result of the next election.

If the Government had any courage at all and if the Democrats were really on about what they say they are on about, then we would allow this Bill to lie on the table and get on with the business of explaining to the public how these new agreements—that is, the Government's health policy—will address the crisis in our health care system. The Government would explain how its health policy would eliminate public hospital waiting lists, which are now between 70,000 and 100,000. It would explain why age pensioners are forced to struggle and save to pay for private health insurance and spend thousands of dollars every year on health insurance while somebody, for example, on $70,000 a year pays no health insurance and utilises space that could otherwise be better used by somebody who is in need.

The Government would also explain how it intends to fund a grossly underfunded public hospital system with fewer and fewer people being able to afford private health insurance—and we have seen those figures drop dramatically to the point at present where only about 40 per cent of our population can afford to take out private health insurance. It would explain why people who choose to pay to look after their own health care rather than relying on the public purse are given no incentive to do so—none whatsoever. They do it—many people over 65 in particular—because they are so afraid. They have seen what has happened to their next-door neighbour. They have seen what has happened to that lady who goes into my local news agency week after week deteriorating, requiring a total hip replacement. That is what they see. It would explain why private hospitals are 60 per cent full while people have to wait in pain and discomfort for routine operations in public hospitals.

If the Minister went out and talked to people in hospitals, both private and public, as I have done around Victoria, he would hear them saying, `What we need is a system to encourage people to move into private health insurance'. The public hospitals are saying that as well as the private hospitals. When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has stated that an election could be called at any time, the Government should not be allowed to force an even harsher form of its own failed system of health onto the States and Territories, as I said, for another five years. Instead, it must tell Australians why it persists with a health policy that has caused so much pain and hardship in our community.

For example, the Government ought to explain why 38 people in New South Wales and Victoria have died this year waiting for a coronary bypass; or why someone in Adelaide was told that the waiting time for a tonsillectomy is eight years; or why a Gold Coast person with chronic renal disease was told that someone would have to die before he had access to dialysis; or why a Tasmanian with a malignant melanoma and a bone marrow condition was told that he would have to wait maybe for up to seven months for follow-up surgery; or why a Queenslander who lost 75 per cent of his sight when he was beaten up is still waiting for surgery three years down the track; or why a Sydney boy with a badly torn kneecap had to wait six days, immobile and in pain, for an operation; or why a woman in a wheelchair in Sydney had to wait six weeks before she could see a urologist to ask why she was having trouble passing urine. That is the real face of the failed policies of this Government. They are the waiting lists—real people standing in queues: children, older people, women; people with all sorts of disorders and diseases waiting in queues.

These are the real reasons why this Parliament should not blindly follow the Government, which is trying to force its inequitable and unfair system of health care onto the States and, as I said, onto Australians for yet another five years. The majority of State and Territory Ministers have recognised that this legislation will not achieve the desperately needed structural reforms of our ailing health care system. That was what Mr Wilson was talking about; he wanted real structural changes, real structural reforms. I do not think I have ever been lobbied about a Bill by so many people at senior levels as I have with this Bill. There is great concern.

The problem is that the much needed structural reforms of our health care system are the last thing on this Government's mind. There is an election to win, and Labor believes that if it can run the myth that Medicare is an accessible, universal, free health care system, then it might just win that election. The Government wants to use the rhetoric in this Bill to perpetuate this cruel myth. It does not matter that the health care system that this Bill envisages is financially unattainable. This time last year, almost to the day, we saw a real change in health, a real structural reform; that was the introduction of the Medicare co-payment. We saw the distinct and real possibility of putting in a price signal for medical care, of getting a better service and of reducing overservicing, with the acceptance of about 70 or 75 per cent of the Australian community according to a number of studies. What did we see? A grab for a few votes, and Mr Keating does a backflip. Who should have the hide to talk about backflips? For a couple of votes, one or two votes here in the Senate—maybe even one—overnight, a year ago today, we had a major structural improvement in health care overturned.

What do we see now? The Government is forcing us into a program for five years because it sees that some votes may be involved. In the run-up to the election Labor has decided that the standard of health care in Australia can play second fiddle to its own political objectives. We have seen that happen before; it is not new.

The contents of the Bill show the real motivations behind the Government's attempt to force the new agreements onto the States prior to the Federal election. Currently the Government provides money to the States and Territories for public health care under the 1988 Medicare agreement. New five-year agreements to replace the current agreement which expires in June 1993, as we all know, are being negotiated. This Bill provides a framework under which these new agreements will be negotiated and moneys appropriated. It defines the categories of funding provided by the Commonwealth and stipulates the conditions to which the States and Territories must agree in order to receive the funding.

The Government announced in the 1992 Budget that the Commonwealth would provide nearly $21 billion to the States and Territories under the new agreements. The Bill provides for five categories of financial assistance to the States and Territories: a base hospitals grant; a hospital bonus payment; a hospital incentive package; a mental health package; and other health service funding. This financial assistance will be paid only if the States and Territories sign a formal agreement with the Commonwealth which complies with the heads of agreement at schedule 2A of this Bill. Among other things, this stipulates that funding be used for the purposes of providing public hospital services and that the States encourage the more effective provision of health services. Statistical information must be furnished to the Commonwealth, and a public patients hospital charter describing the application of Medicare principles to public hospitals must be distributed to the public.

The Bill also provides that financial assistance will not be payable unless the States and Territories give effect or make reasonable efforts to give effect to the Medicare commitments and principles enshrined in this Bill. States and Territories must agree to pass complementary legislation in the terms of the commitments and principles in this Bill. These principles include: that eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients; that access to public hospital services is to be on the basis of clinical need; and that to the maximum practical extent a State or Territory must provide public hospital services equitably to all eligible persons, regardless of where they live. States and Territories must endorse two further Medicare commitments to improve the efficiency, effectiveness and quality of hospital services delivery and to make available information on the public hospital services that eligible people can expect to receive. While laudable, these principles and commitments are hardly attainable under the existing Medicare scheme.

At a time when the public hospital system cannot cope, both New South Wales and Victoria have expressed grave concern that the principles fail to recognise the important role that private health insurance has in the provision of health services—and that is not to be enshrined in this legislation, which is an issue, of course, in its own right—and the fact that individuals ought to have the right to choose to be treated in a public or private hospital supported by health insurance. These two States represent 60 per cent of all public hospitals and public patients in Australia. They have stated that they will not be signing the new agreement or enacting legislation complementary to the commitments and principles in this Bill. These two States, with the increase in the Medicare levy, stand to pay a huge amount but to get nothing back.

It is estimated that over the life of the agreement the net loss to New South Wales from this initiative will be $544m, while Victoria will lose $711m. I think the claim by the Government that this incentive package will reform the State public hospital system is farcical. Equally ineffectual is the estimate of $70m over two years to reduce public waiting lists. We saw that happen before from 1987 to 1989. We had a sum of $50m matched dollar for dollar by the States in an attempt to reduce the waiting lists in public hospitals for elective surgery. Like its predecessor, this latest initiative is doomed to fail, because what are needed are structural reforms. The Government has been told over and over again, by Ministers of every colour, that we need structural reforms in the health system. This Bill confirms that the Government is unwilling and unable to implement the reforms that will deliver quality health care to Australians. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992 is a very important piece of legislation and it is a Bill that the Australian Democrats have spent considerable time looking at. We have discussed it very fully.

PARA.TAB: The Bill sets out the statutory framework for the Government's quality assurance program, which aims to improve the quality of the delivery of health services within hospitals. There is little direct Australian data on the quality of patient outcomes—that is, the actual results of health care as far as the patients are concerned—because, until recently, we have had hardly any scrutiny of the quality of care in our health services, and we have not developed much direct evidence about patient outcomes. This is a particular problem when we want to examine adverse outcomes for patients. Unfortunately, when we start to look at when, where and how things went wrong, much of what we have to base our information on is really just anecdotal evidence.

In its recent report on hospital financing and quality of care issues entitled Casemix—fixing the mix, the Health Issues Centre identified two reasons why we find ourselves in this situation. Firstly, we have within our hospital and health services an inadequate infrastructure on which quality measures can be built. Secondly, there is continuing antagonism from some very vocal sections in the medical profession towards any independent form of quality assurance. But things are changing. There is now a recognition within the health professions that quality of care is an issue that cannot be evaded. At present, a range of measures are in place to address the issue of quality in the delivery of health services. These range from formal to informal activities. Some have been instituted by governments and others by the health professions themselves.

This Bill aims to encourage quality assurance activities by providing statutory immunity to any information or documentation which becomes known or is created specifically and solely for quality assurance purposes. This is an attempt to overcome the reluctance of some health professionals when it comes to reporting problems or poor processes in hospitals because of the fear that they may be sued.

Many consumer groups have been highly critical of this move towards immunity. They argue that granting immunity turns what should be an open and accountable process into a closed and very defensive one. They also argue that the obsession with obtaining immunity reflects a narrow, very medical approach to quality assurance where specific medical treatment practices are examined. But other quality issues, which may be just as important to consumers, could be easily ignored—for example, the availability of interpreters; issues relating to informed consent; and issues such as discharge planning. Immunity is also seen by some as reflecting an overriding concern on the part of hospitals and doctors with avoiding litigation, or at least minimising the risk of it, at the expense of ensuring better community accountability to consumers.

Those concerns are valid, but we have to acknowledge the day-by-day reality of medical practice in hospitals. The reality is that the assurance process will not work and, therefore, will not be successful in reducing adverse patient outcomes unless there is some level of statutory protection. The way that the immunity is structured under the Bill is such that the Minister will be able to declare, by disallowable instrument, the Act to apply to a particular quality assurance activity.

A person who acquires information which becomes known solely as a result of declared quality assurance activity must not make a record of that information or disclose it to another person or a court. Similarly, a court cannot require a person to produce any documentation which was brought into existence solely for the purpose of the declared quality assurance activity. In other words, material which becomes known or is created specifically for quality assurance purposes cannot be used anywhere else. Other material which exists independently of the quality assurance activity—which includes all sorts of information on file in hospitals; it may be pathology reports, X-rays, et cetera—may still be used in court.

However, the Government is not putting up a total immunity for quality assurance activities. It is proposing an exemption to the immunity. This is where I come to clause 106N. That clause states that if it appears to the Minister that the information relates to conduct that may have been a serious offence against a law in force in any State or Territory, the Minister may authorise the information to be disclosed for the purposes of law enforcement, a royal commission or any other prescribed purpose. A serious offence is defined as one being punishable by imprisonment for more than a year. The Government has put up an amendment which purports to make it clear that the Minister's authority to disclose is limited to factual information and will not extend to statements of opinion or general comments.

The Democrats have concerns about this amendment because, in fact, it allows the Minister to disclose non-factual material where the information is contained in a report prepared by a person who was engaged in the quality assurance activity. I do not understand why that rider is there and unless the Minister—as he replies to the second reading debate—can give some reasonable explanation for it, I will be moving to delete that part when we come to the committee stage.

The exemption from statutory immunity has provoked very strong arguments both for and against its inclusion in the Bill. I have talked with several individuals and organisations and there are certainly very convincing arguments on both sides. Those arguing in favour of dropping the exemption and providing a blanket immunity for quality assurance activities say that giving the Minister this discretion will undermine the quality assurance programs themselves. They believe the process can only be effective where practitioners are able to freely discuss their actions with their peers, assured of absolute confidentiality. They argue that in practice, where any sort of fairly serious problem arises, a practitioner will contact the Medical Defence Fund and will be advised: `Say nothing. There is no total statutory immunity, therefore, do not get involved'.

Finally, those supporting total immunity argue that such protection does not prevent likely offences from being pursued. Information and data on files and records which have not been raised in a quality assurance activity are still available to be used in other ways, for example, through hospital credentialling, professional disciplinary tribunals, criminal investigations or civil litigation.

On the other side of the fence, we have equally strong arguments for leaving the exemption in place. Probably the most compelling of these is that the exemption really represents an attempt to balance public interest considerations against the value of confidentiality in the quality assurance process. Despite some fears by doctors, the exemption really does not open up the quality assurance process to any great and alarming extent. If a practitioner has committed a serious offence, the argument goes, then he or she should not be permitted to hide behind quality assurance activity and there must be some alternative avenue through which information can be obtained for the possible legal processes, and it can be responsibly used.

Those arguing against total immunity say that, while it is appropriate to offer protection within the quality assurance process where a practitioner has made a mistake or an error in judgment, it is not appropriate where a criminal offence has been committed. Unlike negligent acts or omissions, a criminal offence requires an intention to commit a specific act. Criminal negligence does not involve a strict test of intention, but the elements of the offence involve a reckless disregard for human life. Why should practitioners who intentionally commit serious offences, or are guilty of criminal negligence, be provided with total immunity as part of the quality assurance process? Indeed, I do not think the general public would support that total level of statutory immunity.

In the end—and I must stress that we devoted a great deal of time to this in discussion—we have decided not to support a blanket immunity. I think there is an overriding public interest consideration which basically says that quality assurance is there for the consumers of health services, it is not there to protect intentional criminal activities by health professionals. Having said that, I am still concerned about the purposes for which disclosure can be made by the Minister. I do not have any great difficulty with disclosure for the purposes of law enforcement on royal commissions, but I am not happy at all with the other part of the exemption; the part which will allow for any other prescribed purpose.

It is one thing to say that people participating in quality assurance have protection if the matter needs to go before the law or a royal commission, but what exactly does `any other prescribed purpose' mean? Presumably such purpose will turn up in regulations at some point, but unfortunately tonight we do not have those regulations before us. Health professionals would, I believe, be entitled to feel rather edgy about the potential size of the hole that could be blown in the whole quality assurance process by this particular wording.

It seems to me to be an uncomfortably wide form of words to tack on the end of an exemption to a fairly carefully thought out statutory protection, and I really cannot see why they are there. We can always extend further exemptions if we do have problems in the future, but I would ask the Minister to detail very clearly why we need these final words.

I now turn to the Medicare Agreements Bill 1992. This Bill is a significant piece of legislation which lays down the basis for the Commonwealth Government to enter into new Medicare agreements with the States for the provision of hospital and other services. It seems that the Commonwealth is having some difficulty in getting all States to sign the new agreement. I understand that until recently there was an insistence that the agreement had to be signed prior to the release of $50m allocated in the 1992-93 Federal Budget. This was specifically allocated to cut waiting lists.

However, I note that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced yesterday that the money will be released to the States whether or not they sign. I have a certain degree of cynicism about the timing of the Government's turnaround, but it is a welcome announcement as I do not think that people on waiting lists should have to bear the brunt of some difficulty in negotiations between Federal and State governments. As it stands, South Australia, Queensland, the ACT and Western Australia have given their in-principle support to the agreement, but as yet the Liberal States are holding out.

Following approaches from both the New South Wales Government and the Victorian Government, as well as several other organisations interested in this issue, the Democrats agreed to refer this Bill to a Senate committee. I need to make it very clear why we did so. It is not because we have any great sympathy with the desire expressed by some governments, particularly New South Wales and Victoria, to have the role of private health insurance formally incorporated into the Medicare principles. We do not have any problem at all with doctors and other health professionals practising in a private capacity and do not have any problems with hospitals being privately owned or operated. But we do have a problem with private health insurance being seen as anything other than a supplement to Medicare and we do not believe that it is appropriate for formal endorsement of private health insurance to be incorporated into Medicare. I will return to that matter later if I have time.

Apart from that issue, we have other concerns about the Bill. Firstly, we are unimpressed with the Government's attempts to rush the Bill through parliament. We have to ask, `Why the hurry?'. Surely, the Parliament should have proper opportunity to examine this legislation. After all, it is setting down parameters for agreements which will have a very significant impact on the delivery of health services in this country up to the next century.

Secondly, New South Wales and Victoria in particular claim that they stand to lose millions of dollars under this new agreement. The Democrats believe that these claims need further exploration and deserve detailed examination. I am aware of claims in some quarters that the New South Wales and Victorian governments are just running their own agendas. Indeed they may well be, but they certainly have the right to be heard and to put all their information on the table. Then, of course, we will have the right to ask the Government whether we should be basing our decisions on these sets of figures.

The third concern is about the conditions being imposed on the States in order to actually receive funding under this agreement. As I understand it, New South Wales and Victoria argue that it is not appropriate for Commonwealth financial assistance to be contingent upon the States introducing complementary legislation or, indeed, having to meet any obligations that the Commonwealth chooses to impose on them.

The opposite point of view is that the Commonwealth should be much tougher on the States and should have strings attached to such large amounts of money. There are some groups in the community which have been arguing to us that the strings should be much tighter. One such group is the Chelmsford Victims Action Group in New South Wales which has pointed to that State's Health Care Complaints Bill. It states that this Bill appears to be seriously flawed, but it would be sufficient for New South Wales to meet fairly general obligations to establish a complaints mechanism as set out in this Medicare Agreements Bill. The Chelmsford group—based on its own horrific experiences of inaction by both the medical profession and a series of State governments—argues that the Bill should really be detailed in a very codified form to compel the States to follow very specific sets of terms and conditions.

As we have stated before, the Democrats are not interested in a system which hands over funds unconditionally to the States. We believe the Commonwealth Government has an obligation to taxpayers to ensure the States spend Federal funds responsibly, as well as an obligation to all those people who are currently on waiting lists. Contrary to what the anachronistic States rights lobby likes to imply, the States are not little independent nations who can run around and do their own thing without any obligation. Indeed, sometimes I think we do not work as closely together as the countries of Europe are now trying to do; after all, we are supposed to be one nation.

That does not mean the States do not have the right to try to negotiate a deal with the Commonwealth or to put up a fight for their own terms and conditions. The Democrats can see no reason to support any call for Federal health funds to be simply handed over to the States with no questions asked and no strings attached. I do not have time to go into the particular principles and commitments set out in the Bill. We will be able to look at a lot of those in detail when the Standing Committee on Community Affairs sits on Friday.

I do want to take up briefly the issue of private health insurance. As I have said, we have other concerns about the Bill, but I want to make the position of the Australian Democrats on this matter perfectly clear. An ideological debate is currently going on about whether basic health services should be funded by public or private means. The Democrats—for reasons we have spelt out time and time again—do not believe the predominantly private option offers benefits to anyone other than private health insurance companies, some medical specialists and some private hospitals.

Let us again look at the problems in the United States. Basically, it has an unstable, inefficient, unfair health insurance disaster. It spends 12.4 per cent of its GDP on health while we spend around 8 per cent. Per capita expenditure on health is $2,566 per year, which is more than double the amount we spend. The United States has 4.7 hospital beds per 1,000 people; we have 9.8. Its infant mortality rate is exceeded amongst OECD countries only by Turkey and Portugal. Even our life expectancy exceeds the Americans.

Its health system is in a mess because it has never made an effort on a national scale to move towards a publicly funded system. In the United States, the Government has never been able to get a firm grip on escalating health expenditure. Basically, it is a system that is out of control. This is the path we will be taken down if the Opposition has its way.

What really amazes me about the Opposition's health policies is that, having decided on a central role for private health insurance, it does not stop there. It goes even further and moves away from any continuing role for a Federal government. As far as the Democrats are concerned, it is madness on a monumental scale to suggest that we do not need some stringent government price control and other regulations if we are going to move wholly or even substantially towards private funding of health services. It is lunacy to think we can have private funding and let the medical profession fix its own fees and not end up with a system which is more costly, less accessible and less equitable.

The Opposition is going to force Australians into taking out private health insurance which many do not want—while it talks about freedom of choice—and, at the same time, it is going to withdraw totally the highly effective regulatory and price restraint mechanisms which are currently in place. Make no mistake about it: under the Opposition's proposals, the cost of health care will rise, not just for individuals but for the country as a whole.

Although I do not agree with it, I can accept that there is an ideological point of view which says we should be funding our health care system largely through private insurance. But I just cannot see how the Opposition can argue that, at the same time, we throw out any element of government control. The Opposition is writing doctors, private hospitals and private health insurers a blank cheque at the Australian public's expense. It is going to find that 8 per cent of GDP looks like a pretty desirable figure after a year or two of that.

Contrary to the rhetoric that comes from some medical groups—such as the AMA—on this point, no-one is talking about nationalising private hospitals or the medical profession. All we are saying is that we would rather have our health system funded directly by public money instead of channelling it via the private health insurance industry. In fact, on any standard of efficiency, it would make far more sense to extend Medicare to cover choice of doctor and hospital—that is, public or private hospital share ward accommodation.

Under this scenario, the role of private insurance would be limited to private ward accommodation in public or private hospitals, gap insurance in private hospitals and ancillary services. This arrangement would reduce waiting lists and provide people with a genuine choice of doctor and hospital. It would also promote competition between public and private hospitals. It would ensure our hospital system remains one of the best in the world and that it continues to be funded via taxation rather than through contributions to private insurance funds. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —After that very intriguing speech from Senator Lees, I know that my colleagues Senator Herron and Senator Walters will be looking forward to responding to it. I suspect that the only way Senator Lees has a hope in Hades of getting her particular utopia put in place is based on the tax policy of the Australian Democrats, who intend to introduce a land value tax and reintroduce a tax on deceased estates. I will leave it at that and suggest that perhaps that gives a hint at how the Democrats would see the future of Australia.
—Seven billion dollars of taxes.

—I thank Senator Kemp. Is that what the Democrats will produce in these measures? There will be no businesses left in the country; there are not too many left now after 10 years of Labor rule. If we were ever in a situation of having the Democrats rule, God forbid! I think we would all go to Macquarie Island—the penguins would be preferable.

PARA.TAB: I rise to speak as the shadow Minister for the aged—I will not be addressing the health issues—on the National Health Amendment Bill 1992, which amends the National Health Act 1953. It comprises two distinct elements: firstly, a fundamental revision of the nursing home benefit payments scheme; and, secondly, a legislative mechanism designed to protect the rights of the Commonwealth and prospective purchasers of approved nursing homes.

If we look at the nursing home benefit payments scheme, we see that both the present home funding system and the previous system which existed pre-1986-87 were and are based, to an extent, on cost reimbursement. Funds are advanced to proprietors during the year and at the end of the year that advanced funding is acquitted against the costs incurred by the nursing home in providing that care. This means that, where a proprietor spends less on providing nursing home care than was advanced during the year, the amount of unspent or overadvanced funding must be repaid to the Commonwealth. However, these overpaid or underpaid moneys are not legally characterised as recoverable debts or entitlements, and therein lies the problem.

An idiosyncrasy of the principal Act means that such debts can be recovered or paid only by fee loadings and not as debts which can be pursued through the courts. This means that proprietors who accrue a liability to the Commonwealth for overadvanced funding and then sell their nursing homes cannot be pursued for that overadvanced funding following the sale of the nursing home. There is, however, a statutory duty to recover that benefit from the fees of the new proprietor. This Bill seeks to change the system so that the person who accrues the liability can be pursued for the money, even though he or she no longer owns the nursing home. Unfortunately, the Bill changes the system only prospectively. Any benefits paid prior to the introduction of this change will not be subject to its provisions.

While the amendment is welcomed by the industry—and also by the Opposition—there is some concern about the fact that the Bill changes the system only prospectively. Many nursing homes around the country have suddenly found themselves liable for huge debts—sums of $96,000, $150,000, $250,000 and $300,000—all because the Commonwealth says that services rendered several years ago by the home, often under the management of a different proprietor, cannot be proven. Overadvanced Commonwealth funds are now being clawed back. I believe it verges on immorality, but that is perhaps for a wider audience to decide.

The basic problem is that it is only now that the Commonwealth is carrying out across-the-board assessments to see whether money advanced to the home as far back as 1986-87 can be substantiated by receipts. Any reasonably minded person would ask: why has the Commonwealth not been doing these validations and assessments every year? Why has it been allowed to go on so long, with the result that so much is deemed to be owing for such a long period? I think taxpayers are entitled to know that the government of the day is monitoring how it is spending its money. Of course they are. Nursing home owners could continue their operations for the next year with full knowledge of their financial situation. That is surely only reasonable.

Let me give the Senate some examples which highlight the problem. A nursing home operated by the Association for the Blind in Western Australia has recently been presented with a bill for $250,000 for overadvanced benefits dating back to 1985. Where has the Government been all this time? That money is now being clawed back from the Association for the Blind at the rate of $5,000 a month. Talk about taking pennies off the eyes of dead men!

As a result, the nursing home is operating at a deficit because it refuses to compromise on the standard of service. Would anybody in this chamber expect the home to reduce the standard of service to blind, elderly people in its care? Of course not. Yet this Government is clawing back $5,000 a month from the Association for the Blind because this debt—if it is agreed to be a debt and that is still in doubt and being disputed—goes back for so many years. Despite 15 months of representations to both the political and the bureaucratic system by the Association, this matter is still unresolved. The Association has now, rightly in my view, sought legal advice.

Let me briefly give the Senate another example. A nursing home in Sydney was purchased last year. The new proprietor is now being hit with a bill close to $150,000. Although the Commonwealth had to approve of the purchase of the nursing home, the new proprietor was not advised by either the previous proprietor or the Department of the possibility of this debt hanging over her head. The Commonwealth is reducing the daily per resident subsidy until it reclaims the $150,000. That proprietor is taking legal action against the Commonwealth.

Let me turn to the mechanism to address the sale or transfer of a nursing home. The mechanism provides for a requirement to give notice of a sale of a home; the identification as far as possible about standing overpayments and fee loadings prior to the sale; the disclosure of such financial information to prospective buyers—thank goodness, at long last; and the recovery of overpayments at the point of sale and from the proceeds of sale. Proprietors, who are the vendors in the transaction, will be required to give notice of sale and will be deterred from completing the sale within 90 days of giving notice. Purchasers will also be required to give notice of their intent to purchase.

The period of notice will enable the vendor's claims, books and records to be scrutinised so that prior to completion a fair estimate can be made of any overpayment and any anticipated fee loading which relate to the period up to the sale. Prior to or at completion of the sale, the purchaser will be required to pay to the Commonwealth from the purchase price the amount of the estimated overpayment. Such payments will be deemed to be paid to the vendor as consideration under the contract of sale.

If the amount paid by the purchaser is less than the estimated overpayment, the vendor will be required to make up the difference. The amount of any anticipated fee loading will be advised to both parties so that appropriate provisions can be made. Immediately after completion of the sale, the actual overpayment relating to the period up until the sale will be determined. Any amount held in trust by the Commonwealth will then be acquitted against the actual overpayment. If a greater amount is held in trust, the balance will be paid to the vendor. If a lesser amount is held, the outstanding amount will be recoverable as a debt. These changes are intended to afford greater protection to the rights of the Commonwealth to money owed to it—properly so—and the rights of the purchasers to information about the home they are buying and to a home unencumbered by liabilities accrued by the previous owner.

At last it seems that commonsense is prevailing. How it could have gone on for so long in such an unsatisfactory way to all parties, I do not know. It does give some credence to the belief that there is an ivory tower in Canberra.

Both the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals and the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association believe that this proposal is sensible and that it will certainly avoid repetition of the situations I have described that have led to these enormous debts hanging over the heads of nursing homes. However, while agreeing with the general principle, both those organisations are concerned with the technical approach taken to fundamental contract law. I suppose only the implementation of the legislation and seeing it working in practice will determine whether their concerns are justified. Unfortunately, so many changes in the aged care area seem to have been based on a `suck it and see' arrangement. It is also unfortunate that so many of the changes that have been made have turned out to be not all that satisfactory in practice.

The Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association claims that the manner in which the Government has approached this in such fine detail could create as many problems as it is trying to solve. That is not to say that there is not support for this legislation. Clearly, there is a recognition that it is fixing up an area that has long needed fixing up. I only regret that the Government has not seen fit to move to redress the situation of those who have incurred these debts, for want of a better word, or these liabilities—perhaps that is not the word either. Nevertheless, the people who owed money to the Commonwealth prior to the date of this legislation being implemented are in the same position in which they have been all this time.

It is unsatisfactory. I think the Government should look again at these enormous burdens which are being placed on proprietors who have had this liability and see whether something cannot be done to ease the burden. The example that I gave the Senate of the Association of the Blind in Western Australia, I think, is unconscionable. I fail to understand why it is that the entreaties of the Association have been met with such intransigence, both from the departmental advisers to the Government and from the Government itself.

It is very hard to understand how a government can countenance the removal of $5,000 a week from the care that is to be given to elderly blind Australians. I cannot imagine how the Minister can explain away the justification for removing that money, because clearly it will affect the care that is given to residents in that nursing home today purely on the basis of care that was given to previous residents in that nursing home in the past. I do not think there is any argument that the care was given. The Commonwealth claims only that that money should rightfully be back in the Commonwealth coffers.

It sounds like a pretty cold-hearted government to me that would rob the blind, but there it is. It has not moved to take any action to help that nursing home or the others which are also in difficulties as a result of the existing legislation. At least we can be glad that the legislation is now being amended so that it will not be able to happen in the future, but for the sake of those who are already caught in that trap I urge the Government to look very seriously at what it can do to help them in their current difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —My principal role this evening is to talk about the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill but, having listened to Senator Lees and my colleague Senator Patterson, I cannot restrain myself from talking about Medicare and the aspects of the Medicare Agreements Bill. Mr Deputy President, you know as well as I do that Queensland has had a free public hospital system for 50 years. Senator Jones, who is in the chamber, is also aware of that. For 50 years, people have been able to go along to a public hospital and get free treatment. In 1973 the now Governor-General presented his Green Paper, which was the progenitor of Medibank. Some public servants in Queensland might not have been born then, but the Queensland public hospital system was the model that developed in Mr Hayden's mind to be unleashed on the rest of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I took the liberty of ringing the Royal Brisbane Hospital this week to find out what the waiting list was in the orthopaedics department. After 50 years of free public hospital systems, it takes 18 weeks to get an appointment to see an orthopaedic surgeon at the Royal Brisbane Hospital.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighteen!

—Eighteen weeks. That is just to get the appointment. Once the patient has that appointment and is seen by the orthopaedic surgeon, if he decides that the patient needs a joint replacement, have a guess how long it takes to get that joint replacement. If the patient is lucky, it is 24 weeks before the date of the operation. That is providing it is not over Christmas, because the orthopaedic department closes down over Christmas. A patient is lucky if it is not over Easter. So the waiting period will probably end up being a year.

PARA.TAB: If the patient happens to be over the age of 70 and has a bad chest or a bad heart problem, he probably will not last the distance. I know for certain that there is a patient at the Royal Brisbane Hospital at the moment that the hospital is trying to get up along the system on clinical grounds alone. The hospital wants him to buck the system, to get ahead, to jump the queue. The Medicare Agreements Bill is trying to enshrine that sort of system for the next five years.

Even the most unintelligent among us must realise that there is something fundamentally wrong if we have a system in place for 50 years and it ends up with queues of that nature. What is the answer? The answer is not that those responsible are unintelligent; I would not say that. There has to be an ideological basis for this enshrinement.

I hear Senator Lees talk about how the Democrats would do it. I can tell the Democrats that it has been done in the world. I was in France a couple of months ago, and I investigated the French health system. Everybody loves it. Every patient loves it because there is no difficulty of access. All the doctors love it because they can treat people unfettered by the constraints of money. There is only one problem. This year France is already two billion francs in debt. The country cannot afford it. I have with me some of the posters being put out in France. It is appealing to its patients. The posters read, `Dear Patient, do you really need to go to the doctor? Why not stay home from work and rest? You will get better more quickly.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I am serious. That is the inevitable consequence of the direction in which the Democrats system goes—hospitals appeal to the patients. But I do not want to talk about that. I really want to talk about the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill. I support the purpose of this Bill, Senator Collins will be pleased to know. I think it is the first time that I have actually got up in this chamber and supported a Government Bill. The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the confidentiality of information supplied to bodies investigating and evaluating the quality of medical services and to provide immunity from civil action for members of investigating bodies. Quality assurance itself refers to the process of the monitoring and improvement of the quality of medical services provided.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I again was amazed that Senator Lees has just found out about quality assurance. Quality assurance has been in existence for at least 300 years that I know of, with the formation of the royal colleges and in particular the royal colleges of surgeons. Quality assurance is what medical care has been all about ever since it was institutionalised. The peer review processes, the mortality meetings that occur and the grand rounds that have occurred in all the major teaching hospitals of Australia are evidence of that. It has been going on for centuries.

What is occurring now, of course, is that, with the development of funding and the awareness of the public as a whole about the requirements for community accountability, the States have already introduced quality assurance Bills. On this occasion, the Federal Government is now formalising it at a Federal level and introducing other aspects that are not covered by the State instrumentalities.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I put the question, I wish to make a statement concerning unparliamentary language. After Question Time today Senator Evans asked Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who was in the chair, to refer to me the question of whether it is in order to accuse an honourable senator of telling a `monstrous untruth'. Recently honourable senators on both sides of the chamber have been guilty of accusing other senators of lying. Sometimes I have ignored this when it has occurred in interjections or at times of some disorder. My forbearance should not be taken as condoning the use of such terms.

PARA.TAB: As past rulings have made perfectly clear, it is not in order for a senator to accuse another senator of lying, or to use any other expression which has the same meaning, that is, that a senator has deliberately made a statement which the senator knows to be untrue. Interjections such as `Why don't you tell the truth?' are therefore also disorderly.

I ask honourable senators to refrain from using such language, and I inform the Senate that I intend to enforce the rule against unparliamentary language. I do not wish debate in the Senate to degenerate into an exchange of abuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Collins.
—This is an outrage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, indeed, I want to talk about an outrage. Some years ago Harold Wilson, who was then Prime Minister of Great Britain, was credited with making the statement that a week is a long time in politics. I am quite sure he was not the first to say that, but he has got the credit for it. Since that time it has been endlessly paraphrased by people saying that a day is a long time in politics. Indeed, that paraphrasing is far more accurate because a day is certainly a long time in the life of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr John—`If the GST goes, I go'—Hewson. Yesterday morning, at 8.45, Dr Hewson appeared on the Rod Henshaw program and was asked the following question:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at the moment you're considering changes to the Fightback! package, specifically exempting food from the GST. What can you tell us about that, how about a scoop?
Dr Hewson replied:

Well, there's been a lot of speculation over the entire time since the package came out, and some of it's wishful thinking on the part of some people. What we've said is that we'd keep the package constantly under review . . .
At this stage, Mr Henshaw broke into the interview and said:
. . . that's political double talk by saying anything could happen, isn't it?
Dr Hewson replied:

Well, no. I mean, at this stage we're not making any substantial change, but as I say, we keep it under review. More importantly though, there are parts of the package we are yet to announce. There are elements of the package that we foreshadowed, the detail of which we haven't announced. Now, that that sort of thing we've been doing quite a lot of work on and hopeful of saying something about that fairly shortly . . .
The interviewer interrupted again and said:
Could exempting food from it be one of them?
Dr Hewson replied:
No, What I'm really talking about is some of the other changes in relation to depreciation, child care, some of those areas where we hadn't specified the detail.

Yesterday morning at 8.45, Dr Hewson categorically ruled out any exemption of food from the goods and services tax. Later in the day—that is, at 2.20 p.m. on the same day—Dr Hewson conducted a doorstop interview after meeting Archbishop Hollingworth. During this interview, he said:

I'm going to take an opportunity on 18 December. I've booked the Press Club and I thought at that occasion I would review the year and review the progress we've made with Fightback. I draw attention to the fact that the recession is deeper and more protracted than the Government has admitted and I think, quite frankly, than most people thought.
Later Dr Hewson was asked:
Do these new initiatives include any variations on the GST policy?
Dr Hewson replied:
We will make some changes . . . but the focus won't be on the changes so much as it will be on the new initiatives that we'll announce in the context of the worst recession in 60 years.
This morning on AM—I listened to this interview and I heard the interview yesterday, which is why I am speaking on the adjournment debate this evening—Dr Hewson was asked by the interviewer:
You said there would be no change—
that is yesterday—
Yesterday morning you said there would be no change to the GST on food. Is that still the case?
Dr Hewson said:
No. What I said is I'm not ruling it out and I'm not taking a side one way or the other.

The fact is, of course, that the interviewer on AM was correct this morning—which I knew, having heard the interview yesterday. Dr Hewson has done a total double backflip in 24 hours. Yesterday, at a quarter to 9 in the morning, he categorically ruled out any exemption of food from the GST and today on AM he denied that he had said it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he just changed his mind.
—Let us look at Dr Hewson's views in the recent past on how he was not going to change his mind. On 20 November this year in a Doorstop interview in Adelaide Dr Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if people moved to get rid of the GST from the package, they'd have to remove me.
Again, in an interview with Neil Mitchell on 3AW on 29 April this year, Dr Hewson said:

I mean, I'm said to be inflexible, well, I am, I'm not going to change. I mean it's the only way to be genuinely compassionate in Australia is to take the hard line and call for the decisions and advocate the right policies.
Again, Dr Hewson said:
We are not budging an inch, Laurie, on this proposal, nor the other proposals contained within Fightback. We know they're right.
Again, in an interview on 2HD on 28 August this year, the interviewer said:
Have you any thoughts, though, about changing any particular elements of the GST?
Dr Hewson said:

No. The system has been designed very carefully. It's considered by the experts to be potentially the best in the world, and the fairest in the world. We have a committee, the Cole Committee, which has taken well over three hundred submissions . . . . But we won't be changing any of the essentials of the package.
Again, on 12 March, Dr Hewson said:

We are prepared to stake everything we have got on it. We are not going to change. Two things that you can be sure of. The pressure will mount on us to do two things in the next 12 months in the run-up to the election. One is to change policy and two is to get down in the gutter with Keating, and I can absolutely guarantee you we will do neither.
Yesterday, apparently, we saw the birth of John Hewson as a politician. It was a stillbirth. But I will give the Senate an indication of how a real politician handled this affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his ambit claim for injury?
—No. It is his ambit claim for the leadership of the coalition. I am speaking of John Howard. This morning John Hewson finished his interview on AM by saying to the interviewer:

SPEECH.PARA: The reason none of this has leaked out is because my colleagues are very good at keeping things confidential.
Of course, that was untrue. That untruth was revealed by John Howard, the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, among others. When he was interviewed on these changes, he said:
Well, I don't want to comment on the quality of any possible changes because, frankly, I don't know what they are at this stage.

I understand that Tim Fischer, the would-be Deputy Prime Minister of this country, when he was interviewed in London, said exactly the same thing. He said to a journalist, `Well, I'm on the run, but I actually don't know anything'—

TALK.START.PARA: —You heard this?

—That is what he said, `I'm on the run but I don't actually have any details of these changes. I don't know what they are'. More importantly, when John Howard was interviewed yesterday, he said quite unequivocally that there certainly would not be any changes to the Opposition's industrial relations policy. I recognise political professionalism when I see it, and I recognise this statement for what it is.

PARA.TAB: Six months ago I was told that the New South Wales Liberals, who have always strongly supported John Howard, were putting the heat on Dr John Hewson. I was told that that pressure started off as an irritant to Dr John Hewson but that it had picked up a great deal of strength over the last two months and had now become very serious and John Hewson's leadership was under very real threat. On a local note, Senator Tambling, a frontbencher—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Does Senator Alston dismiss him that easily? Senator Tambling, a frontbencher and shadow Minister in the coalition, was interviewed on the ABC in the Northern Territory. As Senator Button said today in Question Time, it was a fairly extraordinary interview. Senator Tambling told the interviewer, `Yes, I do know about these changes because Dr Hewson consulted me. I am on the front bench and he consulted me'. The Leader of the National Party was not consulted.
—He is out of the country.

—`Out of the country', says Senator Alston. The shadow Minister for industrial relations said, very aggressively, that he was not consulted at all and he did not have the slightest idea of what the changes involved but that there would be no changes to industrial relations. As a fellow politician, I recognise a knife being inserted very neatly between the ribs when I see one; and that one by John Howard into John Hewson was inserted as nicely as it can be in this business.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling made an extraordinary statement on ABC radio in response to a question about the effects of a GST on isolated communities when he said, `The price of just about every product on the shelf in every shop is going to be reduced'. I notice that Senator Tambling has come into the chamber now. His partner on the ticket from the Northern Territory, Mr Arthur Palmer, was caught out very badly by Dr John Hewson and Tim Fischer on national television telling an untruth. Arthur Palmer said on the public record that he had been privately briefed by Dr Hewson that the GST would be set at 12.5 per cent. Dr Hewson and Mr Tim Fischer on national television categorically denied that they had told Arthur Palmer any such thing.

We now have a situation whereby on ABC radio the shadow Minister Senator Grant Tambling has publicly claimed—obviously not realising what his colleagues had said—that he had been consulted by Dr Hewson and knew about these changes and what they were to be, despite the flat statements from Mr Howard that he had not been; from Mr Reith, the shadow Treasurer, that he had not been; and from the Leader of the National Party in London saying that he had not been consulted. I think Senator Tambling has an obligation to clarify the public record. Did Dr Hewson consult Senator Tambling, as he indicated on ABC radio in the Northern Territory, and advise Senator Tambling, as he asserted, of the changes that will be made to the GST?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is none of your business.

—It is my business because Senator Tambling chose to go on public radio and make that assertion, despite the denials of far more senior shadow Ministers in the shadow Cabinet that they had received no notice from Dr Hewson of any such changes. What is at stake here is Senator Tambling's credibility, in the same way that Mr Palmer's credibility has been so terminally damaged by his false statement about being briefed by Dr Hewson on the same subject—the GST.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to reflect on the prescience of columnists such as Gerard Henderson, who could not be accused on his worst day of being a one-eyed supporter of the Labor Party. In a column he wrote on Fightback on 10 December 1991—I referred to it today in Question Time—headlined `Hewson digging his own policy grave' he pointed out the fraud contained in Fightback over the employment projections. He said quite accurately—of course, it is contained in the Fightback document—that the analysis that has been made of the employment projections in Fightback is not based on the Fightback document at all, but in fact is based on projections made by the Industry Commission in a number of its reports on the job projections it predicts if all of its recommendations in respect of micro-economic reform were implemented. Gerard Henderson stated:

In other words, the firm warranty that some 2 million jobs `will' be created and unemployment halved by the end of the century is just a guess. Well meaning, no doubt. Yet a hypothesis just the same. What is more, the AEM model on which this overtly optimistic promise is based does not take into account the inflationary impact of the Coalition's across-the-board goods and services tax (GST). It is all pie in the sky.

SPEECH.PARA: He finishes off the article by saying:

PARA.TAB: I would hope that Messrs Hewson, Reith and Fischer can create an economic climate where 2 million and more jobs are created. But it is a matter of record that the evidence for this expression of faith is not to be found in almost 600 pages of Fightback! documentation.

SPEECH.PARA: The extraordinary double backflip performed by the `immovable, inflexible' Dr Hewson—to quote him—in 24 hours in wanting to dump the Fightback policy and change its basic structure has got nothing to do with Archbishop Hollingworth. It has nothing to do with any rational approach to economics. It is a very familiar—to a fellow politician—attempt to try to shore up and protect a highly endangered leadership. What happened between yesterday morning, when we were told there would be no change and no exemption, and today is quite simply that some Liberal Party colleagues of Dr Hewson said to him—and I can understand this happening—`John, if you don't agree to soften up, if you don't agree to backtrack, if you don't agree to make some changes, we'll take you up on your invitation that if the GST goes you will go'.

PARA.TAB: The reason Dr Hewson cannot enumerate what changes are to be made in Fightback is that, at this point in time, not only do his senior shadow ministerial colleagues not know—I quote Mr Howard again specifically saying, `Frankly, I don't know'—but Dr Hewson does not know, either. Between now and 18 December a number of consultants will have the computers working flat out to try to work out how a new model can be produced and, at the same time, make the figures add up.

The reason I am speaking on the adjournment this evening—and I have referred to the very prescient comment of Gerard Henderson some time ago under the headline `Hewson digging his own policy grave'—is that this rewrite of Fightback, which is occurring under fairly panic-stricken conditions at the moment, will give the Opposition an opportunity now to do what it did not do in the original document. The reworking that is going on will give it an opportunity to restructure the economic model that it uses; to use an economic analysis—a computer analysis of `son of Fightback', or whatever it calls this new approach—to actually produce a real projection of the likely economic growth and the likely employment growth of its new model.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman just made an aside to me which I think well worth repeating—that is, when one injects a corpse it starts to twitch.
—It's called rigor mortis.

—The Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, is obviously very indicative of the changes that have happened today in the Labor Party and how it is reacting to the fact that the agenda has moved. The Labor agenda has again focused back to the principal areas that were very important on 21 November last year when Fightback caught the imagination of the Australian community. Many things have happened in that 12-month period. But most importantly, of course, we need to be reminded of what has happened to the economy in that period. We need to be reminded of just how bad it has become and the number of things that the Labor Party has just not been able to address. In fact, it has compounded the problems in the community.

PARA.TAB: During the course of his comments, Senator Collins referred to an interview that I gave this morning to the ABC's 8.30 AM report in Darwin. But, of course, Senator Collins did not even quote from a transcript. In his usual manner he made up the comments and the statements that he wanted to use. Let me quote from the transcript of that particular interview that I gave this morning. I will refer to two comments, one by Senator Collins here just a few moments ago and one today in Question Time by Senator Button when he obviously drew on comments that were passed on to him or thrown to him by Senator Collins.

Senator Collins made a great deal about the fact that I was consulted by Dr Hewson. I would hope that I am regularly consulted by the Leader of the Opposition, whose team I am proud to be part of. I am a member of the front bench of the Liberal and National parties shadow Ministry. I engage in regular discussions with all of my colleagues, particularly as they affect my portfolio. Let me just read from the transcript a question I was asked this morning. At the end of the interview, the reporter, Clare Martin, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed. Just a final point, John Hewson is consulting with his front bench about these changes, these additions to Fightback!, were you one of those consulted?
My answer was:
I'm on the front bench Clare.
She again said:
You've been consulted?
My answer was:
Of course.

It is very clear that I have certainly been consulted in respect of all of the policy directions of the Liberal and National parties in the last 12 months. In all of the developments that are currently going on, I am part of that process and proud to be so. Similarly, this afternoon at Question Time Senator Button was obviously reacting to some sort of dig in the ribs from someone else. Senator Button, in responding to a question from Senator Hill, said:
