Suddenly the Opposition starts to read the opinion polls—as Senator Tambling commented this morning on Northern Territory radio—and decides that it will change its policies.

Senator Button also would do very well to look at the transcript of the interview. A large number of issues were addressed in that interview this morning. It went, I think, for eight or 10 minutes. Following on from some earlier questions relating to the introduction, the reporter asked me:
So you don't think these proposed changes to Fightback! are related to the poll results?
My answer was:

Very well obviously they are Clare, you know, and we've got, we've always got to accept that you can always do a better job at selling, anyone who's ever worked in selling knows that, but of course they're not, they shouldn't be always painted up as changes. What Dr Hewson has largely been talking about are a number of new initiatives that are going to complement the Fightback!.

Fightback! is a very comprehensive document, it's gone down very very well in the Northern Territory because of the particular advantages for us, and I'm certainly not getting the level of criticism that some of my colleagues are getting interstate.

That was part of that important interview. I know I have not consulted the Minister but, given that he did not extend any courtesy to me with regard to his comments here this evening, I ask the leave of the Senate to table the transcript of that interview.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is important to remind the Senate that the Fightback initiatives have a tremendous number of advantages for people living in northern Australia. I make no apology for the statement that Senator Collins attributed to me that every product on every shelf in every shop in Australia has its price increased at every stage of production by Labor's hidden indirect consumption taxes and other taxes. Of course, the flow-on effects right through will compound those costs, particularly for people living in remote and rural parts of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The cost of food will get a tremendous fillip from the impact of the Fightback initiatives. Senator Collins, despite his portfolio responsibility, did not comment on the transport costs and the changes that will accrue and flow through to people living in remote and rural northern parts of Australia. Under Fightback, we will abolish the petroleum fuel excise and its flow-on effects will mean that the cost of freight in country areas will be slashed.

Many other policies in Fightback will have a dramatic and major impact—air transport; the delivery of services; assistance to the important tourism industry; advantages in personal tax cuts, zone rebates, education, health, business and development—let alone such issues as immediately scrapping Labor's three mine uranium policy, freeing up the Coronation Hill project and reviewing the tax and investment in large scale projects. They will all have a dramatic and major impact. Senator Collins did not mention one of those issues. He did not stand up for the electorate that we both represent. I would have expected him to have made a much more valiant defence of the area that we both seek to represent.

A number of initiatives will complement the Fightback proposals. Some of these have been announced in recent days. We have already had a number of changes in addition to the policy package, including additional funding for TAFE; the extension of our funding commitment to voluntary welfare agencies to $100m a year for each of our first three years in office; a youth jobs policy to assist young people to get jobs and training; and the continuation of existing concessions and allowances for those going off unemployment benefits and on to Austrain or a youth training wage. As Senator Collins properly attributed to John Howard, there will be flow-on effects from Jobsback and our industrial relations policy.

Changes will be made to the announced department of sustainable development. My colleague Senator Alston has been a champion of superannuation and there will be a series of refinements and improvements to the policy area specifically relating to lump sums, annual carry-over contributions, the preservation age and a reduction in fund investment tax to 20 per cent. In science and technology, the tax concessions for research and development will be increased to 150 per cent and in road transport we guarantee that there will be no road user charges in our first term of office.

These are the initiatives that we have been addressing very positively. I have been consulted about each and every one of them, and I am proud of it. I sincerely hope that there will be many more initiatives in the announcements that will flow next week which will really worry Labor, because it does not have any policies. It has no initiatives that will affect people in this area. It just ain't on for Senator Collins to come in here tonight and carry on as if he were the champion of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never foresaw that I would be speaking tonight on the adjournment debate. I only stayed because I am innately courteous. When the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) rose to speak I thought that I would stay as a matter of courtesy. I must admit that I had a faint hope that Senator Collins's speech might have been a witty address or about something of importance. But it turned out to be neither.

PARA.TAB: The Minister put everything in its right context when he started off by quoting Mr Harold Wilson. I lived in England for a long while. I left it with great pleasure the day Mr Harold Wilson won the election. I will say this about Mr Harold Wilson: he was one of the most boring, unimaginative, unintelligent figures to ever be on the public stage of any country. The invocation to Mr Wilson set the tone for Senator Collins's speech because it was a boring, unimaginative diatribe that just went nowhere.

Through all this mess of words, two themes became apparent. The first was a very thinly disguised attack on the Liberal Party because the Leader had exercised a responsible course of action and had agreed to change his policy. There is nothing mysterious about that, and it is of no relevance. He took a responsible position.

But the reason Senator Collins was moved to get into the debate tonight is that the Labor Party is terrified about this change. I will paraphrase the big black headlines on page 2 of today's Courier-Mail. It said words to the effect of, `Labor Party paralysed by review of Fightback and what might come out of it'. Well might the Labor Party be terrified because Fightback has been very well accepted by the community. At least it is a platform on which we can go to the people and say, `We will clean up the mess that we are in'. We did not create the one million unemployed. We did not lift the debt position from about $32 billion to over $200 billion, as the Government has. That is the fear of the Labor Party.

The second thing that emerged in Senator Collins's speech was a nasty little personality squabble between Senator Collins and Senator Tambling. I can well understand Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon having great feelings of inadequacy when faced with the scintillating brilliance of Senator Tambling on the political stage of the Northern Territory. I can well understand that they feel they need to take whatever smart and quick quips they can to try to level the score. But that one senator, Senator Tambling, is very much the equal of Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon. We are prevented from dining tonight because Senator Collins tried to sneakily—

TALK.START.PARA: —Pulling a stunt.

—Yes. He is pulling a stunt to try to level the score with Senator Tambling. The Minister can talk as much as he likes, but he will never catch up with him. Senator Tambling is far too good for Senator Collins in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins carried on for approximately 20 minutes about the fact that the Liberal Party is exercising a responsible position which is eminently defensible and is reviewing its policies with respect to the Australian community in 1992-93. When we wrote Fightback, we had no idea that we would have one million unemployed or that we would have a balance of payments situation that would be totally out of control and very dangerous for the standard of living of the Australian community. We had no idea that we would be faced with a Budget deficit this year of at least somewhere between $6 billion and $8 billion. That is why we are changing our policy, and that is why, when the policies are out, a Liberal government will be returned at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I was provoked. Like my colleague, I had no intention of rising until I heard the appalling performance that was on the screen some short time back, no doubt fuelled by aNiMaLS' best endeavours. We saw a whole sheaf of papers which were put to very little—
—All my own work.

—I accept that it was mostly Senator Collins's own work. One particular piece of the Minister's own work which fascinated me was his obvious compassion and sensitivity and his awareness of the views of leading church people around the country as evidenced by the fact that on not only one, but on two, occasions Senator Collins referred to `Archbishop Hollingsworth'. I would have thought that anyone in this chamber would know that it is Archbishop Hollingworth, without an `s'. For someone who, only a matter of a couple of minutes ago, took exception to what he thought was a slight mispronunciation of the name `Hewson' not to even understand the Archbishop's correct surname, I think gives us an insight into the Minister's true sensitivity in that area.
—Is this going to get better?

—It will, actually, because it is probably going to get personal, too. What I thought was the most fascinating aspect of all, altogether apart from the fact that Senator Collins and his colleagues are absolutely kicking themselves that they did not take what they then regarded as a golden opportunity to have a pre-Christmas election run but instead decided to hang off for a little longer and now, of course, find that the ground has shifted from under them—
—We wanted to give John Howard a go.
—Order on my right!

—What strikes me as the height of hypocrisy is the suggestion that somehow one is not entitled to make adjustments to policies. Senator Tambling has given a number of examples where it has been very successful indeed. As Senator Tambling also pointed out in relation to superannuation, we made some improvements and refinements on 16 August last. The Government has not laid a glove on them; we have not heard boo since that time; and they have gone down very well in the industry and the wider community. I would have thought it is a classic example of the virtues of consultation—as we did with a technical committee and as we have done with the industry over a period of many months. That is the virtue of consultation.

PARA.TAB: What we had Senator Collins get up here today and suggest was that somehow some people on this side were not consulted—that is his allegation—that somehow Dr Hewson made unilateral pronouncements. Therefore, I want to go back only a matter of months to that extraordinary Monday—do honourable senators remember the Greg Louganis episode? In the space of three days we had Mr Keating making the most extraordinary pronouncements and boasting about it, saying that these were backflips of the highest order, but as long as they are done with a bit of panache, than they are all right by him—a touch of excitement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yeah; whee!

—Do honourable senators remember all of that? Of course, there were three of them. TAFE I recall was one. I remember poor old Mr Beazley in the run-up to the youth summit. It was all supposed to be about youth and jobs and, of course, who is responsible in that area? The Minister for DEET. But did he know anything about it? He did not know who was going to attend. Someone told him that there were going to be young people there, and he said, `That's not my understanding'. He then had to admit that his office had not even been consulted.

PARA.TAB: If it is not appalling enough that someone who obviously ought to be in charge of the organisation of that seminar did not even have the slightest idea what was going on, the extent to which Mr Keating consults really became apparent when we had that pay television fiasco. This was all reported chapter and verse by people like Tom Burton and, indeed, we had Senator Schacht confirming it on AM. The Australian, I think it was last Saturday, quoted an unnamed senior colleague as saying, `If I had been Senator Collins, I would have cut my throat long ago'. The fact is that poor old Senator Collins just gets told what happens in the area of communications. In relation to pay television—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you blame them!

—What is terribly significant is that we have had non-stop interjections from Senator Collins for about the last half to three-quarters of an hour; we could not shut him up. Since we got on this, he has not said boo.
—Well, it is disorderly and I have been pulled up by the Chair.

—I am delighted to hear that Senator Collins is bringing himself to order at long last but, unfortunately, I have to say that his actions speak louder than words. It is quite clear that it hits the mark grievously because Tom Burton got it absolutely right.
—Oh, yes, I am wounded to the quick, senator.

—Keating made no bones about this. He boasted about it. Senator Collins waddled into Mr Keating's office with Senator Richardson's submission which, of course, had been on the table for some weeks. Senator Collins, naturally enough, slavishly adopted what the Department put to him; he thought that that was good enough for him, he was not going to start off in the portfolio making any waves.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins put it on the table and what happened? He was called in by the Prime Minister and told what he thought was the new model. This has nothing to do with what the Committee or anyone else might have thought. This was simply policy making on the run of the highest order. The extraordinary thing was that the media was actually captivated by this for a few days and thought it was all great stuff. One does not bother consulting, looking at the facts or researching all the issues; one simply comes to a conclusion.

I have my doubts about how impromptu all that was. I suspect there was a significant degree of input from outside the Department and certainly from one or two major players. It is perfectly clear they did not bother to consult the newly installed Minister. After all, I suppose he was about the sixth Minister in 12 months and they did not particularly want to waste their time talking to someone who may not be there for very long.

The extraordinary thing was that the Minister for Transport and Communications was not consulted. He is absolutely rolled on a regular basis to the extent that he is a laughing stock amongst his colleagues—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong again.

—who feel sorry for him. They would have cut his throat for him to put him out of his misery. Senator Schacht confirmed it on television. Yet he has the gall to come in here and complain about Dr Hewson listening, consulting and taking account of the even more disastrous figures that we have been confronted with in recent times. There is a current account deficit of $1.8 billion, a foreign debt rise of $13 billion in one quarter alone—it now exceeds $200 billion—and unemployment is up to 11.3 per cent.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that these are the sorts of figures which portray and portend disaster and which urgently require responses. What have we had from the Government? Absolutely nothing except personal vilification, scare campaigns, negativism and nasty comments—everything but policy solutions.

Senator Collins has the cheek to complain about Dr Hewson actually getting out there and talking to people whose names the Minister cannot even pronounce, but who are in a position to understand the depth of the recession. I can recall that Richo was wheeled in here on one occasion to talk about some changes in social security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston should refer to the honourable senator by his proper title.
—I meant to say Senator Richardson.
—You can't even pronounce his name.

—That is true, but I did it deliberately. Poor old Senator Richardson got to his feet and started to quote one of the eminent authorities which he described as Erskine and May. Of course, we know it is Erskine May, but he did not know that, any more than Senator Collins appears to know the names of the leading clergymen in this country. I might say that that is a very significant omission, but very indicative of Senator Collins's true level of concern and degree of consultation with those who are actually aware of the human suffering and social consequences of the Labor Government's disastrous policies.

PARA.TAB: To suggest that somehow there is something even vaguely unusual—let alone improper—about Dr Hewson consulting widely in the community and with his colleagues, and then suggesting that there is a need for a response, is the ultimate in hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you read what John Howard said?

—I did. I am probably being pedantic, but it seemed to me that, taking the point Senator Collins was trying to make, and he is suggesting that Mr Howard did not know what was in the changes, if Mr Howard was correct—and I do not know—in saying that there would not be any changes to industrial relations, then presumably he is doing that on the basis of discussions he has had with Dr Hewson. Therefore, it is quite obvious that he does know what is going on in his area of responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins would not seriously suggest that Dr Hewson ought to consult me about Veterans' Affairs any more than Mr Keating ought to consult him about DEET. In other words, I would have thought the sensible and proper thing to do is to consult the relevant shadow Minister or Minister.

Senator Collins may be the grand exception. I have no doubt that he regards himself as an expert in every field with a view on every issue that he would be more than happy to proffer. That is probably another very good reason why the Prime Minister would not even bother consulting him in his own area, which he did not do on pay television, let alone in any other area.

So to somehow suggest that John Howard is only aware of what might be in the package in relation to industrial relations is to show the paucity and poverty of Senator Collins's argument. It demonstrates that he is absolutely desperate; he is very sorry indeed that he did not take what he might now regard as a golden opportunity; and he is very twitchy about the fact that it is a whole new ball game. I can assure him that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. Having listened to the contribution by Senator Collins tonight, I guess we can be happy that he was able to come in here and talk without having had a briefing from Chris Schacht.
—Order! Please use the correct title.

—Senator Schacht, Mr Deputy President. To that extent, we are ahead. Senator Collins had a briefing from aNiMaLS, and I guess that will be a topic which we will pursue elsewhere. Naturally, Senator Collins is obsessed with leadership challenges, but we will have to wait until

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke's book comes out before Senator Collins's role in that disgraceful activity is fully revealed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all in Paul Kelly's book; you can read it now.

—No; we will be waiting to hear what Mr Hawke says about Senator Collins and the loyalty that he showed him. No wonder Senator Collins is obsessed with these things. With his record, with the blood on his hands, no wonder he raises these particular issues.

PARA.TAB: A comment that John Dawkins made about Senator Collins has puzzled me for quite some time. I thought it was a trifle unfair. When I heard Senator Collins's speech tonight, I recalled the comment which John Dawkins made about him, which I thought was a bit unkind—

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you refer to him as Mr Dawkins?
—Mr Dawkins was commenting that Senator Collins's library had burnt down. He said that both books had been destroyed and one had not even been coloured in yet. I think John Dawkins said it all.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as the International Year of Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and co-ordinating activities for International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Since the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) agreed to be the coordinating agency for the International Year for the World's Indigenous People (IYWIP) in April this year, the Commission has:
(a) seconded an officer, Helen McLaughlin, to the UN Centre for Human Rights in Geneva for 12 months to assist the UN in its work for the Year,

(b) established an IDC to address issues of planning, development and coordination of activities with a focus on the identification of Commonwealth programs and activities that can make a contribution from existing resources. A community awareness strategy is also being developed,

(c) allocated from ATSIC funds $1.5m for 1992-93 and $1m for 1993-94 for IYWIP activities. These activities will include community-based projects in each ATSIC region, support for international conferences in Australia and for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in conferences overseas,
(d) endorsed, in principle, National Objectives for IYWIP,

(e) agreed to establish a National Advisory Committee which includes representatives from the States and Territories, the UN Association of Australia, the Council of Aboriginal Reconciliation and major non-Aboriginal organisations,
(f) required ATSIC officers to consider ways in which other existing programs can contribute to the recognition of the Year.

In regard to activities outside the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs portfolio, the Minister wrote to the Prime Minister in July to brief him on the Year and to ask him to strongly encourage all Commonwealth Ministers to develop ways in which programs within their portfolios could contribute to IYWIP activities. The Prime Minister has since written to all Commonwealth Ministers, Premiers and Chief Ministers asking them to develop programs to mark the Year. Commonwealth Ministers have also been asked how best their portfolios can contribute to IYWIP activities, in particular by identifying ways to mark the Year and by providing specific funding.

(3) ATSIC has established an IYWIP Secretariat within the Social Justice Branch to plan and coordinate activities for IYWIP. The Secretariat comprises officers of the Commission and officers seconded from the Departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Social Security and Transport and Communications.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the ceiling placed on the total level of funding available from the Commonwealth for home and community care programs to each State in the financial years 1988-89 to 1991-92.
(2) What did each State spend in matching Commonwealth funding of home and community care programs in the financial years 1988-89 to 1991-92.
(3) What is the ceiling on funding available from the Commonwealth for home and community care programs to each State in the financial year 1992-93.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) While the Commonwealth appropriates an annual amount, including growth funds, for the Home and Community Care Program (HACC) it does not impose a ceiling on individual States or

ANSWER.PARA: Territories. Rather, it manages individual State requirements for funds from within an overall pool. Under the HACC Agreements the Commonwealth does not unilaterally determine the rate of growth in each State. It does however provide a matching contribution towards growth allocated in individual State Budgets. In this way the growth rates may vary from State to State both above and below the national average.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth appropriates sufficient funds to meet the estimated requirements, including growth, of all States and Territories. The agreed growth factor and the reported HACC expenditure, in each State and Territory, in respect of the nominated years were:

(3) For 1992-93, the Commonwealth budget provides growth of 11.45% nationally over 1991-92 expenditure. This level was set in expectation of State requirements. This growth rate is not an upper limit, but a national average which, as in previous years, will enable States to nominate the level of matching they require.
